Title: Flexible eddy current array measurement system for crack detection in weld zones of steel structures
Affiliations: Yokohama National University, Yokohama, Japan; Trường Đại học Giao thông vận tải, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Yokohama National University, Yokohama, Japan; Kanagawa Institute of Industrial Science and Technology, Ebina, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Trung, Le Quang, Research Unit of Safety Science for Advanced Engineering Systems, Yokohama National University, Yokohama, Japan; Khuong, Nguyenduc, Faculty of Electrical and Electronics Engineering, Trường Đại học Giao thông vận tải, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Dung, Tran Thi Hoai, Graduate School of Environment and Information Sciences, Yokohama National University, Yokohama, Japan; Kasai, Naoya, Research Unit of Safety Science for Advanced Engineering Systems, Yokohama National University, Yokohama, Japan, Graduate School of Environment and Information Sciences, Yokohama National University, Yokohama, Japan; Kiet, Tran Mach Tuan, Graduate School of Environment and Information Sciences, Yokohama National University, Yokohama, Japan; Sekino, Kouichi, Department of Mechanical and Materials Engineering, Kanagawa Institute of Industrial Science and Technology, Ebina, Japan; Fukuda, Honoka, Graduate School of Environment and Information Sciences, Yokohama National University, Yokohama, Japan
Abstract: Crack detection in weld zones of steel structures is essential for ensuring structural safety and reliability. Eddy current (EC) testing is widely used due to its non-contact nature and high sensitivity to surface and sub-surface cracks. This study reports a flexible eddy current array (FECA) sensor with six bendable channels designed to detect surface and sub-surface cracks in the weld zones of steel structures. The excitation coils are connected in series to enhance signal intensity, while interleaved detection coils minimize lift-off effects and improve sensitivity. A real-time measurement system was developed by integrating the FECA sensor with a LabVIEW-based digital lock-in amplifier. Experiments using 500 kHz and 5 kHz excitation frequencies demonstrated effective detection of surface and sub-surface cracks, respectively, including under zinc coatings. Despite manual scanning, stable and repeatable signals were recorded across multiple channels. The proposed system offers high sensitivity, real-time capability, and adaptability to complex geometries. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Enhanced dye treatment and bioelectricity generation in microbial fuel cells: the role of magnetite-inoculated anode and cosubstrates
Affiliations: Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Faculty of Engineering, Kyoto, Japan; Gunma University, Maebashi, Japan; Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Tran, Minh Duc, Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Nguyen, Thu Huong, Department of Environmental Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Kyoto, Japan; Watari, T., Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan, School of Chemistry and Life Sciences, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kubota, Keiichi, Cluster of Materials and Environment, Gunma University, Maebashi, Japan; Setoguchi, Tomoki, Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Hatamoto, M., Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Yamaguchi, Takashi, Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan, Department of Science of Technology Innovation, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan, School of Chemistry and Life Sciences, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: This study investigated the influence of cosubstrate complexity and magnetite-inoculated anodes on microbial fuel cells (MFCs) treating synthetic dyeing wastewater (500 mgCOD/L, 50 mg/L Reactive Black 5). Two MFCs types were constructed: one with magnetite pre-inoculated anodes (MFCM) and another with sludge-only inoculated anodes (MFCS). Both MFCs were operated with either starch or ethanol as the cosubstrate, and in both cases, MFCM consistently outperformed MFCS. For instance, with starch, MFCM achieved 99 % decolorization and a peak voltage of 380.74 mV within 30 hours, compared to 89 % and negligible, unstable voltage in MFCS. A 1500 Ω resistance was optimal for decolorization and electricity generation in MFCM. Microbial analysis revealed that magnetite pre-inoculation enriched electroactive genera, enhanced diversity and extracellular electron transfer, and stabilized microbial networks across cosubstrates. These findings highlight the potential of magnetite pre-inoculated anodes as a novel practical strategy for early anode biofilm control, with significant implications for scalable MFCs applications. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Long term effects of salinity on pollutants removal, microbial community and membrane fouling in an anoxic membrane bioreactor
Affiliations: Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; College of Engineering & Applied Science, Milwaukee, United States; Cheng Shiu University, Kaohsiung, Taiwan; Cheng Shiu University, Kaohsiung, Taiwan; Seoul National University of Science and Technology, Seoul, South Korea; Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan

Abstract: This study employed a lab-scale anoxic membrane bioreactor (MBR) to evaluate the treatment performance, microbial community, and membrane fouling at salinities ranging from 2.5 to 15.0 g NaCl/L. Sharply increasing salinity to 5.0 and 15.0 g NaCl/L caused adverse effects on the performance, resulting in loss of active biomass and reduction in organic removal and nitrification capacity. Specifically, the abundance of Proteobacteria declined from 81.5 % at 2.5 g NaCl/L to 56.1 % at 5.0 g NaCl/L and 43.5 % at 15.0 g NaCl/L. Higher salinities (10 – 15 g NaCl/L) promoted irreversible fouling (R<inf>f</inf> was 33.5–40.6 %) due to the increased secretion of soluble extracellular polymeric substances (EPS), which adsorbed onto the membrane pores. The presence of Chlorofexi could promote the formation of larger flocs and a decrease in irreversible fouling. Ultimately, the optimal condition for an anoxic MBR treating saline wastewater could be up to 15.0 g NaCl/L, suitable for various industrial applications. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Flexible thermoelectric generator with radiative cooling for body-heat-driven self-powered Bluetooth low energy sensing system
Affiliations: King Mongkut's Institute of Technology Ladkrabang, Bangkok, Thailand; Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Industrial University of Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; King Mongkut's Institute of Technology Ladkrabang, Bangkok, Thailand
Authors with affiliations: Gobpant, Jakrit, Department of Physics, King Mongkut's Institute of Technology Ladkrabang, Bangkok, Thailand, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Toan, Nguyen Van, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan, Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Industrial University of Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Ono, Takahito O., Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Kim Tuoi, Truong Thi, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Tran, Ngoc Dang Khoa, Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Industrial University of Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Limsuwan, P., Department of Physics, King Mongkut's Institute of Technology Ladkrabang, Bangkok, Thailand; Klongratog, Bhanupol, Department of Physics, King Mongkut's Institute of Technology Ladkrabang, Bangkok, Thailand, Electronic and Optoelectronic Device Research Unit, King Mongkut's Institute of Technology Ladkrabang, Bangkok, Thailand; Rudradawong, Chalermpol, Department of Physics, King Mongkut's Institute of Technology Ladkrabang, Bangkok, Thailand, Electronic and Optoelectronic Device Research Unit, King Mongkut's Institute of Technology Ladkrabang, Bangkok, Thailand; Sakulkalavek, Aparporn, Department of Physics, King Mongkut's Institute of Technology Ladkrabang, Bangkok, Thailand, Electronic and Optoelectronic Device Research Unit, King Mongkut's Institute of Technology Ladkrabang, Bangkok, Thailand
Abstract: Wearable electronics and wireless IoT sensors are increasingly expected to operate in a self-powered manner. However, their practical deployment remains limited due to the lack of compact, flexible, and sustainable energy sources. Thermoelectric generators (TEGs), which convert body heat into electricity, present a promising solution but are typically hindered by small temperature gradients and the requirement of bulky heat sinks that compromise flexibility. To address these challenges, we developed an ultra-thin flexible thermoelectric generator (FTEG) integrated with a radiative cooling (RC) layer that passively enhances heat dissipation under natural convection. The device, fabricated using high-performance thermoelectric materials on a soft silicone substrate, maintained a total thickness of just 2.26 mm. Finite element modeling and experimental validation confirmed that the RC layer effectively increased the temperature gradient across thermoelectric legs, significantly improving the output power compared to conventional graphite-based or no-cooling designs. The FTEG achieved a maximum normalized power density of 3.51 μW/cm2 under temperature conditions representative of wearable use (T<inf>skin</inf> of 32 °C and T<inf>ambient</inf> of 26 °C). The harvested energy was then stored using a power management circuit and capacitor. This stored energy was successfully used to power a Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) sensing module, enabling stable wireless transmission driven entirely by body heat. These results highlight the practical potential of integrating passive radiative cooling into flexible thermoelectric systems, paving the way for high-performance, battery-free wearable electronics and autonomous IoT applications. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Neutronics benchmark calculations of the NuScale-like SMR core using SCALE/KENO-VI
Affiliations: Vietnam Atomic Energy Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Vietnam Agency for Radiation and Nuclear Safety, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; University of Sharjah, Sharjah, United Arab Emirates; University of Fukui, Fukui, Japan; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Thi Dung, Vietnam Atomic Energy Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Nuclear System Design Engineering, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Ta, Duylong, Vietnam Atomic Energy Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Vietnam Agency for Radiation and Nuclear Safety, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vu, Thanh Mai, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Department of Mechanical and Nuclear Engineering, University of Sharjah, Sharjah, United Arab Emirates; Namizono, Shinichi, Research Institute of Nuclear Engineering, University of Fukui, Fukui, Japan; Mai, Huu Thuan, School of Engineering Physics, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Huu Quyet, Vietnam Atomic Energy Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Ha Pham, Nhu Viet, Vietnam Atomic Energy Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: A neutronics benchmark for a NuScale-like core has been proposed under the Euratom McSAFER project using Monte Carlo solutions from Serpent 2 (v2.2) and the nuclear data library ENDF/B-VII.1. The benchmark aims to facilitate code-to-code comparisons in neutronics calculations for light-water cooled small modular reactors (LW-SMRs), driven by growing global interest in their deployment due to advanced technology, licensing progress, and commercial viability. This highlights the need for high-fidelity analyses to assess the design, safety, and operational features of these reactors. This study focuses on performing neutronics benchmarking calculations of the proposed NuScale-like core using SCALE/KENO-VI, evaluating k-eff, control rod worths, and power distributions with ENDF/B-VII.1 continuous energy (CE) and 252-group libraries. The impact of ENDF/B-VII.0, VII.1, and VIII.0 libraries on neutronics results was also assessed using Serpent 2 (v2.1.31). Results show that SCALE/KENO-VI with ENDF/B-VII.1 CE and 252-group libraries aligns well with the reference, with discrepancies within 44 pcm for reactivity prediction and generally less than 2 % for power distribution, except for the all-rods-in scenario using the 252-group library, which shows a reactivity deviation of 139 pcm. In addition, Serpent 2 with ENDF/B-VIII.0 produced notable differences in the k-eff values compared to ENDF/B-VII.0 and VII.1. Consequently, this work provides valuable and significant neutronics reference data for the proposed NuScale-like core model. Moreover, the NuScale-like core model developed here using SCALE/KENO-VI can serve as a basis for future neutronics and core performance analyses for NuScale-like reactors and other similar LW-SMR designs. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: G., Li, Guo; M., Salem, Mohamed; K., Ben Hamad, Khlid; T., Senjyu, Tomonobu; S., Ueda, Soichiro
Author full names: Li, Guo (59090575100); Salem, Mohamed (55611614700); Ben Hamad, Khlid (57209651997); Senjyu, Tomonobu (57535907000); Ueda, Soichiro (59939501300)
Title: Adaptive-robust control for frequency and voltage stability in multi-terminal DC wind energy systems
Source title: International Journal of Electrical Power and Energy Systems
Affiliations: Nanyang Normal University, Nanyang, China; Nanyang Normal University, Nanyang, China; Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; USM Engineering Campus, Nibong Tebal, Malaysia; Fezzan University, Murzuq, Libya; University of the Ryukyus, Nishihara, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Li, Guo, School of Intelligent Manufacturing and Electrical Engineering, Nanyang Normal University, Nanyang, China, Collaborative Innovation Center of Intelligent Explosion-Proof Equipment, Nanyang Normal University, Nanyang, China; Salem, Mohamed, Institute of Research and Development, Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam, School of Engineering & Technology, Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam, School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, USM Engineering Campus, Nibong Tebal, Malaysia; Ben Hamad, Khlid, Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Fezzan University, Murzuq, Libya; Senjyu, Tomonobu, Faculty of Engineering, University of the Ryukyus, Nishihara, Japan; Ueda, Soichiro, Faculty of Engineering, University of the Ryukyus, Nishihara, Japan
Abstract: In this paper, in order to investigate the stability of the power system as much as possible in the presence of offshore wind farms (OWF) and multi-terminal direct current network (MTDC) based on voltage source converter (VSC), two main aims are pursued. The first aim is to design a two-level integrated control (TLIC) for frequency support at the level of grid-side VSCs (GSVSC). The first level of TLIC is based on adaptive inertial controller (AIC) and adaptive droop controller (ADC). At this level, by adjusting the coefficients of the AIC and ADC controllers, all wind units (WU) that are in their maximum power point tracking (MPPT) mode will work to compensate for the secondary frequency fall (SFF). To achieve this aim, first, WUs are divided into different clusters based on their rotor speed, so that they can be operated sequentially to support the frequency. In the second level, TLIC has been used to establish a fair power flow between GSVSC stations by measuring local frequencies in the onshore power system (OPS), which is called Communication Free Allocation (CFA). In addition to supporting the OPS frequency, this design is able to compensate for the SFF deviation when the WUs are in their MPPT operation. The second aim of this paper is to design a H<inf>∞</inf> resistant controller based on loop shaping at the WSVSC station level. The proposed H<inf>∞</inf> method relies on the mutual characteristic decomposition method (MCDM) for voltage control. DC of MTDC network is designed in such a way that the plant model based on Master-Slave (MS) can reduce MTDC voltage fluctuations under internal and external disturbances. Response the simulation results are evaluated and analyzed in the form of different scenarios that have been done in the MATLAB software environment. Examining these results shows that the proposed plan for damping fluctuations caused by various uncertainties in the power system is very robust. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: N.T., Anh, Nguyen Tuan; B., Ta-Duy, Bach; T., Nguyen-Duc, Tuyen; G., Fujita, Goro
Author full names: Anh, Nguyen Tuan (58706973900); Ta-Duy, Bach (59557867500); Nguyen-Duc, Tuyen (58169197000); Fujita, Goro (59901472200)
Title: A novel approach to optimize and allocate battery energy storage system in distributed grid considering impact of demand response program
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Anh, Nguyen Tuan, School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Ta-Duy, Bach, School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen-Duc, Tuyen, School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Department of Electrical Engineering, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan; Fujita, Goro, Department of Electrical Engineering, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Maintaining grid voltage within operational limits poses a significant challenge in distribution power systems, particularly with the increasing integration of Renewable Energy Sources (RES). This paper introduces an innovative management strategy for Battery Energy Storage System (BESS) to ensure reliable voltage regulation in distributed power systems with substantial Photovoltaic (PV) integration. The proposed method integrates grid sensitivity factor with Second-Order Cone Programming (SCOP) modeling for power flow. BESS's optimal size and location are determined by minimizing the total cost of operation, voltage deviations, power losses, and peak demands in the distribution network. Additionally, the study explores the impact of Demand Response (DR) on BESS size and placement. The method's effectiveness is demonstrated using a modified IEEE 33-bus system with actual load and PV generation data. By incorporating BESS's optimal charging and discharging into traditional power flow analysis, grid parameters such as voltage and power flow accuracy are validated. Simulation results show the optimization model's effectiveness, emphasizing the benefits of properly coordinating BESS in distribution systems with integrated PV. The numerical results indicate that the integration of BESS allocation with DR demonstrates that the proposed approach achieves a substantial reduction in energy losses (19 %), highlighting the effectiveness of the method in ensuring grid reliability under high PV penetration scenarios. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Y., Zhou, Yuqing; X., Fu, Xiao; T., Tang, Tianli; K.D., Vo, Khoa D.; E., Hato, Eiji
Title: Assessing resilience of transit networks: An activity-based space-time accessibility analysis
Affiliations: Southeast University, Nanjing, China; Nanjing Normal University, Nanjing, China; Key Laboratory of Virtual Geographic Environment, Ministry of Education, Nanjing, China; Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou, China; Industrial University of Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Zhou, Yuqing, School of Transportation, Southeast University, Nanjing, China; Fu, Xiao, School of Transportation, Southeast University, Nanjing, China, School of Geography, Nanjing Normal University, Nanjing, China, Key Laboratory of Virtual Geographic Environment, Ministry of Education, Nanjing, China; Tang, Tianli, School of Transportation, Southeast University, Nanjing, China, School of Civil and Transportation Engineering, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou, China; Vo, Khoa D., Faculty of Information Technology, Industrial University of Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Hato, Eiji, Department of Civil Engineering, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Transit network (TN) in urban areas plays an important role in facilitating sustainable urban development, yet disruptions to these networks can significantly reduce their capacity and influence individuals’ behaviours, leading to substantial socio-economic consequences. In recent years, many resilience measurements have been developed to assess transport network performance under disruptions. However, few of these assessments precisely capture the variations of individuals’ daily activity-travel patterns that arise in response to TN disruptions. Considering the spatio-temporal correlation between activity behaviour and travel behaviour, this paper presents an activity-based space-time accessibility measure for assessing the resilience of TN. This method integrates individuals’ activity and travel choice behaviours, TN, and activity locations into a unified framework. Multiple scenarios are designed concerning various disruption occurrence times, disruption levels, recovery times, activity location plans, service times at activity location, and transit vehicle headways to comprehensively capture the factors influencing TN resilience. The effectiveness of the proposed measure is demonstrated by a case study in Xi'an City, China. The results indicate that the proposed activity-based approach is capable of reflecting the dynamic performance of TN by considering the attraction of activity locations as well as network topology and passenger flow. The measure enables policymakers to accurately quantify resilience and develop contingency plans by considering how individuals’ activity-travel patterns change following disruptions. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: V., van Thanh, Vuong; N., Tuan Hung, Nguyen
Author full names: van Thanh, Vuong (36949866300); Tuan Hung, Nguyen (56912954900)
Title: Strain Effect on Rashba Splitting and Phonon Scattering to Improve Thermoelectric Performance of 2D Heterobilayer MoTe2/PtS2
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan
Authors with affiliations: van Thanh, Vuong, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tuan Hung, Nguyen, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan
Abstract: Rashba spin-orbit coupling significantly modifies the electronic band structure in two-dimensional (2D) van der Waals (vdW) heterobilayers, which may enhance their thermoelectric (TE) properties. In this study, we use first-principles calculations and Boltzmann transport theory to explore the effect of strain on the TE performance of 2D vdW heterobilayer MoTe<inf>2</inf>/PtS<inf>2</inf>. A strong Rashba spin-splitting is observed in the valence band, resulting in an increase in the Seebeck coefficient for the p-type. The lattice thermal conductivity of MoTe<inf>2</inf>/PtS<inf>2</inf> is remarkably low, about 0.6 W m-1 K-1 at 300 K, due to large anharmonic scattering. Furthermore, biaxial strain enhances the power factor (PF) by introducing band convergence. At a strain of 2%, the optimal PF for the n-type material reaches 170 μW/cmK2, indicating an approximately 84.78% increase compared to the unstrained state (92 μW/cmK2). Given the low lattice thermal conductivity, the optimized figure of merit ZT achieves up to 0.88 at 900 K for the n-type. Our findings indicate that MoTe<inf>2</inf>/PtS<inf>2</inf> is a highly promising candidate for 2D heterobilayer TE materials owing to its strong Rashba splitting and significant anharmonicity. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: N.T.M., Minh Tu, Nguyen Thi Minh; D.T., Giang, Dinh Thanh; N., Quan, Nguyenminh
Author full names: Minh Tu, Nguyen Thi Minh (36928998600); Giang, Dinh Thanh (59988612500); Quan, Nguyenminh (59158504700)
Title: Ginger processing and applications in Vietnam's food industry:a comprehensive review
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Minh Tu, Nguyen Thi Minh, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Giang, Dinh Thanh, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Quan, Nguyenminh, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: Ginger (Zingiber officinale Roscoe), a perennial herbaceous plant belonging to the Zingiberaceae family, has been used for centuries in various industries, such as foods, cosmetics, and pharmaceuticals, due to its health-beneficial and aroma compounds. Vietnam plays a significant role in the global ginger market, ranking 4th in terms of ginger cultivation area and contributing approximately 5% of worldwide production Click or tap here to enter text.The present review focused on the preliminary processing of ginger, as well as different processing techniques like drying dried ginger powder and ginger starch), distillation (essential oil), extraction (oleoresin, wine and liquor), and fermentation (pickle and candied). A comparison is drawn between the traditional and modern methods to achieve a higher yield of ginger essential oil and ginger oleoresin. Additionally, other applications of ginger in food preservation (seafood and post-harvest products), food flavoring (instant ginger tea, jelly, beer, and liqueur) and the utilization of ginger residue are also discussed. This study provides an overview that highlights the diverse production processes of ginger products while emphasizing the utilization of semi-finished or by-products of ginger for other food-related purposes. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author full names: Linh, Huynh Nhut (59988267900); Giang, Nguyen Truong (59987310400); Tien, Nguyen Thi My (59988268000); Truc, Nguyen Pham Xuan (59988075700); Thi, Bui Minh (59988075800); Hieu, Le Trong (58172746600); Quang, Hong Vinh (58172746700); Kiep, Do Minh (59987690500); Morita, Hiroyuki (7402384527); Hue, Bui Thi Buu (57194059039)
Title: Synthesis and cytotoxicity evaluation of thiazole conjugated amino acid derivatives
Source title: CTU Journal of Innovation and Sustainable Development
Affiliations: Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; University of Toyama, Toyama, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Linh, Huynh Nhut, Department of Chemistry, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Giang, Nguyen Truong, Department of Chemistry, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Tien, Nguyen Thi My, Department of Chemistry, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Truc, Nguyen Pham Xuan, Department of Chemistry, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Thi, Bui Minh, Department of Chemistry, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Hieu, Le Trong, Department of Chemistry, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Quang, Hong Vinh, Department of Chemistry, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Kiep, Do Minh, Institute of Natural Medicine, University of Toyama, Toyama, Japan; Morita, Hiroyuki, Institute of Natural Medicine, University of Toyama, Toyama, Japan; Hue, Bui Thi Buu, Department of Chemistry, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam
Abstract: This paper presents the three-step synthesis and cytotoxicity evaluation of the thiazole-conjugated amino acid derivatives. Starting from the commercially available benzophenone and thiourea, the thiazole structure was successfully constructed bearing the free amino groups at the C-2 position, which was then coupled with the carboxyl functionality of N-Boc L-phenylalanine, N-Boc L-proline and N-Boc L-tryptophane using CDI as the coupling reagent under mild basic conditions to provide the hybrid thiazole/N-Boc amino acid derivatives 5a-c. Finally, the acidic promoted deprotection of the Boc groups afforded the desired hybrid thiazole/amino acid derivatives 6a-c in reasonable total yields. Cytotoxicity assays indicated that the hybrids thiazole/L-proline (6a) and thiazole/L-tryptophan (6c) exhibited rather good cytotoxicity on the cervical cancer cell line (IC<inf>50</inf> =18.86 and 18.25 µM, respectively). Notably, compound 5a having the thiazole conjugated with unprotected N-Boc L-phenylalanine showed very good activity towards the lung cancer (IC<inf>50 =</inf> 15.72 µM), the cervical cancer (IC<inf>50 =</inf> 8.98 µM) and the breast cancer cell lines (IC<inf>50 =</inf> 8.07 µM), which were 1.3-, 1.2-and 2.5-fold, respectively, stronger activity than 5-FU (IC<inf>50</inf> = 20.73, 10.67 and 20.43 µM, respectively). © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Evaluation of adsorption and desorption of wastewater onto rice husk biochar on the course of hydroponic nutrient production

Authors with affiliations: van Nguyen, Quang, Faculty of Environmental Sciences, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Center for Advanced Technology Development, Thai Nguyen University, Thai Nguyen, Viet Nam, Technology and Waste Utilization, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Department of Bioresource Sciences, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Nguyen, Khai Manh, Faculty of Environmental Sciences, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Technology and Waste Utilization, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Department of Bioresource Sciences, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Nguyen, Hung The, Faculty of Environment, Thai Nguyen University, Thai Nguyen, Viet Nam, Department of Bioresource Sciences, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Tuan, Duongdinh, International School, Thai Nguyen University, Thai Nguyen, Viet Nam, Department of Bioresource Sciences, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Dong, Mai Ngoc Thi, International School, Thai Nguyen University, Thai Nguyen, Viet Nam, Department of Bioresource Sciences, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Tran, Hang Minh Thi, Faculty of Environmental Sciences, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Technology and Waste Utilization, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Department of Bioresource Sciences, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; van Hoang, Hung, Center for Advanced Technology Development, Thai Nguyen University, Thai Nguyen, Viet Nam, Department of Bioresource Sciences, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan
Abstract: Wastewater management nowadays targets simultaneously contaminant removal and further utilization while the operation needs to be affordable and comprehensible. This study investigates the adsorption of pristine human urine and the secondary effluent wastewater onto rice husk biochar and subsequently producing hydroponic nutrients using desorption for growing Ocimum basilicum L. (O.basilicum L.). SEM, BET, EDS, XRD, and FTIR were employed to characterize the adsorbent. The results demonstrated that rice husk biochar exhibited excellent adsorption performance, with total organic carbon adsorption efficiency ranging from 60 to 80%, depending on the type of wastewater. Also, 50% of total nitrogen, 70% of phosphorus, and about 80% of potassium were adsorbed onto the biochar. Desorption from human urine–adsorbed biochar produced a solution with 236.5 mg/L N, 256.73 mg/L P, and 4.6 mg/L K, which was then used to grow O. basilicum L. in comparison with the Hoagland solution. The growth indexes of the plants were slightly lower but comparable in statistical perspectives. Nevertheless, the nutritional profile was better and the economic efficiency was superior, thanks to the low costs in nutrient preparation. A potential mass production of hydroponic nutrients based on human urine adsorption–desorption, which also resolves wastewater issue was subsequently asserted for future application. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Comprehensive Statistical Analysis for Characterizing Water Quality Assessment in the Mekong Delta: Trends, Variability, and Key Influencing Factors
Affiliations: Ho Chi Minh City University of Natural Resources and Environment, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Thuyloi University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Ho Chi Minh City University of Transport, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Doan, Vu Thanh, Hydro-Meteorology and Water Resource Faculty, Ho Chi Minh City University of Natural Resources and Environment, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Faculty of Water Resources Engineering, Thuyloi University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Le, Chinh Cong, Faculty of Water Resources Engineering, Thuyloi University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Le, Hung Van Tien, Faculty of Water Resources Engineering, Thuyloi University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Trieu, Ngoc Anh, Faculty of Water Resources Engineering, Thuyloi University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vo, Phule, Faculty of Environment and Natural Resources, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tran, Dangan, Faculty of Water Resources Engineering, Thuyloi University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Hai Van, Faculty of Water Resources Engineering, Thuyloi University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tabata, Toshinori, Department of Agro-environmental Sciences, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Vu, Thu Thi Hoai, Institute of Civil Engineering, Ho Chi Minh City University of Transport, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Abstract: The Mekong Delta, an important agricultural and economic hub in Vietnam, has suffered from severe water quality issues caused by both natural and anthropogenic forces. This paper aims to conduct a rational statistical approach to evaluate the current situation of surface water quality in the Mekong Delta, applying Factor Analysis (FA), Principal Component Analysis (PCA), and Agglomerative Hierarchical Clustering (AHC) to a database of 3117 samples collected by national and provincial monitoring stations. The results revealed significant contamination with organic pollutants (BOD5: 3.50–172.870 mg/L, COD: 6.493–472.984 mg/L), pesticides (e.g., DDTs: n.d to 1.227 mg/L), trace metals (As: 0.006–0.046 mg/L, Cr: n.d–1.960 mg/L), and microbial indicators (Coliforms: n.d–45,100 MPN/100 mL), often higher than the WHO drinking water threshold. PCA/AHC analysis identified the following five major pollution components: (1) organic pollution and sewage/industrial and deposited chemicals (PCA1—23.08% variance); (2) pesticide and agricultural runoff derived contamination with Hg (PCA2—15.44%); (3) microbial pollution of the water was found to correlate positively with Zn and Cu content (PCA3—8.90%); (4) salinity was found to mobilize As and Cr (PCA4—8.00%); (5) nutrient/microbial pollution presumably from agricultural and sewage inputs (PCA5—7.22%). AHC showed some spatial variability that grouped samples in urban/industrial (Cluster 1), rural/agricultural (Cluster 2), and a highly contaminated one, where water was toxic and presented with microbial and Cd contamination (Cluster 3). Levels of pesticides, Cr, and microbial pollution were higher than reported in previous Mekong Delta studies and exceeded regional trends. These results emphasize the importance of holistic water management strategies, including better wastewater treatment, pesticide control, sustainable farming, and climate-adaptive measures to reduce saltwater intrusion and safeguard drinking water quality for the Mekong Delta. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Agglomerative Hierarchical Clustering; Factor Analysis; Mekong Delta; Principal Component Analysis; Water Quality; Agricultural Runoff; Drinking Water; Pesticide; Salinity; Surface Water; Water Management; Water Quality; Mekong Delta; Viet Nam

The support provided by MOST was instrumental in facilitating data collection, analysis, and interpretation, contributing significantly to the completion of this study.

Authors: N.T., Nguyen, Ngoc Tung; M.S., Le, Minh Son; H.P., Truong, Hoang Phuong; P.C., Nguyen, Phong Canh
Author full names: Nguyen, Ngoc Tung (59938898600); Le, Minh Son (59938898700); Truong, Hoang Phuong (59939515600); Nguyen, Phong Canh (59939316300)
Title: Heritage-Based Evaluation Criteria for French Colonial Architecture on Le Loi Street, Hue, Vietnam
Affiliations: University of Sciences, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Graduate School of Global Environmental Studies, Kyoto, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Ngoc Tung, Faculty of Architecture, University of Sciences, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Le, Minh Son, Faculty of Architecture, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Truong, Hoang Phuong, Faculty of Architecture, University of Sciences, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Phong Canh, Graduate School of Global Environmental Studies, Kyoto, Japan
Abstract: The architectural legacy of the French colonial period forms a key part of Vietnam’s urban identity, especially in Hue. Yet, this heritage is rapidly declining: from over 240 structures in 2000, fewer than 100 remain today. This study introduces a heritage-based evaluation framework to assess and preserve French colonial buildings using Le Loi Street, Hue’s historic “Western quarter” as a pilot site. Fourteen colonial-era buildings were systematically assessed through field surveys and expert consultation. A total of 40 specialists participated in the criteria development process, and eight selected experts conducted detailed building evaluations. The final framework includes three main categories and nine specific criteria, based on a 100-point scale, incorporating architectural integrity, historical and cultural significance, contextual fit, and adaptive reuse potential. The results show that all the surveyed buildings qualify as Group A or B, warranting strict conservation or minimal renovation. The study emphasizes the value of localized, expert-informed approaches to heritage planning. The research provides a practical foundation for integrating historic architecture into context-sensitive urban conservation strategies in Hue and comparable Southeast Asian contexts. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Iron oxides/zeolite X composite derived from rice husk ash: fabrication and physicochemical properties for superior heterogeneous Fenton-like oxidation of crystal violet
Source title: Journal of Chemical Technology and Biotechnology
Affiliations: Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Widya Mandala Surabaya Catholic University, Surabaya, Indonesia; National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, Taipei, Taiwan; RIKEN Center for Sustainable Resource Science, Yokohama, Japan; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Tran-Nguyen, Phuong Lan, Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Ly, Kim Phung, Department of Molecular Biology, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Santoso, S. P., Department of Chemical Engineering, Widya Mandala Surabaya Catholic University, Surabaya, Indonesia; Tran, Nguyen Phuong Dung, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, Taipei, Taiwan; Angkawijaya, Artik Elisa, RIKEN Center for Sustainable Resource Science, Yokohama, Japan; Nguyen, Hong Nam, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Huynh, Quoc Khanh, Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Mai, Ngo Truong Ngoc, Department of Chemical Engineering, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Minh Nhut, Department of Chemical Engineering, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Dang, Giao Huynh, Department of Chemical Engineering, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam
Abstract: BACKGROUND: A straightforward and robust technique to develop a heterogeneous Fenton-like catalyst is demonstrated, involving the incorporation of iron oxides into zeolite X derived from rice husk ash, which improved the removal efficiency for crystal violet (CV) with high dye concentration. RESULTS: The synthesis of an iron oxides/zeolite X composite (IOZX) was investigated at room temperature with an iron salt to zeolite X ratio of 10 wt%, an ion exchange time of 5 h and 15% NaOH. With a surface area of 312 m2 g−1, the obtained IOZX also comprised SiO<inf>2</inf> (40.96%), Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> (32.08%), Na<inf>2</inf>O (24.07%) and Fe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> (2.72%). Besides, the uniform distribution of iron oxide particles in the composite was determined by scanning electron microscopy and transmission electron microscopy. IOZX exhibited excellent CV removal performance at concentrations ranging from 200 to 500 mg L−1. After 30 min, 96.87% of CV was removed at the optimal conditions such as pH 7, a catalyst dose of 0.5 g L−1, 10 mmol L−1 H<inf>2</inf>O<inf>2</inf> concentration and a 300 mg L−1 CV concentration. The degradation followed the pseudo-first-order kinetic model, with R2 close to 0.99. The catalytic activities were effectively retained after 10 reaction cycles, indicating the robust performance of IOZX. CONCLUSION: The key success of the current work was the formation of an IOZX catalyst derived from affordable and commonly available byproducts, leading to cost reductions and supporting sustainable practices. The synthesized catalyst could be further advanced and potentially applied for the remediation of cationic dye from aqueous solution. © 2025 Society of Chemical Industry (SCI). © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: C., Le Dinh, Cuong; T., Fujiwara, Takeshi; S.T.P., Phu, Song Toan Pham
Author full names: Le Dinh, Cuong (57222016137); Fujiwara, Takeshi (55502389900); Phu, Song Toan Pham (57406473300)
Title: Plastic Leakage Pattern and Municipal Solid Waste Management Toward Circular Economy
Source title: Process Integration and Optimization for Sustainability
Affiliations: Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Le Dinh, Cuong, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; Fujiwara, Takeshi, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; Phu, Song Toan Pham, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam
Abstract: Plastic pollution is a global environmental problem recently. Moreover, existing linear economy has also worsened status of plastic pollution. Thus, controlling plastic pollution and transitioning from linear economy to circular economy are becoming urgent. Municipal solid waste management plays a fundamental role in plastic pollution control and transition to circular economy. This study aimed at understanding status of plastic leakage and clarifying reversed logistic system in Danang city, Vietnam. The waste flow diagram (WFD) and material flow analysis (MFA) based on principle of mass balance were applied in this study. Yearly unmanaged plastic waste was estimated at 2198 tonnes. The amount of plastic waste leaked into aquatic environment was estimated at 0.99 kg/cap/year. Majority of unmanaged plastic waste mainly originated from uncollected waste (78.05% of total unmanaged plastic waste) and collection service (21.36% of total unmanaged plastic waste). Regarding informal reversed logistic system, itinerant buyers and waste pickers considerably contributed to recyclable waste recovery, collecting with about 69.34 tonnes (79.32% of total recovered recyclable waste) of recyclable material on a daily basis. Despite potential for circulation, other types of recyclable waste — glass, textile and leather, wood, as well as rubber — have not been widely collected for recovery. Results of this study offer scientific base for managers, policymakers, decision makers and related stakeholders of solid waste management system. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

(59901644600)
Title: Highly stable and efficient photoelectrochemical water oxidation at an anisotropically crystallized monoclinic WO3 film with predominant growth of the (202) plane
Affiliations: Niigata University, Niigata, Japan; National Institute of Technology, Japan, Hachioji, Japan; Yamagata University, Yamagata, Japan; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Ho, Hau H., Department of Materials Science and Technology, Niigata University, Niigata, Japan; Zahran, Zaki N., Department of Materials Science and Technology, Niigata University, Niigata, Japan; Chandra, Debraj, Department of Materials Science and Technology, Niigata University, Niigata, Japan; Katsuki, Tomohiro, Department of Materials Science and Technology, Niigata University, Niigata, Japan; Tsubonouchi, Yuta, Department of Materials Science and Technology, Niigata University, Niigata, Japan; Hoshino, Norihisa, Department of Materials Science and Technology, Niigata University, Niigata, Japan; Shiroishi, Hidenobu, National Institute of Technology, Japan, Hachioji, Japan; Ishizaki, Manabu, Yamagata University, Yamagata, Japan; Kurihara, Masato, Yamagata University, Yamagata, Japan; Chu, Hung M., School of Materials Science and Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: An anisotropically crystallized monoclinic WO<inf>3</inf> film was synthesized on a fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) electrode by a one-step hydrothermal method using oxalic acid (Oxa) as a structure directing agent. The WO<inf>3</inf> film (denoted as WO<inf>3</inf>(w-Oxa)) prepared with Oxa was composed of relatively large layered-sheets with 2-5 μm length with predominant growth of the (202) plane (parallel to the substrate), in contrast to small layered-sheets with 1-2 μm length with predominant growth of the (020) or (200) planes for the WO<inf>3</inf>(w/o-Oxa) film prepared without Oxa. Although the photocurrents were generated above 0.6 V vs. RHE for WO<inf>3</inf>(w-Oxa) and WO<inf>3</inf>(w/o-Oxa) electrodes, the incident photon to electron conversion efficiency (IPCE<inf>420</inf> = 38%) at 420 nm and 1.23 V vs. RHE for the former was 2.7 times higher than that (14%) of the latter. The higher IPCE<inf>420</inf> for WO<inf>3</inf>(w-Oxa) is ascribed to higher charge separation (η<inf>sep</inf> = 50%) and catalytic (η<inf>cat</inf> = 95%) efficiencies compared to those (η<inf>sep</inf> = 19% and η<inf>cat</inf> = 82%) for the WO<inf>3</inf>(w/o-Oxa) electrode. Photoelectrochemical impedance spectroscopy (PEIS) measurement suggested effective bulk charge transport in the WO<inf>3</inf>(w-Oxa) electrode compared to the WO<inf>3</inf>(w/o-Oxa) electrode, with advantages suppression of charge recombination, being responsible for the higher η<inf>sep</inf>, eventually causing a higher IPCE for the WO<inf>3</inf>(w-Oxa) electrode. The WO<inf>3</inf>(w-Oxa) electrode showed high photocurrent stability (95% maintained for 7 h) and a Faraday efficiency (FE<inf>O<inf>2</inf></inf>) of 95% for water oxidation. The high stability and FE<inf>O<inf>2</inf></inf> for the WO<inf>3</inf>(w-Oxa) electrode result from the suppression of the competed photo-oxidation of the surface by the attenuated hole accumulation due to efficient water oxidation at the (202) facet surface, which is supported by surface energy calculation of the exposed (202), (020) and (200) facets. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Rational Design 2D Heterobilayers Transition-Metal Dichalcogenide and Their Janus for Efficient Water Splitting
Affiliations: University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Center for Innovative Materials and Architectures, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Bao, Nguyen Tran Gia, Faculty of Physics and Engineering Physics, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Trang, Ton Nu Quynh, Faculty of Physics and Engineering Physics, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Thoai, Nam, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Phan, Thang Bach, Center for Innovative Materials and Architectures, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Thu, Vu Thi Hanh, Faculty of Physics and Engineering Physics, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tuan Hung, Nguyen, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan
Abstract: Direct Z-scheme heterobilayers with enhanced redox potential are viewed as promising for solar-driven water splitting, arising from the synergy between intrinsic dipoles in Janus materials and interfacial electric fields across the layers. This study explores 20 two-dimensional Janus transition-metal dichalcogenide (TMDC) heterobilayers for efficient water splitting. Using density-functional theory (DFT) calculations, we screen them based on band gaps and intrinsic electric fields to identify promising candidates, then further assess carrier mobility and surface chemistry to fully evaluate their overall performance. By examining the alignment of synthetic and internal electric fields, we distinguish between Type-I, Type-II, and Z-scheme configurations, enabling the targeted design of optimal photocatalytic materials. Furthermore, we employ the Fröhlich interaction model to quantify the mobility contributions from the longitudinal optical phonon mode, providing detailed insights into how carrier mobility, influenced by phonon scattering, affects photocatalytic performance. Our findings demonstrate the potential of Janus-based Z-scheme systems to overcome existing limitations in photocatalytic water splitting by optimizing the electronic and structural properties of 2D materials, highlighting a viable pathway for advancing clean energy generation through enhanced photocatalytic processes. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Mercury contamination of sediments at Indonesia Ciujung watershed: contribution of artisanal small-scale gold mining
Affiliations: Badan Riset dan Inovasi Nasional, Central Jakarta, Indonesia; Prefectural University of Kumamoto, Kumamoto, Japan; Vietnam National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Universitas Andalas, Padang, Indonesia; Universitas Pendidikan Indonesia, Bandung, Indonesia

Abstract: Artisanal small-scale gold mining is the largest artificial source of mercury pollution and has been a very common problem recently. This study examined the contribution of Hg release due to artisanal small-scale gold mining in contaminating the sediment of the watershed in Indonesia. Different from other methods, we measured Hg pollution using the stable isotopes of carbon and nitrogen. This report is the first time analytical reports in Indonesia since most papers focus primarily on only detecting heavy metals in river water and sediments, neglecting deep research on Hg pollution and resources. The findings of this study indicate that artisanal and small-scale gold mining activities, located in the upstream areas of the tributaries that act as point sources, are the primary source of mercury in the sediment of the Ciujung watershed. The isotopes δ13C and δ15N successfully trace the Hg-contaminated sediment in the Ciujung watershed derived from the Cisimeut and Ciberang Rivers based on soil organic matter. The biological effect showed the Hg concentration in most of the sampling sites exceeded the effects-range medium and probable effect limit values. The risk quotient values of Hg indicated the Hg pollution had a possibility effect on the benthic organism. Several limitations have also been added in this study and needs for further investigation. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Artisanal Small-scale Gold Mining; Ciujung; Mercury; Sediment

Title: Correlation between Pore Characteristics and High-Performance Carbon Dioxide Capture of Sustainable Porous Carbon Derived from Kraft Lignin and Potassium Carbonate
Affiliations: Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan; University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam

Abstract: The development of cost-effective and efficient adsorbents for CO<inf>2</inf> capture has gained significant interest, with biomass-derived porous carbon materials emerging as promising candidates due to their outstanding textural properties, tunable porosity, and low production cost. This study introduces for the first time a sustainable fabrication of porous carbon from Kraft lignin using K<inf>2</inf>CO<inf>3</inf> as an environment-friendly activator via a spray drying approach and carbonization process. K<inf>2</inf>CO<inf>3</inf> offers a low-toxic, low-corrosive, and eco-friendly alternative to KOH, making it safer for long-term equipment use and more suitable for large-scale applications. Furthermore, K<inf>2</inf>CO<inf>3</inf> effectively creates a microporous structure for CO<inf>2</inf> adsorption while simplifying waste management due to its benign and recyclable carbonate residues. Unlike conventional two-step activation, our approach integrates carbonization and activation into a single step, reducing production time and enhancing efficiency, making it suitable for practical applications. Porous carbon materials obtained through this novel process exhibited a CO<inf>2</inf> adsorption capacity of 4.54 mmol/g at 298 K, comparable to those activated with KOH and outperforming many previously reported adsorbents. Additionally, the effects of K<inf>2</inf>CO<inf>3</inf> concentration and carbonization temperature were systematically studied to optimize CO<inf>2</inf> adsorption performance. A linear correlation analysis between pore structure parameters and CO<inf>2</inf> captures highlighted ultramicropores as key contributors to adsorption efficiency. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H., Xuan, Hungta; D.T., Nguyen, Duc Tuyen
Author full names: Xuan, Hungta (59563393400); Nguyen, Duc Tuyen (58279068400)
Title: Unit Commitment in Microgrid Considering Customer Satisfaction in Incentives-Based Demand Response Program: A Fuzzy Logic Model
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Xuan, Hungta, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Duc Tuyen, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Department of Electrical Engineering, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: The increasing integration of Renewable Energy Sources (RES) poses significant challenges for power system operators due to their inherent variability and intermittency. This paper presents a Mixed-Integer Quadratic Programming (MIQP) approach to solve the Unit Commitment (UC) problem in microgrids, focusing on the combined use of RES, Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS), and Incentive-Based Demand Response (IBDR) programs. The proposed model optimizes power generation scheduling for both grid-connected and isolated microgrid modes. To assess customer satisfaction in IBDR programs, a Fuzzy Logic Model evaluates key factors like load demand, freedom of time, electricity prices, and incentives. This model aims to minimize operating costs when IBDR is not applied or maximize social welfare when IBDR is implemented. Results, obtained using Matlab/Simulink for customer satisfaction modeling and the CPLEX solver in Python for UC optimization, demonstrate that integrating BESS and IBDR enhances system flexibility and resilience to RES fluctuations. In optimal grid-connected operation, the model achieves a 22.27% reduction in operating costs and a 28.95% increase in social welfare compared to isolated operations. Although customer electricity bills rise by 15.35%, increased satisfaction, and system stability underscore the overall benefits of integrating BESS and IBDR for both operators and consumers. These findings demonstrate the potential of this approach to significantly enhance microgrid performance and ensure greater reliability in practical implementations. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Biochar-phytolith composite from rice straw: A dual-function material for hydrogen sulfide removal and slow-release nutrient delivery
Affiliations: Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnam National University of Forestry, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kyushu Institute of Technology, Kitakyushu, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Dinh, Van Mai, SoilTECH laboratory, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Faculty of Environmental Sciences, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Hue Thi T., SoilTECH laboratory, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Institute of Geography, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Anh Minh Hoang, SoilTECH laboratory, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tran, Hang Thi Minh, Faculty of Forestry, Vietnam National University of Forestry, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Duc Thang, SoilTECH laboratory, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Department of Engineering, Kyushu Institute of Technology, Kitakyushu, Japan; Duong, Linh H., SoilTECH laboratory, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Phuongthao, Faculty of Environmental Sciences, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tran, Son Van, Faculty of Environmental Sciences, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Le, Giang H., Faculty of Environmental Sciences, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Huan Xuan, Faculty of Environmental Sciences, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: Rice straw, a natural composite of lignocellulose and phytolith, holds great potential for the facile fabrication of biochar associated with phytolith. This study demonstrates a cascading use of biochar associated with phytolith, first for H<inf>2</inf>S removal from biogas and subsequently as a slow-release source of Si, S and P. Biochar associated with phytolith, referred to as ‘CharPhyt’, was prepared through anaerobic pyrolysis of rice straw and subsequently tested for its capacity to remove H<inf>2</inf>S from farm biogas. The resulting S-sorbed charPhyt, referred to as charPhytS, was then used to track the release of Si, S, P and other nutrient elements. CharPhyt demonstrated effective performance in H<inf>2</inf>S removal by converting H<inf>2</inf>S gas into a solid form. This solid S layer likely acted to reduce the release rates of Si and P. After a 7-day batch experiment, the release rates of Si and P from charPhytS were 9.65 and 0.04 mg/L, respectively. These release rates were ca. 4 and 10 times (respectively) lower than those from charPhyt, which were 39.6 and 0.4 mg/L. The enrichment of S on the surface of charPhyt is proposed as an underlying mechanism through which S likely inhibits the releases of Si and P. In contrast, S maintains an acidic environment, promoting protonation and cation exchange processes, which in turn enhance the release of K, Ca, Mg and Mn. Our findings demonstrate the versatile and practical use of charPhyt for gas purification while creating a slow-release platform for Si, S, P and other nutrients. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Enhanced Thermoelectric Performance of Electrochemically Deposited Cellulose Nanofiber-Bismuth Telluride Nanocomposite
Affiliations: Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Industrial University of Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan; Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Universiti Teknikal Malaysia Melaka, Malacca, Malaysia; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Jianghan, Tian, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Toan, Nguyen Van, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan, Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Industrial University of Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Keita, Sakakibara, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan; Kim Tuoi, Truong Thi, Advanced Institute for Materials Research, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Samat, Khairul Fadzli, Faculty of Industrial and Manufacturing Technology and Engineering, Universiti Teknikal Malaysia Melaka, Malacca, Malaysia; Tran, Ngoc Dang Khoa, Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Industrial University of Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; van Hieu, Nguyenvan, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Ono, Takahito O., Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan
Abstract: Thermoelectric generators (TEGs) provide an innovative approach to converting waste heat into electricity. However, practical application of TEGs is constrained by the limited thermoelectric performance of traditional materials like bismuth telluride (Bi<inf>2</inf>Te<inf>3</inf>)-based thermoelectric materials. Thick thermoelectric films frequently suffer from cracking, leading to reduced reliability and efficiency. To overcome these limitations, this study investigates the incorporation of cellulose nanofibers (CNF) into Bi<inf>2</inf>Te<inf>3</inf>-based thermoelectric films. CNF, a sustainable and biodegradable material, was hypothesized to improve thermoelectric performance by reducing thermal conductivity through enhanced phonon scattering while maintaining favorable electrical conductivity and Seebeck coefficient. Crack-free CNF-Bi<inf>2</inf>Te<inf>3</inf> composite films (400 μm thick) were synthesized using a pulsed electrodeposition method. Structural analysis confirmed that CNF introduced significant microstructural improvements, including grain refinement, enhanced grain boundary scattering, and optimized carrier transport pathways. At an optimal CNF concentration of 0.06 wt%, the ZT value of the composite films reached 0.76, representing a 625% improvement over the pure Bi<inf>2</inf>Te<inf>3</inf> film. This remarkable enhancement was achieved through a significant reduction in thermal conductivity and balanced improvements in electrical conductivity and the Seebeck coefficient. These results highlight the potential of CNF as an effective additive for improving both the thermoelectric efficiency and structural integrity of Bi<inf>2</inf>Te<inf>3</inf>-based materials. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Universal buried interface modification with lead iodide for efficient and stable perovskite solar cells
Affiliations: The Australian National University, Canberra, Australia; The Australian National University, Canberra, Australia; Faculty of Engineering, Sydney, Australia; Institute for Chemical Research, Uji, Japan; Institute for Nanoscale Science & Technology, Adelaide, Australia; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Dang Thuan, School of Engineering, The Australian National University, Canberra, Australia; Bui, Anh Dinh, School of Engineering, The Australian National University, Canberra, Australia; Walter, Daniel, School of Engineering, The Australian National University, Canberra, Australia; Nguyen, Khoa Dang, School of Engineering, The Australian National University, Canberra, Australia; Zhan, Hualin, School of Engineering, The Australian National University, Canberra, Australia; Ta, Xuan Minh Chau, The Australian National University, Canberra, Australia, Faculty of Engineering, Sydney, Australia; Tabi, Grace Dansoa, School of Engineering, The Australian National University, Canberra, Australia; Trần-Phú, Thành, The Australian National University, Canberra, Australia, Chemistry and Nanoscience Center, National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, United States; Chang, Lichun, School of Engineering, The Australian National University, Canberra, Australia; Huang, Keqing, School of Engineering, The Australian National University, Canberra, Australia
Abstract: A controlled amount of excess lead iodide (PbI<inf>2</inf>) in the perovskite precursor has been widely used in perovskite solar cells (PSCs) to enhance the device's performance by passivating defects. However, an excessive amount of PbI<inf>2</inf> can lead to significant hysteresis and reduced stability. Managing the excess PbI<inf>2</inf> in the perovskite bulk and on the top (exposed) surface is achievable, but the bottom surface presents a challenge. This study offers a method for adjusting the amount of excess PbI<inf>2</inf> in perovskite solar cells at both the bottom surface and the bulk of the perovskite layer. This treatment, known as buried interface modification, is effective for both negative-intrinsic-positive (n-i-p) and positive-intrinsic-negative (p-i-n) structures, achieving efficiencies of 25.9% and 24.6%, respectively, with negligible hysteresis and excellent stability of over 1000 hours under light at the maximum power point. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Optimization bio-organic fertilizer production from watermelon rind with Trichoderma spp. for improved Brassica juncea growth
Source title: CTU Journal of Innovation and Sustainable Development
Affiliations: Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Okayama University, Okayama, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Thanh, Bui Hoai, Department of Chemical Engineering, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Long, Tran Vu Bao, Department of Chemical Engineering, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Nghia, Le Van, Department of Chemical Engineering, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Tan, Nguyen Tan, Department of Chemical Engineering, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Tho, Diep Anh, Department of Chemical Engineering, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Van-Pham, Dan Thuy, Department of Chemical Engineering, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Hoa, Nguyen Viet Nhan, Department of Chemical Engineering, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Murata, Yoshiyuki, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; Quyen, Tran Thi Bich, Department of Chemical Engineering, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Thien, Doan Van Hong, Department of Chemical Engineering, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam
Abstract: This study evaluates the effectiveness of Trichoderma spp. in decomposing watermelon rind to produce bio-organic fertilizer. Response Surface Methodology (RSM) with Central Composite Design (CCD) was employed to optimize the cultivation conditions for Brassica juncea using the composted fertilizer. Results demonstrated that Trichoderma spp. significantly accelerated decomposition and improved fertilizer quality. Among the tested parameters, composting duration and fertilization rate significantly influenced plant growth, particularly leaf length and width, while microbial inoculant concentration had no notable effect. Microbial analysis confirmed that Coliform, E. coli, and Salmonella levels were below regulatory limits (ND 108/2017/ND-CP), with none detected in fertilizers produced with Trichoderma spp.. RSM optimization identified the optimal composting conditions as 18 days, 4 wt.% Trichoderma spp., and 50 v/v% fertilizer volume fraction. A high-accuracy mathematical model was developed to predict plant growth responses, effectively forecasting the impact of composting parameters on crop development. These findings highlight the potential of Trichoderma-based bio-organic fertilizers in sustainable agriculture. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Na3.5(MnVFeTi)0.5(PO4)3: A Multi-Transition-Metal-Ion-Engineered NASICON-Type Cathodes for Sodium Ion Batteries
Affiliations: Chungnam National University, Daejeon, South Korea; Chonnam National University, Gwangju, South Korea; University of Münster, Munster, Germany; Shizuoka University, Shizuoka, Japan; City University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong, Hong Kong; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Chonnam National University, Gwangju, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Soundharrajan, Vaiyapuri, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Chungnam National University, Daejeon, South Korea; Alfaza, Ghalib, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Chonnam National University, Gwangju, South Korea; Arifiadi, Anindityo Nugra, University of Münster, Munster, Germany; Feleke, Demelash, University of Münster, Munster, Germany; Nithiananth, Subramanian, Shizuoka University, Shizuoka, Japan; Piao, Junji, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Chonnam National University, Gwangju, South Korea; Zeng, Zhiyuan, City University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong, Hong Kong; Pham, Duong Tung, School of Engineering Physics, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kim, Chunjoong, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Chungnam National University, Daejeon, South Korea; Kim, Jaekook, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Chonnam National University, Gwangju, South Korea, Research Center for Artificial Intelligence Assisted Ionics Based Materials Development Platform, Chonnam National University, Gwangju, South Korea
Abstract: Electrochemically active Na-superionic conductor (NASICON)-type cathodes have the structural flexibility to include various transition elements, thus enabling high power outputs benefited by multi-electron redox reactions. This study amalgamated multiple transition metal ions to construct a new NASICON-type cathode i. e., carbon coated Na<inf>3.5</inf>(MnVFeTi)<inf>0.5</inf>(PO<inf>4</inf>)<inf>3</inf> (NMVFTP/C) for Na-ion batteries (NIBs). The NMVFTP/C cathode engineered in this study demonstrated stable Na+-storage capacity, including long-term cycling stability up to 4000 cycles at 3000 mA g−1 with 96 % capacity retention and a high-rate output capacity of 85.16 mAh g−1 at 2500 mA g−1. To elucidate the ion transport process within the cathode, density functional theory modeling was employed. The low energy barrier for the diffusion of Na+ in the NMVFTP/C materials was proved to be a key factor supporting our material's superior electrochemical performances. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Oxidative fractionation of palm kernel shell waste biomass over bimetallic Co-Cu/Zeolite HY catalyst
Affiliations: Thammasat University, Pathum Thani, Thailand; Thammasat University, Pathum Thani, Thailand; Center of Excellence on Petrochemical and Materials Technology, Bangkok, Thailand; Hirosaki University, Hirosaki, Japan; Synchrotron Light Research Institute (SLRI), Nakhon Ratchasima, Thailand; Industrial University of Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam

Abstract: This study focused on utilizing palm kernel shell waste biomass for liquid-phase oxidation using hydrogen peroxide as the oxidizing agent. Bimetallic Co–Cu catalysts were loaded onto HY Zeolite supports at varying molar ratios of the metals and used for catalytic cracking. The effects of varying parameters, such as reaction temperatures from 140 to 200 °C and reaction times between 1 and 4 h, on the catalytic activity were investigated. The synergistic interactions between Co and Cu regulate the catalytic reactions by balancing the oxidative and hydrolytic pathways for cleaving the intermolecular bonds of lignin. At 180 °C temperature and 2 h of reaction time, the total yield of the compounds obtained from lignin derivatives (phenolics, aldehydes, and carboxylic acids) increased to approximately 34.25 % for the Co:Cu molar ratio of 4:1. Further, the phenol yield remarkably increased from 0.45 to 2.86 % by changing the Co:Cu molar ratio from 1:1 to 4:1, respectively. This synergistic effect enhanced product yields and improved metal dispersion and catalytic stability, contributing to a more efficient biomass conversion process. The reusability studies revealed that the yield of lignin-derived compounds was approximately 90 % of the initial run, even after four consecutive cycles, confirming the long-term applicability of the catalyst. Hence, this catalyst system can be a promising alternative for biomass conversion for synthesizing phenolic compounds owing to its several advantages, including the high yield of lignin derivatives and remarkable catalytic stability. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: J., Ratthiwal, Janejira; L.B., Chul, Lee Byung; L., Gyu, Limmin; Y., Kim, Young-min; S., Karthikeyan, Sathrugnan; A., Watanabe, Atsuichi; S., Kongparakul, Suwadee; T.T.V., Tran, Thi Tuong Vi; C., Samart, Chanatip
Author full names: Ratthiwal, Janejira (57190793395); Chul, Lee Byung (59350849800); Gyu, Limmin (59350901500); Kim, Young-min (57148866400); Karthikeyan, Sathrugnan (59350999700); Watanabe, Atsuichi (56381897000); Kongparakul, Suwadee (24074703800); Tran, Thi Tuong Vi (59269885600); Samart, Chanatip (26436343700)
Title: Catalytic co-pyrolysis of yellow poplar and HDPE using MOF-incorporated HY zeolite catalysts
Affiliations: Thammasat University, Pathum Thani, Thailand; Daegu University, Gyeongsan, South Korea; Frontier Laboratories Ltd., Koriyama, Japan; Center of Excellence on Petrochemical and Materials Technology, Bangkok, Thailand; Dại học Nguyen Tat Thanh, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Ratthiwal, Janejira, Department of Chemistry, Thammasat University, Pathum Thani, Thailand; Chul, Lee Byung, Department of Environmental Engineering, Daegu University, Gyeongsan, South Korea; Gyu, Limmin, Department of Environmental Engineering, Daegu University, Gyeongsan, South Korea; Kim, Young-min, Department of Environmental Engineering, Daegu University, Gyeongsan, South Korea; Karthikeyan, Sathrugnan, Frontier Laboratories Ltd., Koriyama, Japan; Watanabe, Atsuichi, Frontier Laboratories Ltd., Koriyama, Japan; Kongparakul, Suwadee, Department of Chemistry, Thammasat University, Pathum Thani, Thailand, Center of Excellence on Petrochemical and Materials Technology, Bangkok, Thailand; Tran, Thi Tuong Vi, Institute of Applied Technology and Sustainable Development, Dại học Nguyen Tat Thanh, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Samart, Chanatip, Department of Chemistry, Thammasat University, Pathum Thani, Thailand, Center of Excellence on Petrochemical and Materials Technology, Bangkok, Thailand
Abstract: Catalytic co-pyrolysis of yellow poplar and high-density polypropylene (HDPE) was conducted using metal oxide on hydrogen y-type (HY) zeolite to selectively produce monoaromatic hydrocarbons. The reaction was investigated using a tandem micro-reactor connected to a gas chromatography–mass spectrometry (GC–MS) system, encompassing both in-situ and ex-situ studies. Fe oxide/HY and Cu oxide/HY catalysts, prepared via a metal–organic framework (MOF)-incorporated technique, demonstrated excellent metal dispersion and enhanced electron density. The Cu oxide/HY catalyst showed significant production of benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene, and xylene, reaching up to 28% in in-situ studies. Owing to its strong acid sites, this catalyst facilitated the formation of aromatic compounds. In ex-situ studies, furan and acetaldehyde were consumed through the Diels–Alder reaction. The increase in aromatic compounds was highlighted by a synergistic effect percentage as high as 175%. The mechanism of aromatic formation was elucidated through dealkylation, Diels–Alder, and aromatization reactions. The Cu oxide/HY catalyst, combined with the MOF-incorporated preparation technique presents a promising system for catalytic co-pyrolysis of biomass and HDPE. This approach will facilitate efficient and sustainable aromatic hydrocarbon production from renewable and plastic waste sources. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
