Authors: L., Le Thi Minh, Lien; A., Vu Quoc, Anh; D.T., Nguyen, Duc Tuyen; G., Fujita, Goro
Author full names: Le Thi Minh, Lien (58883920100); Vu Quoc, Anh (58883751400); Nguyen, Duc Tuyen (58279068400); Fujita, Goro (36186886000)
Title: Forecasting State-of-Health of Battery Based on Combined EMD-CNN-BiLSTM-SM Method
Affiliations: School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Le Thi Minh, Lien, Department of Electrical Engineering, School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vu Quoc, Anh, Department of Electrical Engineering, School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Duc Tuyen, Department of Electrical Engineering, School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Fujita, Goro, Department of Electrical Engineering, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Battery energy storage systems (BESSs), especially Lithium-ion batteries, are widely applied in power systems due to their numerous advantages. However, the battery will be unstable, leading to failure in the system operation or causing safety accidents when the battery reaches its end-of-life (EOL). Therefore, to accurately predict the State of health (SOH) and the remaining useful life (RUL), a novel prediction method is proposed in this paper based on long short-term memory (LSTM), convolutional neural network (CNN), and self-attention mechanism (SM). The degradation data of the batteries are first processed by the Empirical Mode Decomposition (EMD), then the data is put into the proposed model, and the obtained prediction results are compared with other models for validation. Different batteries from two datasets are utilized in this work to determine the robustness of the method. The errors, including Root Mean Square Error (RMSE), and Mean Absolute Error (MAE) are also calculated to verify the accuracy, and the RMSE and MAE of the proposed method are about 32.6% and 22.7% compared to other methods in all cases, respectively. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: D.B., Nguyen, Duy Bao; T., Fujiwara, Takeshi; C., Le, Cuongcuong; S.T.P., Phu, Song Toan Pham
Author full names: Nguyen, Duy Bao (57406388400); Fujiwara, Takeshi (55502389900); Le, Cuongcuong (59455466400); Phu, Song Toan Pham (57406473300)
Title: A Short Review on the Situation of Municipal Biodegradable Solid Waste Treatment
Affiliations: Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Duy Bao, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; Fujiwara, Takeshi, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; Le, Cuongcuong, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; Phu, Song Toan Pham, University of Science and Technology, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam
Abstract: Biodegradable solid waste (BSW) is the main component of municipal solid waste (MSW), accounting for a significant proportion of 44%. Handling BSW varies depending on the situation of the waste management system and socioeconomic conditions of each country. This study aims at giving a short review of the current situation of BSW treatment methods in the World. With the high amount of BSW, landfilling and incineration are the most reliable methods for low-and middle-income countries. While in developed nations, BSW accounted for 20-40% of the total waste, making Waste-To-Energy the second-best option besides recycling. With a low efficiency of waste segregation at source, BSW in Vietnam accounted for 55-75% of the total MSW. Landfilling was the main method of handling BSW in Vietnam, with 76%, followed by composting with 16%, and the remaining 13% was sent to incineration plants. Since 2022, the Vietnamese Government has promulgated the Environmental Protection Strategies, with the main target being to increase waste recycling and reduce the waste to landfill to 30% by 2025. To achieve these goals, further study to enhance the application of sustainable methods for BSW treatment must be focused. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.P., Dang, Tan Phat; T.K., Tran, Tuan Kiet; T.T., Hoang, Trong Thuc; C.K., Pham, Cong Kha; H.T., Huynh, Huu Thuan
Author full names: Dang, Tan Phat (57219503026); Tran, Tuan Kiet (57215727984); Hoang, Trong Thuc (56024762000); Pham, Cong Kha (56186480400); Huynh, Huu Thuan (55948143700)
Title: The Efficiency of High-performance SHA-3 Accelerator on the System Level
Affiliations: University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; The University of Electro-Communications, Chofu, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Dang, Tan Phat, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tran, Tuan Kiet, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Hoang, Trong Thuc, The University of Electro-Communications, Chofu, Japan; Pham, Cong Kha, The University of Electro-Communications, Chofu, Japan; Huynh, Huu Thuan, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Abstract: The Secure Hash Algorithm-3 (SHA-3) has become increasingly vital in numerous security applications within the Internet of Things (IoT) field. Given the diverse purposes, SHA-3 serves in the IoT landscape, the need for versatility is essential. Additionally, recent studies have primarily focused on achieving high performance and optimizing resource utilization for SHA-3. However, these studies have overlooked the crucial aspect of data transfer between the external memory and the hash function block, as transfer time plays a significant role. This paper proposes an efficient SHA-3 architecture designed for System-on-Chip (SoC) based on a Field Programmable Gate Array (FPGA) called system-level SHA-3 accelerator (SSA) to address the aforementioned challenges and be suitable for real edge computing. The SSA contains three key proposals. Firstly, the proposed padding architecture is designed from a combination of Serial Input to Parallel Output (SIPO) and a barrel shifter, which is well-suitable for managing the data transfer process on the system. Secondly, implementing a two-stage pipelining within the Round Function (RF) to reduce critical path delays and make a high occupancy. Finally, designing four modes (SHA3-224, SHA3-256, SHA3-384, and SHA3-512) enables the SSA to compute various SHA-3 to support a wide range of applications. Our architecture is implemented on the DE10-Standard Development Kit (Cyclone V SX SoC-5CSXFC6D6F31C6N), which is integrated into the FPGA and is controlled by a Dual-Core ARM Cortex-A9 processor. The result is up to 38.34 Gbps in throughput and 5.61 Mbps/ALM in efficiency for the RF computation, 28.02 Gbps in throughput, and 3.63 Mbps/ALM for the full proposed architecture. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: High Performance Computing; Padding; Round Function; Sha-3 Accelerator; Soc Fpga; Efficiency; Field Programmable Gate Arrays (fpga); Hash Functions; Internet Of Things; Programmable Logic Controllers; System-on-chip; Algorithm-3; Field Programmables; High Performance Computing; Padding; Performance Computing; Programmable Gate Array; Round Functions; Secure Hash Algorithm (); Secure Hash Algorithm-3 Accelerator; System-on-chip Field Programmable Gate Array; Systems-on-chip; Data Transfer
Index Keywords: Efficiency; Field programmable gate arrays (FPGA); Hash functions; Internet of things; Programmable logic controllers; System-on-chip; Algorithm-3; Field programmables; High performance computing; Padding; Performance computing; Programmable gate array; Round functions; Secure Hash Algorithm (); Secure hash algorithm-3 accelerator; System-on-chip field programmable gate array; Systems-on-Chip; Data transfer
Funding Texts: Furthermore, this research has introduced a SoC-based SHA-3 accelerator, resulting in substantial enhancements in data transfer efficiency within the system and the processing rate of SHA-3. Nevertheless, a notable challenge within our architecture lies in the large resource utilization, leading to a low Efficiency Index. As a result, we recognize the signif- icance of devising a novel architecture that addresses these resource constraints while maintaining high performance and flexibility. This endeavor is poised to emerge as a crucial research direction in the near future within this field. Title: Optimization of EV Scheduling in a Microgrid Integrated with a Rooftop Solar System Using Forward Dynamic Programming
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Gifu University, Gifu, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Le-The, Cuong, School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nhat, Hoang, School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Duc Tuyen, School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Takano, Hirotaka, Department of Electrical, Electronic and Computer Engineering, Gifu University, Gifu, Japan
Abstract: Electric vehicles (EVs) have been a trend in terms of transportation for a decade because of the energy transition. However, as the number of EVs increases, various problems related to the power quality, such as voltage and load profile, arise. To reduce the negative impact of EV charging, several solutions are suggested, with the integration of renewable energy sources into the charging station combined with Vehicle-to-Grid technology. This paper presents an algorithm to minimize the charging cost of all EVs and flatten the load curve, considering the travel schedule of EV owners and voltage constraints in the power grid. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: D., Nguyen-Dang, Duong; N., Cong Hieu, Nguyen; D.T., Nguyen, Duc Tuyen; G., Fujita, Goro
Author full names: Nguyen-Dang, Duong (57885564700); Cong Hieu, Nguyen (58743607600); Nguyen, Duc Tuyen (58279068400); Fujita, Goro (36186886000)
Title: Photovoltaic Hosting Capacity for Distribution Network Using Statistical Approach
Affiliations: School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen-Dang, Duong, Department of Electrical Engineering, School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Cong Hieu, Nguyen, Department of Electrical Engineering, School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Duc Tuyen, Department of Electrical Engineering, School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Fujita, Goro, Department of Electrical Engineering, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Photovoltaic (PV) hosting capacity, which refers to the maximum amount of PV that can be stably integrated into the grid, is important to consider when integrating PV systems into the grid due to the ability of violations to the network such as overloading and voltage fluctuations. In the literature, various analysis methods were proposed to estimate the penetration of PV, which is proper to install into the distribution networks without negative impacts. This paper presents a statistical approach to calculate the hosting capacity of solar power plants in a practical 35kV distribution network in Vietnam. The uncertainties of PV production and power consumption are also considered to determine the probability of risks to the grid. The results of this study show the maximum PV hosting capacity for the distribution network under consideration and the impact of its integration on the voltage profile in the distribution network. This study highlights the difference between summer and winter scenarios in estimating the PV hosting capacity. The paper also considers the geographical conditions to determine which locations are suitable for future PV installations. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T., Yamazaki, Tamaki; H., Takano, Hirotaka; H., Asano, Hiroshi; D.T., Nguyen, Duc Tuyen
Author full names: Yamazaki, Tamaki (58743608400); Takano, Hirotaka (54394480500); Asano, Hiroshi (55662621100); Nguyen, Duc Tuyen (58279068400)
Title: Calculation Framework of Parameters in Management of Distributed Energy Resources Considering Balance of Power Supply and Demand
Affiliations: Gifu University, Gifu, Japan; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Yamazaki, Tamaki, Department of Electrical, Electronic and Computer Engineering, Gifu University, Gifu, Japan; Takano, Hirotaka, Department of Electrical, Electronic and Computer Engineering, Gifu University, Gifu, Japan; Asano, Hiroshi, Department of Electrical, Electronic and Computer Engineering, Gifu University, Gifu, Japan; Nguyen, Duc Tuyen, School of Electrical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: This paper presents a framework calculating parameters in distributed energy resource (DER) management. It is designed for retail power suppliers holding energy resource aggregator's functions. The calculation framework includes two models of demand response (DR) programs: one is price-based DR, and the other is incentive-based one. For each DR program, the parameters are electricity prices or rebate levels. The authors formulate a power trade between the retail power suppliers and their consumers as a social welfare maximization (SWM) problem. From the viewpoint of SWM, the authors theoretically design the way to set the parameters of the DER management with maximizing the social welfare, while reducing imbalance between power supply and demand. The social welfare is defined as the sum of the retail power suppliers' surplus and the consumers' one in this paper. Through numerical simulations, the authors validate that the calculation framework induces the amount of power consumption to the target value of the DER management and increases the social welfare with reducing the power imbalance. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: F., Zhang, Fangcheng; K., Do-Chi, Kien; H., Takami, Hiroshi
Author full names: Zhang, Fangcheng (58679706800); Do-Chi, Kien (57953324600); Takami, Hiroshi (7202531228)
Title: DC-Link Voltage Control Based on Adaptive IRM-ILQ for Stirling Engine Power Supply Vehicle
Affiliations: Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, Fangcheng, Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan; Do-Chi, Kien, School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Takami, Hiroshi, Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: The growing concern over the increasing scale and frequency of natural disasters has increased the demand for a power supply vehicle that supplies electricity from renewable energy. These vehicles offer versatile and flexible deployment capabilities, while also addressing environmental issues by reducing carbon emissions and minimizing their overall impact. This paper introduces a new approach to obtain optimal voltage control in the power supply vehicle equipped with a Free Piston Stirling Engine Generator (FPSEG) fueled by wood biomass and solar power, along with a battery. The proposed method employs an Inverse Reference Model-Inverse Linear Quadratic (IRM-ILQ) control technique to ensure stable operation and enhance performance. By utilizing an error model based on the inverse reference model derived from voltage equations, the DC link voltage of the FPSEG is effectively regulated through the inverse reference technique. Additionally, the ILQ design method determines the optimal feedback gain. Optimal control of the DC link voltage minimizes FPSEG losses and achieves maximum efficiency and maximum output operation. The effectiveness of this control method is confirmed through simulation. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: S.A., Shirazi, Siamack A.; F., Darihaki, Farzin; Y., Yamazaki, Y.; Y., Nakano, Y.; K., Ushiguchi, K.; V.L., Quang, V. Lam; L., Le Ngoc, L.
Title: Integrity Management of Offshore Process Piping and Equipment with Sand Production – Part II: Remediations
Affiliations: The University of Tulsa, Tulsa, United States; JX Nippon Oil & Gas Exploration Corporation, Tokyo, Japan; Japan Vietnam Petroleum Co. Ltd., Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Shirazi, Siamack A., The University of Tulsa, Tulsa, United States; Darihaki, Farzin, The University of Tulsa, Tulsa, United States; Yamazaki, Y., JX Nippon Oil & Gas Exploration Corporation, Tokyo, Japan; Nakano, Y., JX Nippon Oil & Gas Exploration Corporation, Tokyo, Japan; Ushiguchi, K., JX Nippon Oil & Gas Exploration Corporation, Tokyo, Japan; Quang, V. Lam, Japan Vietnam Petroleum Co. Ltd., Viet Nam; Le Ngoc, L., Japan Vietnam Petroleum Co. Ltd., Viet Nam
Abstract: Sand production is challenging integrity issue that should be monitored to prevent interruption in the oil and gas production facilities. On the other hand, the limitations in the offshore platforms can contribute to the failure in the production system due to sand erosion. The objective of this study is to establish a practical framework of monitoring and a tool for generating Integrity Operating Window (IOW) thresholds, which are used for handling sand production in most safe and effective manner. The ultimate goal is to obtain the highest possible production output from producing wells while minimizing sand erosion related risks to as low as a reasonably practical level. The recommended monitoring measures of sand production, production rate and wall thickness are discussed as a part of sand management system. CFD-based models and mechanistic models are additional tools that can enhance this procedure. Erosion simulations of pipe walls indicated that the cushion tees that have replaced the piping with bends to prevent/reduce erosion rates are also susceptible to significant erosion. Therefore, wall thickness measurements are being conducted at critical locations. A simplified mechanistic model was employed to support developing sand erosion IOW prediction tool and determining monitoring locations, provided that a process for wall thickness measurements at critical locations is in place for verifying and fine tuning the models on regular basis. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: S.A., Shirazi, Siamack A.; F., Darihaki, Farzin; Y., Yamazaki, Y.; Y., Nakano, Y.; K., Ushiguchi, K.; V., Lam Quang, V.; L., Le Ngoc, L.
Title: Integrity Management of Offshore Process Piping and Equipment with Sand Production - Part I: The Pinhole Incident
Affiliations: The University of Tulsa, Tulsa, United States; JX Nippon Oil & Gas Exploration Corporation, Tokyo, Japan; Japan Vietnam Petroleum Co. Ltd., Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Shirazi, Siamack A., The University of Tulsa, Tulsa, United States; Darihaki, Farzin, The University of Tulsa, Tulsa, United States; Yamazaki, Y., JX Nippon Oil & Gas Exploration Corporation, Tokyo, Japan; Nakano, Y., JX Nippon Oil & Gas Exploration Corporation, Tokyo, Japan; Ushiguchi, K., JX Nippon Oil & Gas Exploration Corporation, Tokyo, Japan; Lam Quang, V., Japan Vietnam Petroleum Co. Ltd., Viet Nam; Le Ngoc, L., Japan Vietnam Petroleum Co. Ltd., Viet Nam
Abstract: Sand production is becoming a growing issue for oil and gas operators around the globe. Operators are faced to increase production of oil and gas, which may cause or worthen sand production, while insuring integrity management of process piping and equipment. As a result of higher than expected sand production in a specific field, a pinhole failure was observed on a 12″ Schedule 160 elbow downstream of a Multiphase flow meter (MPFM) that contained a venturi section that caused a localized increase in flow velocities. State-of-the-art Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) based erosion prediction procedure was utilized to determine the root cause of failure and help operators with integrity management of the associated piping systems and equipment. Data used for verification of erosion model included wall thickness losses and sand production data in a separator downstream. Additionally, CFD simulations of erosion rates in 12″ elbows were used for evaluating simplified erosion models that are being used to determine Integrity Operating Window (IOW) of piping that are currently installed downstream of the MPFM. The results in the paper include a comparison of wall thickness measurements and erosion rates of the piping downstream of the MPFM with predicted erosion rates. The CFD predicted erosion pattern and wall thickness losses downstream of the MPFM were comparable with the observed erosion rates. The geometry of MPFM and downstream section was too complicated to model with simplified mechanistic models, but the results of CFD and the mechanistic models were more conservative for isolated elbows downstream where wall thickness data were available with ultrasonic thickness (UT) measurements. The results indicate that simplified mechanistic model of Shirazi, et al. (1995, 2016) was sufficient to support developing sand erosion IOW prediction tool and determining condition monitoring locations, provided that a practical process for wall thickness measurements at critical locations is in place for verifying the outcomes and fine tuning the models on regular and as needed basis. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: S., Neupane, Sanjiv; U., Ghimire, Uttam; S.L., Shrestha, Sangam L.; S.M., Sundaram, S. Mohana; B.R., Shivakoti, Binaya Raj; O., Lorphensri, Oranuj; B., Vuong, Buitran; M., Basharat, Muhammad; R., Malla, Rabin
Author full names: Neupane, Sanjiv (57214132189); Ghimire, Uttam (57205189733); Shrestha, Sangam L. (13407729100); Sundaram, S. Mohana (57370919500); Shivakoti, Binaya Raj (14030317900); Lorphensri, Oranuj (12788970100); Vuong, Buitran (57203835482); Basharat, Muhammad (56398304200); Malla, Rabin (56227408700)
Title: Mapping groundwater resilience to climate change and human development in Asian cities
Affiliations: Asian Institute of Technology Thailand, Khlong Luang, Thailand; Institute for Global Environmental Strategies, Hayama, Japan; Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment, Chonburi, Thailand; Division of Water Resources Planning and Investigation for South of Vietnam, Viet Nam; International Waterlogging and Salinity Research Institute, Lahore, Pakistan; Centre of Research for Environment Energy and Water, Nepal
Authors with affiliations: Neupane, Sanjiv, Asian Institute of Technology Thailand, Khlong Luang, Thailand; Ghimire, Uttam, Asian Institute of Technology Thailand, Khlong Luang, Thailand; Shrestha, Sangam L., Asian Institute of Technology Thailand, Khlong Luang, Thailand; Sundaram, S. Mohana, Asian Institute of Technology Thailand, Khlong Luang, Thailand; Shivakoti, Binaya Raj, Institute for Global Environmental Strategies, Hayama, Japan; Lorphensri, Oranuj, Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment, Chonburi, Thailand; Vuong, Buitran, Division of Water Resources Planning and Investigation for South of Vietnam, Viet Nam; Basharat, Muhammad, International Waterlogging and Salinity Research Institute, Lahore, Pakistan; Malla, Rabin, Centre of Research for Environment Energy and Water, Nepal
Abstract: Groundwater resources in major Asian cities, including Bangkok and its vicinity, Ho Chi Minh City, Kathmandu Valley, and Lahore, confront escalating challenges due to climate change and human development. Over-extraction has led to groundwater depletion, causing socio-environmental and economic issues. This study investigates the combined impacts of climate change and urban development on groundwater resources and assesses the resilience of these cities’ groundwater systems that are essential for sustainable management strategies. Employing a model-based approach, the study analyses climate and land use changes, groundwater recharge, levels, and resilience. Three land-use and extraction scenarios—high, medium and low—are examined to evaluate their effects on groundwater. The results suggest that all four Asian cities are expected to be warmer in future. Results predict warmer condi-tions across all cities, with Ho Chi Minh City experiencing the most significant temperature increases. All cities anticipate increased rainfall under both Representative Concentration Pathway (RCP) scenarios, notably Bangkok. Groundwater recharge is projected to decrease in high urbanisation settings and both RCPs, contrasting with a rise in low to medium urbanisation contexts. Under a high urbanisation scenario, the outskirts of all four Asian cities are resilient to climate change and human development, whereas the centre or urban areas are not resilient. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Asian Cities; Climate Change; Groundwater Resiliency; Human Development

Authors: T.D., Nguyen, Tuyen Dinh; L.H.B., Nguyen, Long Hoang B.; D., Tran, Dong; R.N., Tripathi, Ravi Nath; H.N., Tran, Hai N.
Author full names: Nguyen, Tuyen Dinh (59454595000); Nguyen, Long Hoang B. (58523556400); Tran, Dong (58069207000); Tripathi, Ravi Nath (56111717200); Tran, Hai N. (57193230097)
Title: Ecap-less 800V On-board Battery Charger Based on Unbalanced Half-bridge Split Capacitors Power Decoupling Circuit
Affiliations: Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Kyoto University of Advanced Science, Kyoto, Japan; Ltd, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Tuyen Dinh, Faculty of Electrical and Electronics Engineering, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Long Hoang B., Faculty of Electrical and Electronics Engineering, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Ltd, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tran, Dong, Ltd, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tripathi, Ravi Nath, Kyoto University of Advanced Science, Kyoto, Japan; Tran, Hai N., Ltd, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Abstract: This paper proposed an Electrolytic Capacitor-less (Ecap-less) 800V onboard charger (OBC) based on a Half-bridge Split Capacitors Power Decoupling (HSC-PD) circuit. A new design and control method proposed for HSC-PD to minimize the capacitance needed for the dc-link of the OBC enables the deployment of Film capacitors (Fcap) only. Both dc component and capacitance values of the decoupling capacitors are designed unequally with the bottom-bias capacitor approach, reducing not only equivalent capacitance and ac voltage ripple but the current rating of the PD circuit. An effect of fourth-line frequency harmonics caused by the double-line frequency of voltage and current in the PD circuit is also analyzed. The feedback control developed for HSC-PD based OBC system considering the proposed unequal dc component and capacitance. The impact of the DC offset ratio discussed for the converter efficiency and experimental results demonstrate the superiority of the proposed method. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.D., Nguyen, Tuyen Dinh; T.T.K., Nguyen, Trinh T.K.; R.N., Tripathi, Ravi Nath; L.H.B., Nguyen, Long Hoang B.; M.V., Vo, Minh V.; H.N., Tran, Hai N.
Author full names: Nguyen, Tuyen Dinh (59454595000); Nguyen, Trinh T.K. (58263850500); Tripathi, Ravi Nath (56111717200); Nguyen, Long Hoang B. (58523556400); Vo, Minh V. (58572399500); Tran, Hai N. (57193230097)
Title: High Efficiency Dual-Bridge LLC Resonant Converter with Adaptive Frequency Control for On-Board Charger Applications
Affiliations: Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Kyoto University of Advanced Science, Kyoto, Japan; Ltd., Vung Tau, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Tuyen Dinh, Faculty of Electrical and Electronics Engineering, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Trinh T.K., Faculty of Electrical and Electronics Engineering, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tripathi, Ravi Nath, Nagamori Actuator Research Center, Kyoto University of Advanced Science, Kyoto, Japan; Nguyen, Long Hoang B., Ltd., Vung Tau, Viet Nam; Vo, Minh V., Ltd., Vung Tau, Viet Nam; Tran, Hai N., Ltd., Vung Tau, Viet Nam
Abstract: This paper proposes an adaptive frequency control strategy for the unidirectional DC/DC converter based on Dual-bridge LLC (DBLLC) resonant converter to eliminate the circulating interval (CI), which causes high conduction loss. The LLC resonant converters are the preferred choice to select of DC/DC converter topology for on-board charger (OBC) due to it provides many advantages such as high efficiency, high power density. The DBLLC resonant converter operating with variable frequency and the pulse width-modulated (PWM) control will be applied as an isolated stage (DC/DC converter) of 400V-7.4 kW to improve the power density and efficiency of the whole system. The advantage of operating at the adaptive frequency is that the conduction loss in all devices will be reduced, while the soft switching technique is still achieved over the full load range. Furthermore, the detailed CI characteristic along with losses analysis is presented. The topology is designed for 400 VDC input to 220-380VDC output conversion, in the power range from 3.3 kW to 7.4kW. All theoretical analysis and the experimental results on the proposed converter are provided to verify the system performance. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: D.T., Nguyen, Duc Tuyen; D., Nguyen-Dang, Duong; T.L., Viet, Thinh Le; H., Takano, Hirotaka
Author full names: Nguyen, Duc Tuyen (58279068400); Nguyen-Dang, Duong (57885564700); Viet, Thinh Le (57954752600); Takano, Hirotaka (54394480500)
Title: An Efficient Scalogram Generator for Partial Shading Analysis of Photovoltaic Array
Affiliations: School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Virginia Tech College of Engineering, Blacksburg, United States; Gifu University, Gifu, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Duc Tuyen, Department of Electrical Engineering, School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen-Dang, Duong, Department of Electrical Engineering, School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Viet, Thinh Le, Virginia Tech College of Engineering, Blacksburg, United States; Takano, Hirotaka, Department of Electrical, Electronic and Computer Engineering, Gifu University, Gifu, Japan
Abstract: Photovoltaic (PV) systems are negatively affected by many troubles, such as conductor faults, broken glass, cell aging, etc. Among them, partial shading conditions (PSC) not only reduce the output power of the PV systems but also cause hot spots on the surface of PV panels. This paper presents a Convolutional Neural Network-based method for PSC detection and classification. The highlights of this proposal are a scalogram extracted from the I-V characteristics of the PV array and a preprocessing phase implemented by a periodic function-based filter and the wavelet transform. The best accuracy of the proposed model is 98.41% through 819 test images after 50 training epochs, which proves its effectiveness. The future improvement of this work is also discussed in the conclusions. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author full names: Son Huu, Vu Xuan (58307617700); do Dinh, Hieu (58399834700); Minh Giang, Nguyen Hoang (58308063600); Takano, Hirotaka (54394480500); Nguyen, Duc Tuyen (58279068400)
Title: Deep Learning-Based Real-Time Solar Irradiation Monitoring and Forecasting Application for PV System
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Gifu University, Gifu, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Son Huu, Vu Xuan, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; do Dinh, Hieu, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Minh Giang, Nguyen Hoang, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Takano, Hirotaka, Department of Electrical, Electronic and Computer Engineering, Gifu University, Gifu, Japan; Nguyen, Duc Tuyen, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: Due to the high penetration of renewable energy sources (RESs), especially, solar power or photovoltaic (PV), the operation of the power system has coped with several severe technical issues such as supply-demand balance and low inertia. To mitigate these problems, PV power generation or solar irradiance forecast is of great importance. In the last decades, myriad forecasting methods have been introduced, yet these approaches do not concentrate on the real-time forecast. This paper proposes deep learning-based real-time solar irradiation monitoring and forecasting system with data collected from sensors before being stored in the database. Two predictive models, namely, Long Short-term Memory (LSTM) and Convolution Neural Network - Long Short-term Memory (CNN-LSTM), are constructed for day-ahead solar irradiance forecasting. These predicted results are aggregated employing Linear Least Square (LLS) method into the selected forecast values and updated periodically. The forecasting results show that the selected predicting values improve significantly compared to individual ones. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: V.K., Hoang, Van Khanh; O., Sambuu, Odmaa; J., Nishiyama, Jun; T., Obara, Toru
Author full names: Hoang, Van Khanh (57190619015); Sambuu, Odmaa (26536689700); Nishiyama, Jun (26533015900); Obara, Toru (7103069089)
Title: Impact of the Melt-Refining Process on the Performance of Sodium-Cooled Rotational Fuel-Shuffling Breed-and-Burn Reactors
Affiliations: Vietnam Atomic Energy Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam; National University of Mongolia, Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia; National University of Mongolia, Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia; Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Hoang, Van Khanh, Vietnam Atomic Energy Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Sambuu, Odmaa, School of Engineering and Applied Sciences, National University of Mongolia, Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia, Nuclear Research Center, National University of Mongolia, Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia; Nishiyama, Jun, Laboratory for Zero-Carbon Energy, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Obara, Toru, Laboratory for Zero-Carbon Energy, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: This study assesses a Rotational Fuel-Shuffling Breed-and-Burn (RFBB) fast reactor that operates in breed-and-burn (B&B) mode with a rotational fuel-shuffling scheme and remains within the 200 displacements per atom (DPA) radiation damage constraint of currently verified cladding materials. The design is based on a commercial-scale fast burner reactor called the Super Power Reactor Innovative Small Module (S-PRISM) reactor. To reduce the high DPA values of discharged fuels, the melt-refining process developed in the Experimental Breeder Reactor-II (EBR-II) project is adopted in this study. The effects of the melt-refining process on the performance of the RFBB are investigated via five scenarios and compared with a core to which the melt-refining process is not applied: Scenario I, “Homogenization,” occurs without the removal of fission products (FPs) during the melt-refining process; Scenario II, “Homogenization and FP Removal,” occurs with the removal of FPs to a fraction similar to that in the melt-refining process developed in the EBR-II project; Scenario III, “Homogenization, FP Removal, and Make-Up,” is similar to Scenario II but makes up fuel losses with natural uranium; Scenario IV, “With 1% TRU [transuranics] Losses,” is similar to Scenario III but is evaluated with 1% of actinides not recovered; Scenario V, “With 10% TRU Losses,” is similar to Scenario III but is evaluated with 10% of actinides not recovered. The results show that it is neutronically and thermal hydraulically feasible to establish a B&B mode with the rotational fuel-shuffling scheme and by reconditioning the fuel whenever its cladding reaches its proven 200 DPA radiation damage limit. In Scenario V, the core is subcritical due to a large number of actinides not being recovered during the melt-refining process. The cores of the other scenarios are all critical. The cores of scenarios in which FPs are removed during the melt-refining process have higher excess reactivity than that of the core of Scenario I (“Homogenization”) and that of the core to which the melt-refining process is not applied. The numerical analyses also show that in scenarios that include making up fuel losses during melt refining, the core is fed with more natural uranium make-up fuel during operation and thus has lower burnup. Other characteristics, such as power density distributions, neutron flux profiles, and fertile and fissile nuclide density distributions, are all stable during operation. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: G.M.T., Nguyen, Gia Minh Thao; L., Ton-That, Long; K., Fujisaki, Keisuke; K., Naruse, Kenya; H., Naitoh, Haruo
Author full names: Nguyen, Gia Minh Thao (55903864900); Ton-That, Long (24389745600); Fujisaki, Keisuke (56449463400); Naruse, Kenya (57226093782); Naitoh, Haruo (7006168623)
Title: Conceptual Diagrams of Extended Building Factor for Analysis and Evaluation of Factors on Core Loss Density Increase in IPMSM
Affiliations: Toyota Technological Institute, Nagoya, Japan; International University - Vietnam National University HCM City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Gia Minh Thao, Toyota Technological Institute, Nagoya, Japan; Ton-That, Long, Toyota Technological Institute, Nagoya, Japan, School of Electrical Engineering, International University - Vietnam National University HCM City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Fujisaki, Keisuke, Toyota Technological Institute, Nagoya, Japan; Naruse, Kenya, Toyota Technological Institute, Nagoya, Japan; Naitoh, Haruo, Toyota Technological Institute, Nagoya, Japan
Abstract: This study analyzes and evaluates the stator core loss density of an interior permanent magnet synchronous motor (IPMSM) by proposing and developing conceptual diagrams of an extended building factor while considering the nonlinearity of the magnetic properties of the material. The IPMSM, whose stator and rotor are composed of non-oriented electrical steel, is investigated. First, the motor is driven by a three-phase inverter with the pulse width modulation (PWM) excitation method and then with the three-phase sinusoidal excitation technique at a rotational speed of 1500 rpm in each condition. The calculation procedure of the stator core loss of the IPMSM is improved from our previous method. The finite element method (FEM) is used to support the identification and computation of motor iron losses, where the PWM carrier frequency is 10 kHz. In addition, experimental results of the extended building factor diagrams for the ring and IPMSM cores under the sinusoidal and inverter excitations are shown and discussed. The main objectives of this study are to investigate and clarify the reasons for increasing the IPMSM stator core loss density owing to the effects of the core shapes and two excitation methods, as well as to thoroughly identify the dominant impact between the core shape and excitation method on the increase in the iron loss density. Furthermore, based on the extended building factor, particular values of the IPMSM stator and rotor core losses in the experiment can be relatively separated and determined. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Future changes in mean and extreme precipitation over Peninsular Malaysia using CORDEX-SEA 5 km simulations
Affiliations: Universiti Malaysia Terengganu, Kuala Terengganu, Malaysia; Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia, Bangi, Malaysia; Ramkhamhaeng University, Bangkok, Thailand; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Ateneo de Manila University, Quezon City, Philippines; Agency for Meteorology Climatology and Geophysics (BMKG), Jakarta, Indonesia; Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, Canberra, Australia; National Institute for Environmental Studies of Japan, Tsukuba, Japan; Meteorological Research Institute, Tsukuba, Japan; National University of Singapore, Singapore City, Singapore; Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok, Thailand; National Water Research Institute of Malaysia (NAHRIM), Seri Kembangan, Malaysia; Badan Riset dan Inovasi Nasional, Central Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Chung, Jing Xiang, Faculty of Science and Marine Environment, Universiti Malaysia Terengganu, Kuala Terengganu, Malaysia; Juneng, Liew, Faculty of Science and Technology, Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia, Bangi, Malaysia; Santisirisomboon, Jerasorn, Ramkhamhaeng University, Bangkok, Thailand; Ngo-Duc, Thanh, REMOSAT Laboratory, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Phan-Van, Tan, Department of Meteorology and Climate Change, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Trinh-Tuan, Long, Center for Environmental Fluid Dynamics, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Cruz, Faye T., Regional Climate Systems Laboratory, Ateneo de Manila University, Quezon City, Philippines; Dado, Julie Mae B., Regional Climate Systems Laboratory, Ateneo de Manila University, Quezon City, Philippines; Srisawadwong, Ratchanan, Ramkhamhaeng University, Bangkok, Thailand; Gunawan, Dodo, Center for Climate Change Information, Agency for Meteorology Climatology and Geophysics (BMKG), Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: The Coordinated Regional Climate Downscaling Experiment (CORDEX) Southeast Asia further downscaled three of its 25 km products, i.e. EC-Earth, HadGEM2-ES and MPI-ESM-MR forced regional climate simulations to a higher resolution of 5 km. A newer RegCM4.7 model was used for this exercise. For the simulations over Peninsular Malaysia, analysis shows that these simulations have much smaller precipitation biases. They can correctly predict the annual precipitation cycle over the east coast of Peninsular Malaysia compared to the 25 km simulations. The ensemble of these . 5 km simulations indicates that Peninsular Malaysia is expected to experience a decrease in its seasonal mean precipitation, regardless of the RCP 4.5 or RCP 8.5 scenarios. Aside from the reduction of seasonal mean precipitation, consecutive dry and wet days are expected to increase and decrease, respectively. This indicates that Peninsular Malaysia will experience a long dry spell in the future. At the same time, it is suggested that Peninsular Malaysia will have fewer days with very heavy precipitation. Overall, the findings from this study suggest that the 5 km downscaled climate simulations improve significantly over 25 km and that the Peninsular Malaysia region can expect a drier future climate and extremes. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Removal of hexavalent chromium using durian in the form of rind, cellulose, and activated carbon: Comparison on adsorption performance and economic evaluation

Abstract: Durian rind (DR) is one of the lignocellulose-containing agro-industrial wastes abundant in many South Asian counties. Contributing toward a sustainable and zero waste future, DR was utilized as raw material for cellulose and activated carbon production. A chemical delignification method was adopted to valorize DR into cellulose, while carbonization and subsequent KOH activation steps were used to convert the DR into activated carbon. The resulting materials exhibited high adsorption capacity toward Cr6+ (154.2 and 223.3 mg/g for cellulose and activated carbon, respectively). The activated carbon derived from DR exhibited a faster adsorption rate of Cr6+ compared to cellulose and raw DR. The adsorption of Cr6+ by DR-derived adsorbents exhibited a monolayer tendency, with isotherm and kinetics data following the Khan and pseudo-second-order models. The total production cost of converting DR into cellulose and activated carbon was evaluated using life-cycle cost analysis (LCCA). Compared to the cellulose production, DR to activated carbon conversion requires up to 6-fold higher cost for energy. Based on the economic analysis, ∼US$ 2.9 and US$ 4.2 were needed to convert 1 kg DR into cellulose and activated carbon, respectively. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Peace Thought and Socioeconomy for the Space Age Using Satellites

Abstract: As humans move into space, we need to seek a better and more sustainable space economic system. Given the current social philosophies of the Earth, it is likely that future humans will repeat the same destructive patterns of their predecessors, including a return to war and neglect of the environment. This article explores new ideas for the peaceful use of the planet, focusing on the sustainable development goals and other economic systems and a new system of giving and wealth redistribution called the "One Smile Foundation." © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Deflector effect on flow behavior and drag of an Ahmed body under crosswind conditions
Source title: Journal of Wind Engineering and Industrial Aerodynamics
Affiliations: Le Quy Don Technical University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Kyushu University, Research Institute for Applied Mechanics, Kasuga, Japan; Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan; Mazda Motor Corporation, Fuchu, Japan

Abstract: This study investigates the effect of a deflector on Ahmed model drag and the flow on the slant during steady crosswind conditions by experimental methods at a based-height Reynolds number of 2.45 × 105. The length deflector is 0.09 times the length of the slant. The deflector was fixed at the leading edge of the slant with an upward angle of 5° to the horizontal axis. Force, pressure, and global skin-friction measurements were conducted to understand the relation between drag, pressure distribution, and flow fields on the slant surface. The results showed that the deflector reduces aerodynamic drag at low yaw angles. This result is due to the breakdown structure of longitudinal vortexes and the separation bubble, which leads to fully separated flow on the leading edge of the slant. However, at yaw angles above 8°, a large reversed flow region forms on the slant and the drag of the model increases. A similar flow structure on the slant is observed for yaw angles of 12° and 15°. Conversely, the model lift is reduced with the deflector at all yaw angles tested. Detailed pressure distribution and complex flow structure on the slant provide insight in this study. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Mobile power generation system based on biomass gasification
Source title: International Journal of Coal Science and Technology
Affiliations: East China University of Science and Technology, Shanghai, China; Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Zaozhuang University, Zaozhuang, China; Dại học Nguyen Tat Thanh, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Ltd, Huzhou City, China; Ural Federal University, Yekaterinburg, Russian Federation

F., Ural Federal University, Yekaterinburg, Russian Federation; Yoshikawa, Kunio, Ltd, Huzhou City, China
Abstract: Disaster-hit and/or un-electrified remote areas usually have electricity accessibility issues and an abundance of plant-derived debris and wood from destroyed wooden structures; this can be potentially addressed by employing a decentralized ultra-small biomass-fed gasification power generating system. This paper presents an assessment of the technical viability of an ultra-small gasification system that utilizes densified carbonized wood pellets/briquettes. The setup was run continuously for 100 h. A variety of biomass was densified and carbonized by harnessing fugitive heat sources before charging into the reactor. Carbonized briquettes and furnished blends exhibited inferior gasification performance compared to the carbonized pellets. In the absence of tar blockage problems, steady-state conditions were achieved when pre-treated feedstock was used. Under steady-state conditions for carbonized pellets gasification operated at an equivalence ratio of 0.32, cold gas efficiency and carbon conversion achieved 49.2% and 70.5%, respectively. Overall efficiency and maximum power output of 20.3% and 21 kW were realised, respectively. It was found that the system could keep stable while the low heating valve of syngas was over 4 MJ/m3 on condition that avoiding tar blocking issues. The results indicate that the proposed compact ultra-small power generation system is a technically feasible approach to remedy power shortage challenge. In addition, process simulation considering carbonized wood gasification combined power generation was formulated to produce syngas and electricity. Woody pellets with the flow rate of 20 kg/h could generate a 15.18 kW power at the air flow rate of 40 Nm3/h, which is in a good agreement with 15 kW in the 100 h operation. It is indicated that the gasification combined power generation cycle simulated by Aspen simulator could achieve reliable data to assist the complicated experiment operation. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: New optimized configuration for a hybrid PV/diesel/battery system based on coyote optimization algorithm: A case study for Hotan county

Abstract: The main objective of this study is to present a multi-objective and optimal hybrid PV/diesel generator/ battery Renewable Energy System (HRES) to provide this reliability in the Hotan county, placed in Taklamakan Desert. This study uses the ɛ-constraint method along with a developed version of the coyote optimization algorithm to achieve the best values of the component sized to decrease the loss of load probability, CO<inf>2</inf> emission value, and the annualized cost of the system. Sensitivity analysis also is performed to show each component's impact on the system. The results demonstrate that the DG backup system improves the yearly cost of the system from 8347.2 $ to 9318.4 $, which shows about 10.42% increasing by increasing the fuel consumption. Here, the LLP increases from 0% to 9.19% and the CO2 emissions improve from 2531.2 kg/yr to 13257 kg/yr. Accordingly, the COE value is reduced from 0.39 $/kWh to 0.24 $/kWh over the PV penetration, reducing from 92.27% to 59.42%. This decreasing indicates that the system fuel cost has more impact than the cost of PV on the COE, which is due to the low cost required of conventional power production than the PV system. The results also indicate a noteworthy upshot on the battery storage unit size such that the size of ɛ<inf>CO<inf>2</inf></inf> has been enhanced from 27.4 kWh to 50 kWh in the range from 7000 kg/year to 25 kg/year. The results also are compared with the PSO-based optimal system and HOMER software results to show its excellence toward them. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Y., Yu, Ying; A., Mori, Akihisa; T.D., Truong, Thuy Dang; N., Kittner, Noah
Author full names: Yu, Ying (57209100786); Mori, Akihisa (57190668519); Truong, Thuy Dang (55204355000); Kittner, Noah (55874868200)
Title: Will the public in emerging economies support renewable energy? Evidence from Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam
Affiliations: Department of Environmental Sciences and Engineering, Chapel Hill, United States; The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; University of Economics Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; College of Arts & Sciences, Chapel Hill, United States
Authors with affiliations: Yu, Ying, Department of Environmental Sciences and Engineering, Chapel Hill, United States; Mori, Akihisa, Graduate School of Public Policy, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Truong, Thuy Dang, School of Economics, University of Economics Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Kittner, Noah, Department of Environmental Sciences and Engineering, Chapel Hill, United States, College of Arts & Sciences, Chapel Hill, United States
Abstract: Public acceptance and support are crucial to increasing the adoption of renewable energy technologies and establishing new renewable energy policies. In Vietnam, where plans to rapidly scale-up electricity generation are among the fastest globally, one question of interest is what would motivate people to pay more for electricity generated by renewable energy sources? As part of its national Power Development Plan, Vietnam targets a future electricity mix consisting of at least 21% renewable energy by 2030. This study assesses the public's willingness to pay (WTP) for increasing renewable energy share and corresponding motivating factors in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam. Drawing from a valid sample of 294 households, this study uses a double-bounded dichotomous choice contingent valuation method (CVM) to evaluate the public perception of renewable energy. On average, respondents are willing to pay about $4.39 USD more on their monthly electric bill to support renewable energy, which represents a 9.48% increase. Notably, respondents most concerned with air quality and the utility's profitability indicated their support to pay more for renewable energy. This study suggests the importance of communicating health-related air pollution mitigation benefits for emerging economies and building support among customers so that electric utilities can increase renewable energy targets. From a policy perspective, improved and transparent disclosure of air pollution data and utility financial statements could expedite the transition to renewable energy in emerging economies, such as Vietnam. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: D.C., Nguyen, Dong Chung; Y., Ishikawa, Yasuaki
Author full names: Nguyen, Dong Chung (57211267147); Ishikawa, Yasuaki (7403118748)
Title: Artificial neural network for predicting annual output energy of building-integrated photovoltaics based on the 2-terminal perovskite/silicon tandem cells under realistic conditions
Affiliations: Aoyama Gakuin University, Tokyo, Japan; Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Materials Science, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Dong Chung, College of Science and Engineering, Aoyama Gakuin University, Tokyo, Japan, Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Materials Science, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Ishikawa, Yasuaki, College of Science and Engineering, Aoyama Gakuin University, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: A high-efficiency perovskite/silicon tandem solar cell has been a promising candidate for building-integrated photovoltaics. This work presents a deep learning approach to predicting the annual output energy harvested by the 2-terminal perovskite/silicon tandem solar cells, thereby optimizing the tandem structure design. The data set for training and validating an artificial neural network (ANN) is the Atlas-simulated results of the tandem cell with the various perovskite layer's bandgap and thickness under the real-world conditions composed of the solar spectrum, incident spectral angle, and solar module temperature in a particular month of a year for a specific direction. Consequently, we reveal the significant influence of solar spectral shape on the ANN performance. The proposed ANN model has a mean square error of 1.26 and a correlation coefficient of 0.99979. Based on the spectral and environmental database in Gifu (Japan) in 2015, we predict that the optimal perovskite layer's bandgap and thickness are 1.72 eV and 680 nm for the east, south, and west facades, 1.73 eV and 700 nm for the rooftop, respectively. Consequently, the highest annual output energy obtained is 282.54, 105.07, 174.71, and 90.79 kWh/m2 for the rooftop, the east, south, and west facades, respectively. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Nguyen et al. (2022b) ) coming to the solar cell planes are estimated by the website . The solar module temperature was calculated in this work following the estimation method for the solar cells based on the silicon wafer ( Oh et al., 2010 ), as presented in the SI.

Authors: V.D., Dang, Van Dien; C., Hsiao, Changyu; P.–., Le, Phuoc –.Anh; V.Q., Le, Van Qui; D., Ho Phuong Thao, Dang; T.H., Do, Thi Hien; K.H., Wei, Kung– Hwa
Author full names: Dang, Van Dien (57218252185); Hsiao, Changyu (57765742700); Le, Phuoc –.Anh (57211802056); Le, Van Qui (57217604418); Ho Phuong Thao, Dang (57209369158); Do, Thi Hien (57188737815); Wei, Kung– Hwa (7203013401)
Title: Surface-Plasma-Induced One-Pot Synthesis of N,S-Carbon Dot Intercalated MoS2/Graphene Nanosheets for Highly Efficient Hydrogen Evolution Reaction
Affiliations: National Yang Ming Chiao Tung University, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Ho Chi Minh City University of Industry and Trade, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Shinshu University, Matsumoto, Japan; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; National Yang Ming Chiao Tung University, Hsinchu, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Dang, Van Dien, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, National Yang Ming Chiao Tung University, Hsinchu, Taiwan, Faculty of Biology and Environment, Ho Chi Minh City University of Industry and Trade, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Hsiao, Changyu, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, National Yang Ming Chiao Tung University, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Le, Phuoc –.Anh, Shinshu University, Matsumoto, Japan, Institute of Sustainability Science, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Le, Van Qui, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, National Yang Ming Chiao Tung University, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Ho Phuong Thao, Dang, Faculty of Biology and Environment, Ho Chi Minh City University of Industry and Trade, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Do, Thi Hien, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, National Yang Ming Chiao Tung University, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Wei, Kung– Hwa, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, National Yang Ming Chiao Tung University, Hsinchu, Taiwan, Center for Emergent Functional Matter Science, National Yang Ming Chiao Tung University, Hsinchu, Taiwan
Abstract: Herein, a facile and rapid surface-plasma-induced method was adopted for the one-pot synthesis of a 2D/0D/2D hybrid nanostructure consisting of N,S co-doped carbon dots (NSCD) intercalated few-layer MoS<inf>2</inf>/graphene nanosheets (MoS<inf>2</inf>/G) as an excellent catalyst for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). In this process, bulk MoS<inf>2</inf>and graphite foil served as the sources of MoS<inf>2</inf>and graphene nanosheets, respectively, while glucose and thiourea served as the source of NSCD. The sturdy integration of 0D NSCD and 2D MoS<inf>2</inf>/G in a well-constructed ternary composite provided a huge number of edge active sites with tunable and extraordinary physicochemical properties for electron transport, facilitating HER performance. The optimal NSCD@MoS<inf>2</inf>/G exhibited a superior catalytic activity toward HER with a low onset potential (37 mV), an overpotential of 98 mV at 10 mA cm-2, and a Tafel slope as small as 53 mV dec-1, which were better than other 2D electrocatalysts. The increase in double-layer capacitance for NSCD@MoS<inf>2</inf>/G (12.2 mF cm-2), which was 2-fold of the MoS<inf>2</inf>/G sample, is strong evidence of the large catalytic edge sites and electrical coupling in the NSCD@MoS<inf>2</inf>/G ternary system. Moreover, the strong bonding and interaction between NSCD and MoS<inf>2</inf>/G nanosheets enabled outstanding long-term stability and structural integrity, displaying 95 and 90% activity retention at 10 and 50 mA cm-2after 48 h i-t test, respectively. This approach paves the way to efficient syntheses of 2D/0D/2D heterostructures with great potential for various energy-related applications. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: D.T., Nguyen, Duc Tuyen; L., Hoang-Tuan, Linh; H., Ta-Xuan, Hung; L., Do-Van, Long; H., Takano, Hirotaka
Author full names: Nguyen, Duc Tuyen (58279068400); Hoang-Tuan, Linh (57929472800); Ta-Xuan, Hung (57929092300); Do-Van, Long (57411357500); Takano, Hirotaka (54394480500)
Title: A Mixed-Integer Programming Approach for Unit Commitment in Micro-Grid with Incentive-Based Demand Response and Battery Energy Storage System
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan; Gifu University, Gifu, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Duc Tuyen, School of Electrical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Department of Electrical Engineering, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan; Hoang-Tuan, Linh, School of Electrical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Ta-Xuan, Hung, School of Electrical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Do-Van, Long, School of Electrical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Takano, Hirotaka, Department of Electrical, Gifu University, Gifu, Japan
Abstract: In the context of the increasing penetration of intermittent renewable energy resources (RES), one of the significant challenges facing traditional bulk power systems and microgrids is the scheduling generation units problem. Many studies have focused on solving the energy management problem for microgrids integrating RES. To address the intermittency caused by RES, flexible components such as battery energy storage systems (BESS) or demand response (DR) are considered. To clarify the problem of integrating these flexible components, a mixed-integer programming (MIP) approach for the unit commitment (UC) problem for microgrids with BESS and DR is proposed in this paper. An incentive-based demand response model as a negative power source and a detailed model for the vanadium redox battery (VRB) are introduced to improve the efficiency and reliability of microgrids. The objective optimization function, including the costs of generation, emissions, and maintenance, is minimized considering the uncertainty of the load and renewable energy sources. The obtained simulation results are compared with the genetic algorithm (GA) method as the basis for verification in different case studies. The obtained results have clarified the effect of using the BESS model and DR program on system operation. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Post-flood recovery in the central coastal plain of Vietnam: determinants and policy implications
Affiliations: University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; University of Economics, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; University of Agriculture and Forestry, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Ha, Vo Hoang, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan, Faculty of Economics and Development Studies, University of Economics, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Mizunoya, Takeshi, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Nguyen Duc, Kien, Faculty of Economics and Development Studies, University of Economics, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Dung, Truong Quang, Faculty of Economics and Development Studies, University of Economics, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; An, Le Thanh, Faculty of Economics and Development Studies, University of Economics, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Phan, Nguyen Thai, Faculty of Economics and Development Studies, University of Economics, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Tan Quang, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; Tien, Pham Thi Trieu, Faculty of Land Resources and Agricultural Environment, University of Agriculture and Forestry, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Dinh, Nguyen Cong, Faculty of Economics and Development Studies, University of Economics, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam
Abstract: This study focused on the timing aspects of post-flood recovery, which has not been adequately considered by previous scholars. Data for analysis were obtained from direct interviews with households in Quang Dien and Phong Dien coastal plain districts of Thua Thien Hue Province, Central Vietnam. Both quantitative and qualitative approaches were employed to gain insight into factors driving household rehabilitation. The findings accentuated improvements in women's post-flood resilience as a result of effective interventions from communities, authorities and NGOs. Diversifying livelihoods into the non-agricultural sector was also an important factor to shorten the rehabilitation processes. Additionally, the results emphasized the efficacy of social interactions, notably between relatives and informal groups, after floods. The potential negative consequences of reliance on government support in household rehabilitation efforts are also preliminarily discussed. We conclude by suggesting a number of policies and interventions related to poverty eradication, livelihood diversification, strengthening community cohesion, and breaking down the reliance psychology. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Central Vietnam; Flood Recovery; Flood Rehabilitation; Floods; Social Connections

Title: Emergence of Different Replica Dirac Cones and Intra- and Intervalley Scatterings in Short-Wavelength Graphene Superlattices Modulated by an Atomic-Scale Sharp Potential
Affiliations: University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Center for Innovative Materials and Architectures, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HUTECH, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Vu, Nam Hoang, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Center for Innovative Materials and Architectures, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Le, Hieuvan, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Phan, Thang Bach, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Center for Innovative Materials and Architectures, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Thoai, Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, High Performance Computing Laboratory, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Toan The, Faculty of Physics, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Le, Hungminh, Faculty of Natural Sciences, Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Kawazoe, Yoshiyuki, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Minh Cao, Thi, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HUTECH, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Abstract: Here, we calculate the unfolded band structure of short-wavelength graphene superlattices modulated by the atomic-scale sharp potential of a semiconductor surface, using density functional theory. We show that in the case of the superlattice graphene Brillouin zone (SBZ) center folded into the primitive graphene Brillouin zone (GBZ) corner, the emergence of different replica Dirac cones and their scattering behaviors are driven by the substrate-induced potential or atomic-scale disorders as well as by the correlation between the rotation angle of the superlattice and the trigonal warping orientation of the Dirac cone because of the quantum interference associated with the scattering at the SBZ edge. In particular, a superlattice with a rotational angle of φ = 30° (G-N√3 × N√3-R30°, N > 1) facilitates intervalley scattering, whereas an unrotated superlattice (G-N3 × N3) is favorable to intravalley scattering. For a superlattice with a rotational angle in the range of 0 < φ < 30°, the intervalley and intravalley scatterings may be comparable to each other, leading to the emergence of mixed inequivalent replica cones at the SBZ center (or GBZ corner). Interestingly, such inequivalent replica cones facilitate a stronger intervalley scattering at the GBZ corner, compared to the G-N√3 × N√3-R30° and G-N3 × N3 superlattices, thus opening a larger energy gap at the primitive Dirac point. In addition to the inversion symmetry breaking in graphene, we show that intervalley scattering can also generate an energy gap at the secondary Dirac point. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.N., Duong, Thanh Nga; K.Q., Tran, Khiem Quang; T., Satomi, Tomoaki; H., Takahashi, Hiroshi
Author full names: Duong, Thanh Nga (57766164900); Tran, Khiem Quang (57195357032); Satomi, Tomoaki (54922505400); Takahashi, Hiroshi (55711673600)
Title: Effects of agricultural by-product on mechanical properties of cemented waste soil
Affiliations: Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Duong, Thanh Nga, Faculty of Civil Engineering, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Tran, Khiem Quang, Faculty of Civil Engineering, Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Satomi, Tomoaki, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Takahashi, Hiroshi, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan
Abstract: Waste soil produced from construction sites currently emerges as a big problem to environment. These soils cannot be reused directly cause of its weakness in strength properties. Hence, this study focuses on improving mechanical properties of waste soil by using cement and corn husk fiber. The environment has also benefited from using corn husk fiber since corn husk is agricultural by-product. In order to evaluate the impact of corn husk fiber and cement on mechanical characteristics of waste soil, a series of laboratory experiments containing tension and compression test is carried out. In addition, scanning electron microscopy (SEM) test is conducted to investigate interaction between fibers and soil-cement matrix. Fiber content from 0 to 1% by dry soil mass and corn husk lengths of 10 and 30 mm are used in this research. The results present that strength properties of cemented soil are enhanced when fiber is added. The most improvements corresponding to compressive strength, splitting tensile strength, and direct tensile strength are 30.6%, 206.1%, and 27.9%, respectively. A strong interaction between fibers and soil-cement matrix observed from SEM results in the improvement of strength properties of cemented soil. Fiber inclusion contributes to the more ductile and durable behavior under loading. Fiber length and fiber content have a remarkable effect on the cemented soil behavior. The increase in fiber length and content leads to the increase in residual stress and the decrease in loss of post-peak stress. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Assessing teacher training programs for the prevalence of sustainability in learning outcomes, learning content and didactic approaches
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Education, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Trường Đại học Sư phạm Hà Nội, Hanoi, Viet Nam; University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; National Academy of Education Management, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kyoto University of Foreign Studies, Kyoto, Japan; Universität Bayreuth, Bayreuth, Germany; Open Universiteit, Heerlen, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Anh Ngoc K., Hanoi University of Education, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Thao Phuong, Trường Đại học Sư phạm Hà Nội, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kieu, Kinh Thi, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Yen Thi Hoang, National Academy of Education Management, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Dang, Dung Tien, Trường Đại học Sư phạm Hà Nội, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Singer, Jane, Kyoto University of Foreign Studies, Kyoto, Japan; Schruefer, Gabriele, Universität Bayreuth, Bayreuth, Germany; Tran, Trinh Ba, Trường Đại học Sư phạm Hà Nội, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Lambrechts, Wim, Open Universiteit, Heerlen, Netherlands
Abstract: Reorienting teacher education should be placed at the heart of reorienting education towards sustainable development. This requires that teacher education institutes reorient and redefine their outcome standards as well as redesign their training programs accordingly to incorporate and implement Education for Sustainable Development (ESD). Although many efforts have been made to promote ESD in teacher training, little information is available regarding to what extent ESD is integrated in teacher training programs or curricula. This study examines how ESD is incorporated in teacher training programs in terms of learning content, learning outcomes and didactic approach, through analyzing 429 course syllabi offered by the Hanoi National University of Education (HNUE) in Vietnam. HNUE training programs were found to contain some elements of ESD but they lack coherence or systematic inclusion. The results suggest needed strategic changes at organizational (university) and individual (instructor) levels to improve ESD in teacher education. This paper contributes to the discussion on the implementation of a holistic curricular assessment approach for three aspects of ESD (learning content, learning outcomes and didactic approach) and highlights the ongoing need for improving curricular assessment strategies for sustainability. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: D.T., Nguyen, Duc Tuyen; D., Nguyen-Dang, Duong; T., Le-Viet, Thinh; G., Fujita, Goro
Author full names: Nguyen, Duc Tuyen (58279068400); Nguyen-Dang, Duong (57885564700); Le-Viet, Thinh (57221553909); Fujita, Goro (36186886000)
Title: Continuous Reconfiguration Framework for Photovoltaic Array under Variable Partial Shading Conditions: Heuristic-Based Algorithms with Optimizing Switching Operation
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Duc Tuyen, Department of Electrical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Department of Electrical Engineering, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan; Nguyen-Dang, Duong, Department of Electrical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Le-Viet, Thinh, Department of Electrical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Fujita, Goro, Department of Electrical Engineering, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: The operation of the photovoltaic (PV) system under partial shading conditions (PSC) is complicated since the output characteristic of the PV system is profoundly affected by the heterogeneous irradiance of PSC. This paper proposes a dynamic reconfiguration framework to tackle PSC in the PV array. Continuous operation of the dynamic PV array reconfiguration under cloud-induced partial shading is considered by developing an emulator of the moving cloud. In addition, the Particle Swarm Optimization and Rao algorithms are improved to obtain the optimal PV array configuration under PSC. The operation of switching is enhanced by simultaneously considering the total switching times and the operation of highly active switches. The simulation results on the (Formula presented.) PV array demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed framework in terms of reducing the number of local maximum power points on the power-voltage characteristic, enhancing power output, and relieving stress on the switching operation of the PV array under different PSC. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: D.T., Nguyen, Duc Tuyen; T., Le-Viet, Thinh; D., Nguyen-Dang, Duong; T., Dao-Quang, Tung; Q.M., Bui, Quang Minh
Author full names: Nguyen, Duc Tuyen (58279068400); Le-Viet, Thinh (57221553909); Nguyen-Dang, Duong (57885564700); Dao-Quang, Tung (57886496300); Bui, Quang Minh (57423693300)
Title: Photovoltaic Array Reconfiguration under Partial Shading Conditions Based on Short-Circuit Current Estimated by Convolutional Neural Network
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Duc Tuyen, Department of Electrical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Department of Electrical Engineering, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan; Le-Viet, Thinh, Department of Electrical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen-Dang, Duong, Department of Electrical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Dao-Quang, Tung, Department of Electrical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Bui, Quang Minh, Department of Electrical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: Partial shading conditions (PSC) have negative effects on the operation of photovoltaic (PV) systems. In this paper, a PV array reconfiguration method is developed to minimize power losses of PV arrays under partial shading conditions. The proposed reconfiguration method is based on equalizing the reduction of the short-circuit current of the PV modules in the PV array. Eight state-of-the-art Convolutional Neural Network models are employed to estimate the effect of shading on the short-circuit current of a PV module. These models include LeNet-5, AlexNet, VGG 11, VGG 19, Inception V3, ResNet 18, ResNet 34, and ResNet 50. Among eight models, the VGG 19 achieves the best accuracy on 1842 sample images. Therefore, this model is used to estimate the ratio of the actual short-circuit current and the estimated short-circuit current in four studied shading scenarios. This ratio decides the switching rule between PV modules throughout the PV array under PSC. A (Formula presented.) experimental PV array shows that the proposed reconfiguration method improves the output power from 5.81% to 25.19% in four shading patterns. Accordingly, the power losses are reduced from 1.32% to 13.75%. The power improvement and the reduction of power losses of the proposed dynamic PV array reconfiguration system under four case studies demonstrates its effectiveness in addressing the effects of PSC on the PV array. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
