Authors: K., Lin, Kuanyu; S., Nachimuthu, Santhanamoorthi; M.T., Nguyen, Minh Tho; H., Mizuta, Hiroshi; J.C., Jiang, Jyhchiang Chiang
Author full names: Lin, Kuanyu (57202237494); Nachimuthu, Santhanamoorthi (55142086900); Nguyen, Minh Tho (7401564839); Mizuta, Hiroshi (7103079845); Jiang, Jyhchiang Chiang (7404829292)
Title: Effects of Electric Field on the Performance of Graphene-Based Counter Electrodes for Dye-Sensitized Solar Cells: A Theoretical Study
Affiliations: National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, Taipei, Taiwan; Viện Khoa học và Công nghệ Tính toán, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; KU Leuven, Leuven, Belgium; Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Nomi, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Lin, Kuanyu, Department of Chemical Engineering, National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, Taipei, Taiwan; Nachimuthu, Santhanamoorthi, Department of Chemical Engineering, National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, Taipei, Taiwan; Nguyen, Minh Tho, Department of Chemical Engineering, National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, Taipei, Taiwan, Viện Khoa học và Công nghệ Tính toán, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, KU Leuven, Leuven, Belgium; Mizuta, Hiroshi, School of Materials Science, Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Nomi, Japan; Jiang, Jyhchiang Chiang, Department of Chemical Engineering, National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, Taipei, Taiwan
Abstract: We have investigated the influence of an external electric field on the performance of graphene-based counter electrode (CE) materials such as pristine, boron-doped graphene (BC<inf>5</inf>), and nitrogen-doped graphene (NC<inf>5</inf>) for dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs) using density functional theory calculations. The stable I<inf>2</inf> adsorption geometries, electronic properties, and charge transfer between I<inf>2</inf> and different graphene nanosheets in the presence and absence of an external electric field are calculated. We find that the NC<inf>5</inf> graphene sheet exhibits high affinity for the I<inf>2</inf> molecule and greater sensitivity to the external electric field. Our calculations indicate that the I<inf>2</inf> dissociation on the NC<inf>5</inf> graphene sheet is thermodynamically and kinetically favorable even in the absence of an external electric field; however, the I∗ atomic desorption energy is relatively large (0.70 eV), and it is the rate-determining step in the I<inf>3</inf> - reduction reaction. We demonstrate that a negative external electric field decreases the interaction between the I∗ atom and the NC<inf>5</inf> graphene sheet and eases the I∗ desorption. The excellent catalytic property of the NC<inf>5</inf> graphene sheet toward I<inf>2</inf> dissociation and I∗ atom desorption makes it as an alternative nonmetallic CE for DSSCs. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: K., Kakar, Kifayatullah; T.D., Xuan, T. D.; N.V., Quan, N. V.; I.K., Wafa, Imran Khan; H.D., Tran, Hoang Dung; T.D., Khanh, Tran Dang; T.D., Dat, Tran Dang
Author full names: Kakar, Kifayatullah (57208034396); Xuan, T. D. (7003473828); Quan, N. V. (57195263220); Wafa, Imran Khan (57208025084); Tran, Hoang Dung (57202392125); Khanh, Tran Dang (6603569488); Dat, Tran Dang (57200967821)
Title: Effcacy of N-Methyl-N-Nitrosourea mutation on physicochemical properties, phytochemicals, and momilactones A and B in rice
Affiliations: Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan; Nangarhar University, Jalalabad City, Nangarhar, Afghanistan; Ministry of Agriculture, Kabul, Afghanistan; Dại học Nguyen Tat Thanh, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Agricultural Genetics Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnam National University of Agriculture, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Khai Xuan International Co. Ltd., Ha Dong District, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Kakar, Kifayatullah, Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan, Faculty of Agriculture, Nangarhar University, Jalalabad City, Nangarhar, Afghanistan; Xuan, T. D., Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan; Quan, N. V., Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan; Wafa, Imran Khan, Irrigation and Livestock, Ministry of Agriculture, Kabul, Afghanistan; Tran, Hoang Dung, Faculty of Biotechnology, Dại học Nguyen Tat Thanh, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Khanh, Tran Dang, Department of Genetic Engineering, Agricultural Genetics Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Center for Expert, Vietnam National University of Agriculture, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Dat, Tran Dang, Khai Xuan International Co. Ltd., Ha Dong District, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: Attempts regarding the improvement and development of novel rice with better quality and higher productivity have been increasing. Among approaches, mutation is a direct alteration on the genome and considered as one of the most beneficial routes to acquire new beneficial traits in rice. An experiment was carried out to explore the effects of N-methyl-N-nitrosourea (MNU) mutation on the antioxidant activities, phytochemical compounds, and momilactones A (MA) and B (MB) in rice. Two rice cultivars, K1 (an original cultivar DT84) and K2 (mutated DT84), were examined. Antioxidant activities, phenolic compounds, and momilactones of the rice grain, husk, and straw portions were measured and quantified. Antioxidant activities were higher in grain and straw of K2, whereas K1 showed greater antioxidant activity in rice husk. Additionally, K2 displayed higher total phenolic contents (TPC) in grain and straw as well as lower of it in the husk, but these variations significantly differed only in the straw portion. An increase in total flavonoid contents (TFC) was observed in the husk of K1, while K2 significantly enhanced TFC in straw. Both MA and MB, two compounds obtaining antidiabetes, anticancer, antimicrobial, antigout, and antiobesity properties, were detected and quantified in grain, husk, and straw of K1 and K2 samples. Generally, the contents of MA were higher than MB in all tested portions of rice crop. MA and MB were higher in straw followed by those in husk and grain, respectively. K2 contained higher amounts of MA and MB in straw and husk, but lower contents in grain compared with those in K1. This study illustrates that MNU mutation can improve grain quality and enhance bioactive compounds in straw, husk, and grain of rice. This approach has the potential to develop functional foods from rice, and therefore help farmers in developing countries to improve value in rice production. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: S., Sekimoto, Shun; Y., Homura, Yuta; V.D., Ho, Van Doanh; M., Inagaki, Makoto; N., Shirai, Naoki; T., Ohtsuki, Tsutomu
Author full names: Sekimoto, Shun (9842612000); Homura, Yuta (57205277497); Ho, Van Doanh (57158859300); Inagaki, Makoto (56985257600); Shirai, Naoki (56404738300); Ohtsuki, Tsutomu (7202417813)
Title: Neutron activation analysis of carbonate reference materials: coral (JCp-1) and giant clam (JCt-1)
Source title: Journal of Radioanalytical and Nuclear Chemistry
Affiliations: Institute for Integrated Radiation and Nuclear Science, Kyoto University, Sennan, Japan; Vietnam Atomic Energy Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tokyo Metropolitan University, Hachioji, Japan; Novaltis Farma, Sapporo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sekimoto, Shun, Institute for Integrated Radiation and Nuclear Science, Kyoto University, Sennan, Japan; Homura, Yuta, Institute for Integrated Radiation and Nuclear Science, Kyoto University, Sennan, Japan, Novaltis Farma, Sapporo, Japan; Ho, Van Doanh, Vietnam Atomic Energy Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Inagaki, Makoto, Institute for Integrated Radiation and Nuclear Science, Kyoto University, Sennan, Japan; Shirai, Naoki, Department of Chemistry, Tokyo Metropolitan University, Hachioji, Japan; Ohtsuki, Tsutomu, Institute for Integrated Radiation and Nuclear Science, Kyoto University, Sennan, Japan
Abstract: Two kinds of carbonate reference materials, coral (JCp-1) and giant clam (JCt-1), were subjected to neutron activation analysis (NAA) using the Kyoto University Reactor in order to determine the halogen contents (Cl, Br, and I), as well as the abundances of a few other elements in these materials. The results from the present study are in agreement with previously reported data using this technique. However, inconsistencies are observed between the NAA data and data derived from inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry studies for some elements. From a comparison of the halogen contents in the two carbonate reference materials with those in sedimentary rocks, differences in the mode of formation of the two carbonates are discussed. © 2019 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H.N., Tran, Hoai Nam; Y., Kato, Yasuyoshi; P.H., Liem, Peng Hong; V.K., Hoang, Van Khanh; S.T., Hoang, Syminh Tuan
Author full names: Tran, Hoai Nam (15926474700); Kato, Yasuyoshi (7404906454); Liem, Peng Hong (6603970138); Hoang, Van Khanh (57190619015); Hoang, Syminh Tuan (56008648900)
Title: Minor Actinide Transmutation in Supercritical-CO2-Cooled and Sodium-Cooled Fast Reactors with Low Burnup Reactivity Swings
Affiliations: Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Tokyo City University, Tokyo, Japan; Nippon Advanced Information Service, Naka, Japan; Vietnam Atomic Energy Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Tran, Hoai Nam, Institute of Fundamental and Applied Sciences, Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Kato, Yasuyoshi, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Liem, Peng Hong, Cooperative Major in Nuclear Energy, Tokyo City University, Tokyo, Japan, Nippon Advanced Information Service, Naka, Japan; Hoang, Van Khanh, Vietnam Atomic Energy Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hoang, Syminh Tuan, Institute of Fundamental and Applied Sciences, Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam
Abstract: This paper presents the investigation of minor actinide (MA) transmutation in supercritical CO<inf>2</inf>-cooled and sodium-cooled fast reactors (S-CO<inf>2</inf>-FR and SFR) with the thermal output of 600 MW(thermal) for simultaneously attaining low burnup reactivity swings and reducing long-life radioactive waste. Minor actinides are loaded uniformly in the fuel of the cores, and the MA contents are determined to minimize the burnup reactivity swings. In the S-CO<inf>2</inf>-FR, the burnup reactivity swing is minimized to 0.11% ∆k/kk’ when the MA content is 6.0 wt%. In the SFR, the MA content was determined to reduce the burnup reactivity swing while maintaining sodium void reactivity under a design limitation of 5 $. The burnup reactivity swing of the SFR is reduced to 1.94% ∆k/kk’, whereas sodium void reactivity is about 4.7 $ when 10.0 wt% MAs are loaded. The low burnup reactivity swing enables minimization of control rod operation during fuel burnup. The number of control rods in the two reactors is reduced to ten, which is half of a typical sodium-cooled mixed-oxide fuel MONJU reactor without MA loading. The MA transmutation rates in the S-CO<inf>2</inf>-FR and SFR are 42.2 and 52.2 kg/year, respectively, which are equivalent to the production rates in seven and nine light water reactors of the same electrical output. © 2019 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: K., Trang, Kien; L., Tonthat, Long; G.M.T., Nguyen, Gia Minh Thao; N., Tran Ta Thi, Ngoc
Author full names: Trang, Kien (57200629762); Tonthat, Long (57196008888); Nguyen, Gia Minh Thao (57219665250); Tran Ta Thi, Ngoc (57212212905)
Title: Mango Diseases Identification by a Deep Residual Network with Contrast Enhancement and Transfer Learning
Affiliations: International University - Vietnam National University HCM City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Toyota Technological Institute, Nagoya, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Trang, Kien, School of Electrical Engineering, International University - Vietnam National University HCM City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tonthat, Long, School of Electrical Engineering, International University - Vietnam National University HCM City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Gia Minh Thao, Toyota Technological Institute, Nagoya, Japan; Tran Ta Thi, Ngoc, School of Electrical Engineering, International University - Vietnam National University HCM City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Abstract: Plant diseases have a great influence on the productivity and economics of agriculture. In the traditional method where manual labour and experiences play important roles, early plant disease detection and prevention for field crop are inefficient. This can bring negative effects in stopping the spread of diseases. Applications of image processing techniques and computer vision may provide a solution to these problems. Deep learning is known as one of the most powerful techniques which is able to address more complicated tasks compared to traditional machine learning thanks to the embedded complex layers. This paper presents an image-based diseases identification method using a deep neural network with contrast enhancement and transfer learning from the PlantVillage dataset. Since there exist various sizes of leaf, rescaling and centre alignment are performed to standardize images. Besides, contrast enhancement is used to improve quality of visualization which gives a well-prepared step for further processing. By using a collected mango disease dataset, the proposed model is trained to identify 3 common diseases from the healthy one. The proposed model is then compared with other pre-trained models. An accuracy of 88.46% is achieved for the proposed model, which is higher than the results obtained from other pre-trained models. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H.X., Nguyen, Hieu Xuan; T., Tsuji, Takao
Author full names: Nguyen, Hieu Xuan (57197779463); Tsuji, Takao (35354735900)
Title: Boundary Optimal Power Output of Solar PV Systems in Medium Voltage Distribution System
Affiliations: Yokohama National University, Yokohama, Japan; Vietnam National University of Agriculture, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Hieu Xuan, Yokohama National University, Yokohama, Japan, Vietnam National University of Agriculture, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tsuji, Takao, Yokohama National University, Yokohama, Japan
Abstract: The rapid introduction of photovoltaic (PV) systems into distribution networks causes serious power quality issues e.g. overvoltage and power asset overloading which limit the rating and number of further PV connections. Recently, with the advanced technology of smart meters, both active and reactive power outputs of PV inverters are tuned to optimize network operation e.g. minimizing network loss and PVs' active power curtailment in centralized methods. However, searching the optimal output of PVs in a large feasible operational region along with several variables due to the increasing number of PV systems requires a centralized controller much time to converge and cannot efficiently catch up with the change of PVs' output in the real operation. In this paper, by narrowing the searching region, boundary optimal inverter dispatch method is proposed. More reliable simulation outputs are obtained within a shorter calculation time, making the proposed method more applicable in the practical operation. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: K.N., Dang, Khanh N.; M.C., Meyer, Michael Conrad; A., Ben Ahmed, Akram; A., Ben Abdallah, Abderazek; X.T., Tran, Xuan Tu
Author full names: Dang, Khanh N. (57188649063); Meyer, Michael Conrad (56446153500); Ben Ahmed, Akram (55637510200); Ben Abdallah, Abderazek (6505933787); Tran, Xuan Tu (16308138900)
Title: 2D-PPC: A single-correction multiple-detection method for Through-Silicon-Via Faults
Affiliations: Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Waseda University, Tokyo, Japan; National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan; The University of Aizu, Aizuwakamatsu, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Dang, Khanh N., ISISLAB, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Meyer, Michael Conrad, G.S. of Information, Waseda University, Tokyo, Japan; Ben Ahmed, Akram, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan; Ben Abdallah, Abderazek, Adaptive Systems Laboratory, The University of Aizu, Aizuwakamatsu, Japan; Tran, Xuan Tu, ISISLAB, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: Through-Silicon-Via (TSV) is one of the most promising technologies to realize 3D Integrated Circuits (3D-ICs). However, the reliability issues due to the low yield rates, the sensitivity to thermal hotspots and stress issues due to the difference in temperature between layers are preventing TSV-based 3D-ICs from being widely and efficiently used. Due to defect clustering, 3D-ICs could have multiple defects in the same region which cannot be detected by using error correction codes while dedicated testing could take a significant number of testing cycles. This paper presents a 2D Parity Product Code (2D-PPC) with the ability to correct one fault and detect, at least, two faults. With the extension using Orthogonal Latin Square, 2D-PPC could detect multiple defects while reasonably increasing the area cost and latency. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

(57202596499); Teranishi, Takashi (8082593500); Ueno, Y. (57202215763)
Title: Commissioning of a portable ionization chamber at high counting rate using heavy ion beams
Source title: Journal of Radioanalytical and Nuclear Chemistry
Affiliations: Sungkyunkwan University, Seoul, South Korea; Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kwag, Minsik, Department of Physics, Sungkyunkwan University, Seoul, South Korea; Chae, Kyungyuk, Department of Physics, Sungkyunkwan University, Seoul, South Korea; Cha, Soomi, Department of Physics, Sungkyunkwan University, Seoul, South Korea; Duy, Nguyen Ngoc Dang, Department of Physics, Sungkyunkwan University, Seoul, South Korea, Institute of Research and Development, Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Iribe, Kotaro, Department of Physics, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Kim, Duhyun, Department of Physics, Sungkyunkwan University, Seoul, South Korea; Kim, Minjae, Department of Physics, Sungkyunkwan University, Seoul, South Korea; Oka, S., Department of Physics, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Teranishi, Takashi, Department of Physics, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Ueno, Y., Department of Physics, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan
Abstract: A fast ionization chamber with a high counting rate was commissioned at the 8 MV tandem accelerator complex of Kyushu University in Japan. Heavy ion beams consisting of 12C and 16O with E<inf>beam</inf> = 36 MeV were used to investigate the detector performance. By using various beam intensities ranging from 103 to 106 particles per second (pps), the maximum counting rate of the ion counter was measured to be about 8 × 105 pps. The detector performance under different gases was also investigated using two common gases in the ionization chamber: isobutane and P-10 gases. The results show that the negative effects due to pileups, which are often observed at high counting rates, can be greatly reduced when P-10 gas is used. © 2019 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: K., Nakarai, Kenichiro; Y., Suzuki, Yuji; M., Mori, Masanobu; L.S., Ho, Lanh Si; A., Arai, Akira; Y., Kobayashi, Yusuke
Author full names: Nakarai, Kenichiro (15726047100); Suzuki, Yuji (55508447700); Mori, Masanobu (7404717723); Ho, Lanh Si (57191583880); Arai, Akira (57206510246); Kobayashi, Yusuke (55507734800)
Title: Physicomechanical properties and durability of a new lightweight porous mortar utilizing woodchips
Affiliations: Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan; Gunma University, Maebashi, Japan; Kochi University, Kochi, Japan; Đại học Công nghệ Giao thông vận tải, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kobayashi Kogyou, Inc., Maebashi, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nakarai, Kenichiro, Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering, Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan; Suzuki, Yuji, Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering, Gunma University, Maebashi, Japan; Mori, Masanobu, Faculty of Science and Technology, Kochi University, Kochi, Japan; Ho, Lanh Si, Đại học Công nghệ Giao thông vận tải, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Arai, Akira, Kobayashi Kogyou, Inc., Maebashi, Japan; Kobayashi, Yusuke, Kobayashi Kogyou, Inc., Maebashi, Japan
Abstract: To contribute towards sustainability and cleaner production, we experimentally investigated the basic physicomechanical properties of a new porous mortar containing Japanese cedar woodchips and evaluated its durability by one-year immersion tests in ion-exchanged water and sodium chloride solution. The lightweight woodchip-containing porous mortar has high water and gas absorptivity, in addition to high skid resistance and high durability against calcium leaching. Calcium-leaching-induced strength reduction was not significant because it was compensated by strength increases from additional cement hydration in water during immersion tests. © 2019 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: D.T., Nguyen, Duc Tuyen; K., Goshome, Kiyotaka; N., Endo, Naruki; T., Maeda, Tetsuhiko
Author full names: Nguyen, Duc Tuyen (58279068400); Goshome, Kiyotaka (55191355100); Endo, Naruki (26664442300); Maeda, Tetsuhiko (8913022600)
Title: Optimization strategy for high efficiency 20 kW-class direct coupled photovoltaic-electrolyzer system based on experiment data
Affiliations: National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Duc Tuyen, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Goshome, Kiyotaka, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan; Endo, Naruki, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan; Maeda, Tetsuhiko, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan
Abstract: For the first time worldwide, the PEM electrolyzer directly coupled with the up-to-20 kW PV panels to produce hydrogen is reported as a demonstration of a high solar-to-hydrogen (STH) efficiency CO<inf>2</inf>-free hydrogen-production system. With the direct-coupling configuration, the power loss on an interlink DC/DC converter and its cost are avoided as known. Since the maximum power point (MPP) of PV unit is fluctuated by the fluctuating irradiance, this MPP is tracked by changing the number of the electrolyzer cell controlled by the MPPT algorithm, which allows changing the PV operating voltage. In our system, the averaged PV efficiency is 17.2%, and the electrolysis efficiency is 86.5% in a whole-day test. Thus, the STH efficiency is 14.9%. The hydrogen generation capacity of 18.6 Nm3 (5.01 kg CO<inf>2</inf> reduction) is demonstrated in that whole-day test. Besides, the method to make the simulation model of the system from on-site data is shown. As a result, neither the preliminary test nor off-site test is needed. Therefore, this method can be used to check the condition of the entire system and each component in long-term operation which has never been found in the literature. The simulated model can also be used to investigate the PV-electrolyzer system. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: D.C., Huong, D. C.; H.V., Thanh, Huynh Van; G.M.T., Nguyen, Gia Minh Thao
Author full names: Huong, D. C. (8247212600); Thanh, Huynh Van (57215292610); Nguyen, Gia Minh Thao (55903864900)
Title: Design of functional interval observers for a battery and motor circuit model of electric vehicle
Affiliations: Quy Nhon University, Quy Nhon, Viet Nam; Deakin University, Geelong, Australia; Toyota Technological Institute, Nagoya, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Huong, D. C., Department of Mathematics, Quy Nhon University, Quy Nhon, Viet Nam; Thanh, Huynh Van, School of Engineering, Deakin University, Geelong, Australia; Nguyen, Gia Minh Thao, Research Center for Smart Vehicles and Electromagnetic Energy System Lab, Toyota Technological Institute, Nagoya, Japan
Abstract: In this paper we first establish a model of battery and motor circuit for electric vehicle (EV). We then consider the problem of estimating linear functions of the state vector of this model. We design two novel observers to estimate the set of admissible values for linear functions of the state vector at each instant of time. Conditions for the existence of the linear functional interval observers are given and an effective algorithm for computing unknown observer matrices is presented. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: L., Sang, Lequang; T., Maeda, Takao; Y., Kamada, Yasunari
Author full names: Sang, Lequang (57194508528); Maeda, Takao (7404540215); Kamada, Yasunari (7102943566)
Title: Study effect of extreme wind direction change on 3-bladed horizontal axis wind turbine
Source title: International Journal of Renewable Energy Development
Affiliations: Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Mie University, Tsu, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sang, Lequang, Institute of Energy Science, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Maeda, Takao, Division of Mechanical Engineering, Mie University, Tsu, Japan; Kamada, Yasunari, Division of Mechanical Engineering, Mie University, Tsu, Japan
Abstract: The Horizontal Axis Wind Turbines (HAWT) are used very popular in the world. They were installed mainly on land. However, on the land, the wind regime change is very complex such as high turbulence and constantly changing wind direction. In the International Electrotechnical Commission (IEC) 61400-1 standard, the wind regime is devided into the normal wind conditions and the extreme wind conditions. This study will focus on the extreme wind direction change and estimate the aerodynamic forces acting on a 3-bladed HAWT under this condition. Because the extreme wind direction change may cause extreme loads and it will affect the lifetime of HAWTs. This issue is experimented in the wind tunnel in Mie University, Japan to understand these effects. The wind turbine model is the 3-bladed HAWT type and using Avistar airfoil for making blades. A 6-component balance is used to measure the forces and the moments acting on the entire wind turbine in the three directions of x, y and z-axes. This study estimates the load fluctuation of the 3-bladed wind turbine under extreme wind direction change. The results show that the yaw moment and the pitch moment under the extreme wind direction change fluctuate larger than the normal wind condition. Specifically, before the sudden wind direction change happened, the averaged maximum pitch moment MX is-1.78 Nm, and after that MX is 4.45 Nm at inrush azimuth of 0°. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: M.H., Giang, Mai Huong; B.H., Trung, Bui Huy; Y., Yoshida, Yuichiro; T.D., Xuan, T. D.; M.T., Que, Mai Thanh
Author full names: Giang, Mai Huong (57205122281); Trung, Bui Huy (57205121125); Yoshida, Yuichiro (35331125200); Xuan, T. D. (7003473828); Que, Mai Thanh (57205116080)
Title: The causal effect of access to finance on productivity of small and medium enterprises in Vietnam
Affiliations: Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan; Banking Academy of Vietnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Giang, Mai Huong, Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan, Banking Academy of Vietnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Trung, Bui Huy, Banking Academy of Vietnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam, School of Social Sciences, Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan; Yoshida, Yuichiro, Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan; Xuan, T. D., Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan; Que, Mai Thanh, Banking Academy of Vietnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: In many developing countries, obtaining financial services at affordable rates and fair terms has been a significant challenge for small and medium enterprises (SMEs). However, this issue has not been paid much attention in Vietnam, even though SMEs account for about 95% of total enterprises and the financial market of the country has not been well developed. This study investigates the causal effects of access to finance on productivity of SMEs operating in the manufacturing sector in Vietnam. Productivity was measured as the total factor productivity (TFP) obtained by production function estimation using the Levinsohn and Petrin approach. Regarding financial accessibility, two factors covered the extent to which firms might have a bank loan or overdraft facility were employed. To study the causal inferences of access to finance on firm productivity, the research adopted the difference-in-differences (DID) approach, as well as the propensity score matching (PSM) coupled with DID technique. The empirical results indicated that improving the financial accessibility could directly enhance firm productivity. Particularly, it was shown that firms having access to a bank loan could significantly improve TFP by approximately 8.6% in the DID model and about 9% in the PSM-DID model. Meanwhile, the firm average TFP increased by approximately 12.3% and 15.7% in simple DID and PSM-DID models, respectively, when firms had an overdraft facility. These findings suggest that the government should put more effort into assisting SMEs in generating bankable projects, and create a sound and healthy financial environment to stimulate firms' access to finance, which will ensure their sustainability and growth. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H.N., Tran, Hoai Nam; V.K., Hoang, Van Khanh; P.H., Liem, Peng Hong; H.T., Hoang, Hung T.P.
Author full names: Tran, Hoai Nam (15926474700); Hoang, Van Khanh (57190619015); Liem, Peng Hong (6603970138); Hoang, Hung T.P. (57200636569)
Title: Neutronics design of VVER-1000 fuel assembly with burnable poison particles
Affiliations: Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Vietnam Atomic Energy Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tokyo City University, Tokyo, Japan; Nippon Advanced Information Service, Naka, Japan; Vietnam Atomic Energy Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Tran, Hoai Nam, Institute of Fundamental and Applied Sciences, Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Hoang, Van Khanh, Vietnam Atomic Energy Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Liem, Peng Hong, Cooperative Major in Nuclear Energy, Tokyo City University, Tokyo, Japan, Scientific Computational Division, Nippon Advanced Information Service, Naka, Japan; Hoang, Hung T.P., Nuclear Training Center, Vietnam Atomic Energy Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: This paper presents neutronics design of VVER-1000 fuel assembly using burnable poison particles (BPPs) for controlling excess reactivity and pin-wise power distribution. The advantage of using BPPs is that the thermal conductivity of BPP-dispersed fuel pin could be improved. Numerical calculations have been conducted for optimizing the BPP parameters using the MVP code and the JENDL-3.3 data library. The results show that by using Gd<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> particles with the diameter of 60 μm and the packing fraction of 5%, the burnup reactivity curve and pin-wise power distribution are obtained approximately that of the reference design. To minimize power peaking factor (PPF), total BP amount has been distributed in a larger number of fuel rods. Optimization has been conducted for the number of BPP-dispersed rods, their distribution, BPP diameter and packing fraction. Two models of assembly consisting of 18 BPP-dispersed rods have been selected. The diameter of 300 μm and the packing fraction of 3.33% were determined so that the burnup reactivity curve is approximate that of the reference one, while the PPF can be decreased from 1.167 to 1.105 and 1.113, respectively. Application of BPPs for compensating the reduction of soluble boron content to 50% and 0% is also investigated. © 2019 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Burnable Poison; Burnup Reactivity; Fuel Assembly; Power Peaking Factor; Vver-1000

Authors: H.X., Nguyen, Hieu Xuan; T., Tsuji, Takao
Author full names: Nguyen, Hieu Xuan (57197779463); Tsuji, Takao (35354735900)
Title: Multi-layer Reactive Power Control of Solar Photovoltaic Systems in MV Distribution Network
Affiliations: Yokohama National University, Yokohama, Japan; Vietnam National University of Agriculture, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Hieu Xuan, Yokohama National University, Yokohama, Japan, Vietnam National University of Agriculture, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tsuji, Takao, Yokohama National University, Yokohama, Japan
Abstract: The growing penetration of photovoltaic (PV) systems in distribution networks causes various power quality issues e.g. voltage rise, network losses. To deal with the overvoltage, inverter-based reactive power contribution is one of the most commonly proposed approaches. However, using standard strategies with fixed droop parameters limits the control effectiveness. Moreover, much reactive power absorbed by PVs around noon might increase the network loss, overload the substation consequently, especially in the network with long distribution feeders. In this paper, a combined centralized and local control method is proposed with the suggestion of multilayer structure. Droop parameters of local control are updated every 15 min by centralized control to minimize reactive power flow through substation while keeping voltages in permitted levels. By avoiding overloading substation, more PV generation can be added to the feeder. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Reading habits, socioeconomic conditions, occupational aspiration and academic achievement in Vietnamese junior high school students
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Education, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnam Academy for Ethnic Minorities, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Thai Nguyen University of Education, Thai Nguyen, Viet Nam; Duc Trong High School, Lam Dong, Viet Nam; Sciences Po Paris, Paris, France; Foreign Trade University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; The Vietnam National Institute of Educational Sciences, Hoan Kiem district, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hanoi Amsterdam High School for the Gifted, Cau Giay district, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Ritsumeikan Asia Pacific University, Beppu, Japan; Phenikaa University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Phenikaa University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Université Libre de Bruxelles, Brussels, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Hien, Le Thi Thu, Faculty of Pedagogy, Hanoi University of Education, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Trung, Tran, Faculty of Basic, Vietnam Academy for Ethnic Minorities, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Thao, Trinh Thi Phuong, Department of Mathematics, Thai Nguyen University of Education, Thai Nguyen, Viet Nam; Thanh, Nguyen Chi, Faculty of Pedagogy, Hanoi University of Education, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Thuy Phuong Tram, Duc Trong High School, Lam Dong, Viet Nam; Vuong, Thu Trang, Sciences Po Paris, Paris, France; Vu, Thi Hanh, School of Economics and International Business, Foreign Trade University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Quynh, Dieu, The Vietnam National Institute of Educational Sciences, Hoan Kiem district, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vuong, Ha My, Hanoi Amsterdam High School for the Gifted, Cau Giay district, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hoang, Phuong Hanh, The Vietnam National Institute of Educational Sciences, Hoan Kiem district, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: Reading practices play an important role in the learning process of students. Especially in a fast-changing world where knowledge about nature and society is in a constant state of flux, book reading helps students foster skills such as thinking, valuing, adaptability and creativity for sustainable development. This research study used a dataset of 1676 observations of junior high school students from Northern Vietnam to explore students' academic achievement and its association with their reading passion, family socio economic condition, parental education and occupational aspiration. The empirical results show that higher grades in STEM-related subjects are predicted by reading interest (β<inf>Readbook</inf> = 0.425, p < 0.0001), with students who love reading books achieve higher score than those who take no interest in books. Remarkably, the education level of the mother strongly enhances academic performance, with β = 0.721 (p < 0.0001) in cases of mother having a university diploma or higher. Students coming from wealthy families are more likely to buy books whereas borrowing from the library is the main source of books for students who grow up in not-rich families. However, even among wealthy families, investment into buying books still rely more on personal interest, despite the aforementioned educational benefits of book reading, as evidenced by an over 7 percentage point disparity between the likelihood of purchasing books among wealthy-family students who took an interest in reading (45%) versus students of the same background who did not like to read (38.7%). The results present implications for education policy making with a vision towards United Nations' Sustainable Development Goal 4: Quality Education. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Methane bi-reforming over boron-doped Ni/SBA-15 catalyst: Longevity evaluation
Affiliations: Universiti Malaysia Pahang Al-Sultan Abdullah, Pekan, Malaysia; Dại học Nguyen Tat Thanh, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Hochiminh City University of Natural Resources and Environment (HCMUNRE), Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Toyohashi University of Technology, Toyohashi, Japan; King Abdulaziz City for Science and Technology, Riyadh, Saudi Arabia; Universiti Malaysia Pahang Al-Sultan Abdullah, Pekan, Malaysia

Abstract: A highly active and stable boron-promoted catalyst was successfully prepared by using the sequential incipient wetness impregnation technique and examined for methane bi-reforming reaction. The initial investigation found that the NiO and B<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> particles were dispersed on the outer surface of the high surface area SBA-15 support. In addition, the catalytic activity was increased linearly with the tested reaction temperature due to the endothermic nature of the reaction. In fact, the catalyst achieved the CH<inf>4</inf> conversion and H<inf>2</inf>/CO molar ratio of approximately 67.3% and 2.7, respectively at 1073 K. The resulting product ratio is highly suitable for downstream Fischer-Tropsch (FT) synthesis. The B-promoted catalyst showed the lowest degree of catalyst deactivation (4%) at 1023 K. Additionally, the XPS measurements unveiled that the boron facilitates the adsorption of CO<inf>2</inf> by donating electrons to the neighbouring Ni cluster and thus improved its catalytic performance. Furthermore, Raman and XRD analysis revealed that the boron promotion on 10%Ni/SBA-15 could prevent the reoxidation and deposition of carbonaceous species. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: M.T., Nguyen, Minh Tri; D.H., Le, Duong H.; T., Nakajima, Takuma; M., Yoshimi, Masato; N., Thoai, Nam

Title: Attention-based neural network: A novel approach for predicting the popularity of online content
Affiliations: Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Service Strategy Sector, Tokyo, Japan; TIS Inc., Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Minh Tri, Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Le, Duong H., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nakajima, Takuma, Service Strategy Sector, Tokyo, Japan; Yoshimi, Masato, Strategic Technology Center, TIS Inc., Tokyo, Japan; Thoai, Nam, Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Abstract: Since the rate at which new content is uploaded to the Internet has reached unprecedented marks, knowing the popularity of online content, especially video, is of importance for network management, recommendation schemes, service design, advertising planning, and so on. Despite the fact that various models have been developed, few of them address the short-term popularity prediction. Toward this goal, we exploit the self-attention mechanism of the Transformer, a state-of-the-art model in neural machine translation, to forecast the values of multiple time series in the near future. Specifically, we propose an attention-based non-recursive neural network, a novel model that entirely dispenses with recurrence and convolutions, for time series prediction. Since our model is the combination of the input attention mechanism in the dual-stage attention-based recurrent neural network (DA-RNN) and the self-attention of Transformer, it is able to adaptively select the most relevant input sequences as well as capture the long-term dependencies across previous time steps to make the prediction. The experiments show the root mean square errors (RMSEs) achieved by our model are only 6.06 and 3.60 when testing on the NASDAQ 100 dataset and the views count of the top most popular videos on Youtube respectively, while the RMSEs of DA-RNN are 8.52 and 12.31. Hence, our model outperforms the baseline not only in time series prediction but also in contents popularity prediction aspect. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Abstract: Book reading is an important factor contributing to children's cognitive development and education for sustainable development. However, in a developing country like Vietnam, statistics have reported a low figure in book reading: only 1.2 books a year. This research study used a dataset of 1676 observations of junior high school students from Northern Vietnam to explore students' reading behavior and its association with demographic factors, and the family's reading culture. Data analysis suggests the older the student gets, the less inclined they are to read, and being female and having hobbies of low sensory stimulation are linked to higher preference for reading. Regarding scholarly culture at home, students who read more varied types of books and spend more time on books are correlated with higher reading interest. Reading habits are also positively reinforced by the capacity to access books and parental book reading. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: The Performance Characteristics of TCP with Network Coding in Power Line Communication Network
Affiliations: University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Kyushu Institute of Technology, Kitakyushu, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ha, Nguyen Viet, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Kyushu Institute of Technology, Kitakyushu, Japan; van Hau, Le, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Thao Nguyen, Tran Thi, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tsuru, Masato M.T., Kyushu Institute of Technology, Kitakyushu, Japan
Abstract: Transmission Control Protocol with Network Coding (TCP/NC) has been a potential proposal to improve the transmission performance of TCP in lossy networks while it still takes advantage of congestion and retransmission control of TCP for reliable end-To-end data transfer. TCP/NC uses additional sub-layer called Network Coding layer below the TCP layer to handle packet losses without sensed by the TCP layer. In our previous work, we introduced some variants of TCP/NC such as TCP/NCwLRLBE (TCP/NC with Loss Rate and Loss Burstiness Estimation) which can improve the retransmission and adapt to the changing of the channel. However, it is just evaluated on the simple packet loss conditions, e.g., random loss or Gilbert loss. On the other hand, reliable end-To-end data transfer in diverse IoT (Internet of Things) environments (e.g., Power Line Communication-PLC) in a cost-efficient manner is an emerging challenge. Therefore, in this paper, we investigate the characteristics of the TCP/NC on PLC networks, to have a more in-depth evaluation of its performance and applicability in a practical PLC environment with many conditions causing packet loss such as noise variants, distance, etc. The result of our simulation on ns-3 (Network Simulation 3) shows that TCP/NC can work well on PLC environment compared to the traditional protocols such as TCP NewReno with Selective Acknowledgment (SACK) and TCP Westwood+. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Study of secondary implantation of radioisotopes during alpha-particle irradiation
Source title: Journal of Radioanalytical and Nuclear Chemistry
Affiliations: Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Magyar Tudomanyos Akademia, Budapest, Hungary; RIKEN Nishina Center for Accelerator-Based Science, Wako, Japan; Hokkaido University, Sapporo, Japan; Hokkaido University, Sapporo, Japan; Hokkaido University, Sapporo, Japan

Abstract: This work presents the recoil and secondary implantation of radioisotopes at different bombarding energies in the range of ~ 13 to ~ 40 MeV by using an α-particle beam of 50 MeV irradiating a stack of Ag, Ni and Ti metal foils. Activation cross-sections for the produce radioisotopes were calculated and confronted with literature data. The implanted activity is presented as a function of the primary beam energy for six produced radioisotopes 57Ni, 57Co, 65Zn, 51Cr, 48V and 46Sc. The use of each of these radioisotopes in engineering experiments based on the nano-thin layer activation is discussed. © 2019 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: A., Kimura, Atsushi; S., Nakamura, Shoji; K., Terada, Kazushi; T., Nakao, Taro; K., Mizuyama, Kazuhito; N., Iwamoto, Nobuyuki; O., Iwamoto, Osamu; H., Harada, Hideo; T., Katabuchi, Tatsuya; M., Igashira, Masayuki
Author full names: Kimura, Atsushi (7402711846); Nakamura, Shoji (55468288600); Terada, Kazushi (55974075300); Nakao, Taro (35299781700); Mizuyama, Kazuhito (8895133100); Iwamoto, Nobuyuki (35899912400); Iwamoto, Osamu (7004878937); Harada, Hideo (16197087500); Katabuchi, Tatsuya (23392432900); Igashira, Masayuki (22961715700)
Title: Measurements of the 243 Am neutron capture and total cross sections with ANNRI at J-PARC
Source title: Journal of Nuclear Science and Technology
Affiliations: Japan Atomic Energy Agency, Kashiwa, Japan; Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Institute for Integrated Radiation and Nuclear Science, Kyoto University, Sennan, Japan; Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Nagoya University, Nagoya, Japan; Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kimura, Atsushi, Nuclear Science and Engineering Center, Japan Atomic Energy Agency, Kashiwa, Japan; Nakamura, Shoji, Nuclear Science and Engineering Center, Japan Atomic Energy Agency, Kashiwa, Japan; Terada, Kazushi, Nuclear Science and Engineering Center, Japan Atomic Energy Agency, Kashiwa, Japan, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Nakao, Taro, Nuclear Science and Engineering Center, Japan Atomic Energy Agency, Kashiwa, Japan, Nagoya University, Nagoya, Japan; Mizuyama, Kazuhito, Nuclear Science and Engineering Center, Japan Atomic Energy Agency, Kashiwa, Japan, Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Iwamoto, Nobuyuki, Nuclear Science and Engineering Center, Japan Atomic Energy Agency, Kashiwa, Japan; Iwamoto, Osamu, Nuclear Science and Engineering Center, Japan Atomic Energy Agency, Kashiwa, Japan; Harada, Hideo, Nuclear Science and Engineering Center, Japan Atomic Energy Agency, Kashiwa, Japan; Katabuchi, Tatsuya, Institute of Innovative Research, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Igashira, Masayuki, Institute of Innovative Research, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Neutron total and capture cross sections of 243 Am have been measured in Accurate Neutron Nucleus Reaction measurement Instrument at Materials and Life Science Experimental Facility of Japan Proton Accelerator Research Complex with a neutron time-of-flight (TOF) method. The neutron capture cross section in the energy region from 10 meV to 100 eV was determined using an array of Ge detectors. Three samples with different activities were used for measurements of the capture cross section. The neutron total cross section in the energy region from 4 meV to 100 eV was measured using Li-glass detectors. Derived cross-section value at neutron energy of 0.0253 eV is 87:7 ± 5:4 b for the capture cross section and 101±11 b for the total cross section. © 2019 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: C., Phan, Chianh; H., Nguyen, Hathu; H.A., Nguyen, Hao Anh; Y., Matsui, Yoshiki
Author full names: Phan, Chianh (36998615600); Nguyen, Hathu (57201549194); Nguyen, Hao Anh (57202683836); Matsui, Yoshiki (7402827345)
Title: Effect of total quality management practices and jit production practices on flexibility performance: Empirical evidence from international manufacturing plants
Affiliations: Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Graduate School of International Social Sciences, Yokohama, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Phan, Chianh, School of Business Administration, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Hathu, School of Business Administration, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Hao Anh, Department of Business Administration, Graduate School of International Social Sciences, Yokohama, Japan; Matsui, Yoshiki, Department of Business Administration, Graduate School of International Social Sciences, Yokohama, Japan
Abstract: This paper presents the results of an empirical study investigating the relationship between Total quality management (TQM) practices, Just-in-time (JIT) production practices, and flexibility performance in manufacturing companies. Correlation and regression analysis are applied to analyze the data collected from 280 manufacturing plants in 12 countries including China, Finland, German, Italy, Israel, Japan, Korea, Spain, Sweden, Taiwan, United Kingdom, and Vietnam from 2013 to 2015 in the framework of a High Performance Manufacturing Project. The analytical results confirm the closed linkage between TQM, JIT production practices and flexibility performance. Moreover, this study indicates that the effect of JIT production practices on flexibility performance can be strengthened with a higher level of TQM practices. The main findings of this study suggest that flexibility performance can be built up by implementing both TQM and JIT production practices, and TQM should be regarded as the platform to maximize the effect of JIT production on flexibility performance. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.D., Hong, Thong Duc; O., Fujita, Osamu; T.H., Soerawidjaja, Tatang Hernas; I.K., Reksowardojo, Iman Kartolaksono
Author full names: Hong, Thong Duc (55894466300); Fujita, Osamu (7004673028); Soerawidjaja, Tatang Hernas (6505685589); Reksowardojo, Iman Kartolaksono (6507227091)
Title: Soot formation of dodecane, aviation bio-paraffins and their blends with propylbenzene in diffusion flames
Affiliations: Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Hokkaido University, Sapporo, Japan; Institut Teknologi Bandung, Bandung, Indonesia; Institut Teknologi Bandung, Bandung, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Hong, Thong Duc, Department of Automotive Engineering, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Division of Mechanical and Space Engineering, Hokkaido University, Sapporo, Japan; Fujita, Osamu, Division of Mechanical and Space Engineering, Hokkaido University, Sapporo, Japan; Soerawidjaja, Tatang Hernas, Department of Chemical Engineering, Institut Teknologi Bandung, Bandung, Indonesia; Reksowardojo, Iman Kartolaksono, Combustion Engines and Propulsion Systems Laboratory, Institut Teknologi Bandung, Bandung, Indonesia
Abstract: Co-annular smoke-free laminar diffusion wick-fed flames of dodecane, aviation bio-paraffins and each blended with various amounts of propylbenzene of 10, 20, 25 vol% have been used to study soot formation. A light extinction method is adopted to determine the total soot volume (TSV) as a function of flame height and fuel mass consumption rate (FMCR). The empirical models have been built to predict TSVs of dodecane/propylbenzene (Do/PB) mixtures and aviation bio-paraffins/propylbenzene (Bio-P/PB) mixtures as the function of two variables of FMCR and concentration of propylbenzene content (%PB). TSVs of Do/PB mixtures and Bio-P/PB mixtures increase with increasing flame height, FMCR and %PB. The effect of flame height, FMCR and %PB on soot formation are respectively expressed as the quadratic, power law and linear functions. At low FMCRs, Bio-P/PB mixtures produce a slightly higher TSV than Do/PB mixtures. In contrast, at high FMCRs, the soot formations of Do/PB mixtures are slightly higher than those of their corresponding counterparts. The differences are argued to be mainly due to the remainder of a small amount of oxygenates in the bio-paraffins. It may be concluded that the aviation bio-paraffins are very similar to dodecane in respect to soot formation. © 2019 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

(57202923547); Nguyen, Mai (57226701470); Nguyen, Quyen Thi (57205940116); Nguyen, Anh Duc (59192896700); Dieu Thuy, Ung Thi (59158272700); Truong, Quang Duc (41361850100); Tung, Nguyen Thanh (7004175503); Nguyen, Liem Quang (54585822300); Tran, Phong Dinh (18435066600)
Title: Structure and electrochemical property of amorphous molybdenum selenide H2-evolving catalysts prepared by a solvothermal synthesis
Affiliations: Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hung Yen University of Technology and Education, Khoai Chau District, Viet Nam; Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Materials Science, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Chuc T., Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Hung Yen University of Technology and Education, Khoai Chau District, Viet Nam; Duong, Tuan M., Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Mai, Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Materials Science, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Quyen Thi, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Anh Duc, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Dieu Thuy, Ung Thi, Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Materials Science, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Truong, Quang Duc, Institute of Multidisciplinary Research for Advanced Materials, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Tung, Nguyen Thanh, Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Materials Science, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Liem Quang, Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Materials Science, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tran, Phong Dinh, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: Amorphous molybdenum selenide nanoparticles were synthesized by the solvothermal treatment of Mo(CO)<inf>6</inf> and Se in dimethylformamide. By varying the Mo(CO)<inf>6</inf> over Se molar ratio, we obtained a family of MoSe nanoparticles having comparable morphology but different chemical composition. Using a combination of experimental analyses (e.g. XRD, ICP-MS, Raman, XPS)and DFT theoretical calculation, we found that the structure of MoSe was close to that of the amorphous molybdenum sulfide analogous but not that of MoSe<inf>2</inf> layers. The MoSe was found to consist of [Mo<inf>3</inf>Se<inf>13</inf>]2- cluster within its structure together with some structural defects. Thanks to its less ordered structure, the MoSe can be activated by several chemical and electrochemical treatment resulting in a catalytic enhancement. A treatment with fuming HCl resulted in generation of a novel catalyst displaying 1.4 time higher catalytic current. Remarkably, a treatment with reflux NaOH solution resulted in generation of a component being soluble in water and displaying catalytic H<inf>2</inf>-evolving activity at a moderate onset overpotential of ca. 200 mV, being one of the most attractives homogeneous catalysts in water. © 2019 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: D.D., Nguyen, Duy Dinh; K., Yukita, Kazuto
Author full names: Nguyen, Duy Dinh (57190812356); Yukita, Kazuto (6603216799)
Title: A soft-starting method for Dual Active Bridge Converters
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Aichi Institute of Technology, Toyota, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Duy Dinh, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Yukita, Kazuto, Aichi Institute of Technology, Toyota, Japan
Abstract: This paper deal with current stress during the starting time of Dual-Active-Bridge DC/DC converters. The cold-starting method and the popular soft-starting technique using Dual-Phase-Shifts (DPS) are firstly analyzed. Accordingly, mathematics equations to identify the current stress are derived. Based on that a new method is proposed that preserves the minimum current stress of the former method, whereas reduces the starting time. Experimental results confirm that current stress is reduced 40% compared to that of cold-starting method; and the starting time is shorten by 12.5% compared to that obtained by DPS method with the same current stress. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: P., van Mao, Pham; T., Arima, Tatsumi; Y., Inagaki, Yaohiro; K., Idemitsu, Kazuya
Author full names: van Mao, Pham (57210750784); Arima, Tatsumi (7203063732); Inagaki, Yaohiro (7202954138); Idemitsu, Kazuya (7004513119)
Title: Evaluation of mechanical properties of (Ce,Gd)O2-x as a surrogate for (U,Gd)O2-x solid solutions
Affiliations: Tâp Doàn Diên lúc Viêtnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: van Mao, Pham, Tâp Doàn Diên lúc Viêtnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Arima, Tatsumi, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Inagaki, Yaohiro, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Idemitsu, Kazuya, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan
Abstract: The mechanical properties of CeO2-Gd2O3 solid solutions as a surrogate for UO2-Gd2O3 burnable poison fuel were evaluated by both experimental and molecular dynamics (MD) analyses. Surface observation and X-ray diffraction measurement showed that Gd2O3 doping into CeO2 depressed the grain size of CeO2-Gd2O3 solid solution and caused the expansion of the lattice parameter up to 15 wt% of Gd2O3 content. The mechanical properties were estimated from the sound velocities measured by the ultrasonic pulse-echo method. The sound velocities in CeO2-Gd2O3 were found to decrease with increasing Gd2O3 content, which caused the reduction in the elastic moduli and Debye temperature. On the other hand, the results obtained from MD analyses showed the lattice expansion of CeO2-Gd2O3, the decrease of the average nearest distance between Ce (or Gd) and O ions, and the decrease of oxygen coordination number around each cation while the Gd2O3 content was increasing. It was, therefore, found that the bond valence sum considered to be the effective cation charge slightly decreased with increasing Gd2O3 content. Thus, the crystal binding energy decreased and consequently, the elastic moduli decreased. In addition, the lower value of experimental elastic moduli may be partly caused by crystal imperfection, e.g. grain boundaries, pores, and cracks. © 2019 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T., Arima, Tatsumi; J., Miyachi, Junpei; M., van Pham, Mao; Y., Inagaki, Yaohiro; K., Idemitsu, Kazuya
Author full names: Arima, Tatsumi (7203063732); Miyachi, Junpei (57210744418); van Pham, Mao (57210743275); Inagaki, Yaohiro (7202954138); Idemitsu, Kazuya (7004513119)
Title: Evaluation of melting behavior in the system UO2-ZrO2: Molecular dynamics simulation
Affiliations: Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Tâp Doàn Diên lúc Viêtnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Arima, Tatsumi, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Miyachi, Junpei, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; van Pham, Mao, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan, Tâp Doàn Diên lúc Viêtnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Inagaki, Yaohiro, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Idemitsu, Kazuya, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan
Abstract: Melting point of UO<inf>2</inf> was evaluated by four calculation methods of molecular dynamics simulation. Comparing with the one-phase simulation, the melting point obtained by the two-phase simulation was closer to the experimental value and was almost constant with respect to the size of supercell. In the surface melting simulation, the melting points of supercells with (100) and (110) surfaces were the almost same, however, that obtained for the supercell with (111) surface was higher than others. Using the nanocrystal UO<inf>2</inf> with Wulff shape, the volume dependence of melting point was evaluated. As a result, the melting point increased with the volume of nanocrystal and was lower than those obtained by other simulation methods. Two-phase simulation technique was applied to the evaluation of melting points of UO<inf>2</inf>-ZrO<inf>2</inf> solid solutions. The mixing UO<inf>2</inf> and ZrO<inf>2</inf> caused a small instability of a crystal phase, therefore, the fusion enthalpy and melting point of solid solution decreased with an increase of ZrO<inf>2</inf> content up to 60-80 mol%. Above that content, the melting point increased again. © 2019 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: D., Kobayashi, Daiki; H., Ohtake, Hideaki; K., Takemoto, Koji; V., Hoang, Vietnguyen; T., Masuta, Taisuke
Author full names: Kobayashi, Daiki (57194462738); Ohtake, Hideaki (55469287600); Takemoto, Koji (57209256660); Hoang, Vietnguyen (57196803511); Masuta, Taisuke (24178442100)
Title: Reliability and Economic Efficiency in Power System with PV Considering Import Fuel Price Transition
Affiliations: Meijo University, Nagoya, Japan; National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Kobayashi, Daiki, Meijo University, Nagoya, Japan; Ohtake, Hideaki, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan; Takemoto, Koji, Meijo University, Nagoya, Japan; Hoang, Vietnguyen, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Masuta, Taisuke, Meijo University, Nagoya, Japan
Abstract: In conventional power systems, large power sources such as thermal, hydro, and nuclear power plants supply the vast majority of the electricity. However, in future power systems, the installed capacities of renewable energy sources such as wind power and photovoltaic generation (PV) systems will increase, and these sources will supply a large volume of electricity. The potentially frequent occurrence of supply-demand imbalances in future power systems is a concern. Therefore, coordinated operation with supply-demand balancing between large power sources and renewable energy sources is necessary. In this study, we focus on operation with supply-demand balancing and PV generation, considering both economic efficiency and reliability. We evaluate the impact of import fuel price transitions on supply and demand in a future power system (for the assumed period of 2030-2050) in which a large PV generation source is installed. We conducted numerical simulations on a bulk power system model. We consider both the import fuel price and PV-generation installed capacity as parameters. © 2019 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: D.D., Nguyen, Duy Dinh; K., Yukita, Kazuto; G., Fujita, Goro; C.M., Ta, Cao Minh
Author full names: Nguyen, Duy Dinh (57190812356); Yukita, Kazuto (6603216799); Fujita, Goro (36186886000); Ta, Cao Minh (36851849900)
Title: A simple DC bias elimination technique for Dual-Active-Bridge DC/DC converters
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Aichi Institute of Technology, Toyota, Japan; Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Duy Dinh, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan; Yukita, Kazuto, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Fujita, Goro, Aichi Institute of Technology, Toyota, Japan; Ta, Cao Minh, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: A new and simple DC bias elimination technique for a Dual-Active-Bridge DC/DC converter is proposed in this paper. The principle is to make the positive and negative volt-seconds of the magnetizing inductance balance when the phase shift changes. This can be done with minimum disruption on the overall control system by some minor modifications on the setting of the PWM modules of the digital signal processor. Thanks to the technique, the DC bias is completely eliminated. Besides, the system dynamics is much improved. © 2019 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: N.K., Trung, Nguyen Kien; K., Akatsu, Kan
Author full names: Trung, Nguyen Kien (57188632923); Akatsu, Kan (6602843024)
Title: Design challenges for 13.56MHz 10 kW resonant inverter for wireless power transfer systems
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Trung, Nguyen Kien, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Akatsu, Kan, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: This paper presents the design process of a 13.56 MHz 10 kW and high efficiency inverter for wireless power transfer systems. The main challenges that are the effect of the parasitic components, the using of the high-speed switching devices and the inverter topology are discussed. Finally, an optimal design of 10kW inverter using E-mode GaN is shown with the efficiency of over 95%. © 2019 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: N., Vichet, Nguon; K.D., Kawamura, Kensuke D.; D.P., Trong, Dung Phan; N., van On, Nguyen; Z., Gong, Zhe; J., Lim, Jihyun; S., Khom, Sok; C., Bunly, Chhun
Author full names: Vichet, Nguon (57210565104); Kawamura, Kensuke D. (8599559800); Trong, Dung Phan (56698103200); van On, Nguyen (57210559922); Gong, Zhe (55790119600); Lim, Jihyun (57208385873); Khom, Sok (57210552114); Bunly, Chhun (57210563528)
Title: MODIS-based investigation of flood areas in southern Cambodia from 2002–2013
Affiliations: Cambodia National Mekong Committee, Phnom Penh, Cambodia; Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan; Japan International Research Center for Agricultural Sciences, Tsukuba, Japan; Hanoi Urban Planning Institute (HUPI)–Hanoi People’s Committee (HPC), Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnam National University of Forestry, Hanoi, Viet Nam; National Agriculture and Food Research Organization, NARO, Tsukuba, Japan; Ministry of Environment, Phnom Penh, Cambodia
Authors with affiliations: Vichet, Nguon, Cambodia National Mekong Committee, Phnom Penh, Cambodia, Graduate School for International Development and Cooperation, Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan; Kawamura, Kensuke D., Japan International Research Center for Agricultural Sciences, Tsukuba, Japan; Trong, Dung Phan, Graduate School for International Development and Cooperation, Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan, Department of Strategy Development for Urban and Rural zone, Hanoi Urban Planning Institute (HUPI)–Hanoi People’s Committee (HPC), Hanoi, Viet Nam; van On, Nguyen, Graduate School for International Development and Cooperation, Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan, College of Landscape Architecture and Interior Design, Vietnam National University of Forestry, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Gong, Zhe, Graduate School for International Development and Cooperation, Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan; Lim, Jihyun, Graduate School for International Development and Cooperation, Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan, Western Region Agricultural Research Center, National Agriculture and Food Research Organization, NARO, Tsukuba, Japan; Khom, Sok, Cambodia National Mekong Committee, Phnom Penh, Cambodia; Bunly, Chhun, Ministry of Environment, Phnom Penh, Cambodia
Abstract: In Cambodia and the Vietnamese Mekong Delta, floods commonly occur during the rainy season, and a better understanding of their spatio-temporal distribution is important for both disaster prevention and the improvement of agricultural production. This study investigated spatio-temporal flood inundation and land cover change from 2002 to 2013 in the southern part of Cambodia using Terra satellite on-board Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) images. The algorithm for flood inundation detection, WFFI (Wavelet-based Filter for detecting spatio-temporal changes in Flood Inundation) was used, and the parameters were modified to fit the present study. The estimated inundation areas were validated using eight Landsat images. In a comparison between the original and modified WFFIs, the modified WFFI (70–96%) exhibited better accuracy than the original WFFI (30–70%). Overall, the temporal change in the flood inundation area presented a decreasing trend, and a link to the in-situ observed water level showed a decreasing trend during the rainy season. Furthermore, the estimated flood inundation exhibited a significant delay since 2008. Based on the yearly land cover MODIS product, the permanent water body and wetland areas decreased, whereas the cropland areas increased. This was as a result of increased agricultural productivity. However, water shortage was the major obstacle to increasing agricultural productivity, and it also had a negative impact on aquatic ecology, such as fish spawning grounds. © 2019 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Environmental Monitoring; Flooding; Natural Disaster; Satellite Remote Sensing

Authors: V., Doan, Vanquang; H., Kusaka, Hiroyuki; N.M., Truong, Nguyen Minh
Author full names: Doan, Vanquang (57203166987); Kusaka, Hiroyuki (7006355697); Truong, Nguyen Minh (31067566000)
Title: Roles of past, present, and future land use and anthropogenic heat release changes on urban heat island effects in Hanoi, Vietnam: Numerical experiments with a regional climate model
Affiliations: University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Doan, Vanquang, Center for Computational Sciences, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Kusaka, Hiroyuki, Center for Computational Sciences, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Truong, Nguyen Minh, Department of Meteorology, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: This study investigates the roles of land-use cover (LUC) and anthropogenic heat (AH) on the past, present, and future urban heat island (UHI) effect over the megapolitan area of Hanoi, Vietnam. We use a dynamical downscaling method with a regional climate model coupled with an urban canopy scheme to run sensitivity simulations with LUC and AH data from 1990, 2010, and 2030. The LUC data in 1990 and 2010 are derived from remote sensing data, whereas the LUC data for 2030 come from the city's master plan. The AH data are estimated from past and projected energy-use conditions. The results show that the LUC-AH coupled changes during 2010–2030 will have much greater impact on the local UHI effect than those during 1990–2010. In the urban-core area, the monthly mean surface air temperature in July is predicted to increase by 0.7 °C by 2030, double the increase of 0.35 °C during 1990–2010. We show that the temperature increase during 1990–2010 is mostly due to the change in LUC conditions, but the increase in the future AH will contribute 30–50% to the total temperature increase in the urban areas. © 2019 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: B.H., Nguyen, Bao H.; T., Okimoto, Tatsuyoshi
Author full names: Nguyen, Bao H. (57192897175); Okimoto, Tatsuyoshi (25225934800)
Title: Asymmetric reactions of the US natural gas market and economic activity
Affiliations: University of Economics Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; The Australian National University, Canberra, Australia; Research Institute of Economy, Trade and Industry, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Bao H., School of Economics, University of Economics Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Okimoto, Tatsuyoshi, Crawford School of Public Policy, The Australian National University, Canberra, Australia, Research Institute of Economy, Trade and Industry, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: This paper provides new empirical evidence on the asymmetric reactions of the US natural gas market and US economy to its market fundamental shocks. We find that results based on a smooth transition vector autoregressive (STVAR) model provides a plausible and robust explanation to the behavior of the US natural gas market, which asymmetrically reacts in bad times and good times. During times of recession, natural gas production shrinks in response to a positive oil price shock, while the corresponding response is found to be positive in times of expansion. The positive relationship between the price of natural gas and crude oil is found to be more prominent in expansions, especially in the long run. In addition, the results also reveal that US economic activity is much more sensitive to oil and natural gas price shocks occurring in bad times than in good times. © 2019 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Abstract: A flexible paper-structured catalyst (PSC) that can be applied to the anode of a solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC) was examined for its potential to enable direct internal reforming (DIR) operation. The catalytic activity of three types of Ni-loaded PSCs: (a) without the dispersion of support oxide particles in the fiber network (PSC-A), (b) with the dispersion of (Mg,Al)O derived from hydrotalcite (PSC–B), and (c) with the dispersion of (Ce,Zr)O<inf>2-δ</inf> (PSC–C), for dry reforming of CH<inf>4</inf> was evaluated at operating temperatures of 650–800 °C. Among the PSCs, PSC-C exhibited the highest CH<inf>4</inf> conversion with the lowest degradation rate. The electrochemical performance of an electrolyte-supported cell (ESC) was evaluated under the flow of simulated biogas at 750 °C for cases without and with the PSCs on the anode. The application of the PSCs improved the cell performance. In particular, PSC-C had a remarkably positive effect on stabilizing DIRSOFC operation fueled by biogas. © 2019 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: N.N., Nguyen, Ngoc Nhu; P.T., Nham, Phong Tuan; Y., Takahashi, Yoshi
Author full names: Nguyen, Ngoc Nhu (57204128017); Nham, Phong Tuan (55351748400); Takahashi, Yoshi (58438748000)
Title: Relationship between ability-based emotional intelligence, cognitive intelligence, and job performance
Affiliations: Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Ngoc Nhu, Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan; Nham, Phong Tuan, School of Business Administration, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Takahashi, Yoshi, Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan
Abstract: Based on previous findings, which found that the three facets of ability-based emotional intelligence (EI) have varying effects on job performance, this study investigates the relationship between emotional intelligence, cognitive intelligence (CI), and job performance. The use of a cascade model suggests a progressive pattern, starting from emotion perception, followed by emotional understanding and emotion regulation, with downstream effects on job performance. Considering the advantages and disadvantages of both measurements, we employed the performance-based ability measurement, the Mayer-Salovey-Caruso Emotional Intelligence Test (MSCEIT) and the self-reporting ability EI measurement, Wong Law Emotional Intelligence Scale (WLEIS). Our findings supported the cascade model, but in the case of WLEIS measures, both self-emotion appraisal and others' emotion appraisal precede emotion regulation, leading to a positive effect on job performance. Moreover, CI moderated the relationship between EI and job performance, such that a decline in CI rendered the relationship more positive. The MSCEIT and WLEIS showed similar results, thus supporting the cascading model and moderating effects. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: M.H., Nguyen, Minh Hoang; S.K., Meirmanov, Serik K.; T.T., Vuong, Thu Trang; M., Ho, Manhtung
Author full names: Nguyen, Minh Hoang (57205713877); Meirmanov, Serik K. (6507462505); Vuong, Thu Trang (57193856945); Ho, Manhtung (57196438315)
Title: Internationalization and its discontents: Help-seeking behaviors of students in a multicultural environment regarding acculturative stress and depression
Affiliations: Ritsumeikan Asia Pacific University, Beppu, Japan; Ritsumeikan Asia Pacific University, Beppu, Japan; Sciences Po Paris, Paris, France; Phenikaa University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Phenikaa University, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Minh Hoang, International Cooperation Policy, Ritsumeikan Asia Pacific University, Beppu, Japan; Meirmanov, Serik K., Department of Public Health Management, Ritsumeikan Asia Pacific University, Beppu, Japan; Vuong, Thu Trang, Campus Européen de Dijon, Sciences Po Paris, Paris, France; Ho, Manhtung, Centre for Interdisciplinary Social Research, Phenikaa University, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Faculty of Economics and Business, Phenikaa University, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: Stress and depression can be seen as the major obstacles for sustained education and attainment of foreign students, and in turn, the sustainability of an education system as a whole. However, the mainstream consideration following Berry's model on acculturation does not take into account whether students of the host countries are immune to these problems. This study aims to examine the prevalence and predictors of help-seeking behaviors among international and domestic students in a multicultural environment by employing ANOVA and polynomial regression. Some significant results from this study are: (1) Informal sources were the most prevalent sources of help-seeking among international and domestic students, while formal help-seeking was not popular; (2) international students were more likely to overcome emotional difficulties alone and seek help on the Internet than domestic students; (3) acculturative stress was a positive predictor of formal, informal, and miscellaneous help-seeking behaviors among international students and informal help-seeking behaviors or among domestic students; and (4) depression was negatively correlated with the willingness of international students to seek help from informal sources. The findings hint at the risk of acculturative stress faced by domestic students in a multicultural environment being overlooked and the lack of help-seeking sources for international students. The study also provides empirical evidence for policy-planners to design a sustainable education system better at supporting students dealing with depression and acculturative stress. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
