Authors: S., Singh, Sharanjit; M.B., Bahari, Mahadi B.; B.B., Abdullah, Bawadi Bin; T.T.P., Pham, Thi Thuy Phuong; Q.D., Truong, Quang Duc; D.V.N., Vo, Dai Viet N.; A.A., Adesina, Adesoji Adediran
Author full names: Singh, Sharanjit (57202164259); Bahari, Mahadi B. (57189077303); Abdullah, Bawadi Bin (36967979400); Pham, Thi Thuy Phuong (56038451400); Truong, Quang Duc (41361850100); Vo, Dai Viet N. (35957358000); Adesina, Adesoji Adediran (35564888500)
Title: Bi-reforming of methane on Ni/SBA-15 catalyst for syngas production: Influence of feed composition
Affiliations: Universiti Malaysia Pahang Al-Sultan Abdullah, Pekan, Malaysia; Universiti Teknologi PETRONAS, Seri Iskandar, Malaysia; Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Dại học Nguyen Tat Thanh, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; ATODATECH LLC, Brentwood, United States
Authors with affiliations: Singh, Sharanjit, Faculty of Chemical and Natural Resources Engineering, Universiti Malaysia Pahang Al-Sultan Abdullah, Pekan, Malaysia; Bahari, Mahadi B., Faculty of Chemical and Natural Resources Engineering, Universiti Malaysia Pahang Al-Sultan Abdullah, Pekan, Malaysia; Abdullah, Bawadi Bin, Department of Chemical Engineering, Universiti Teknologi PETRONAS, Seri Iskandar, Malaysia; Pham, Thi Thuy Phuong, Institute of Chemical Technology, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Truong, Quang Duc, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan, Ceramics and Biomaterials Research Group, Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Vo, Dai Viet N., Faculty of Chemical and Natural Resources Engineering, Universiti Malaysia Pahang Al-Sultan Abdullah, Pekan, Malaysia, Dại học Nguyen Tat Thanh, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Adesina, Adesoji Adediran, ATODATECH LLC, Brentwood, United States
Abstract: Bi-reforming of methane (BRM) was evaluated for Ni catalyst dispersed on SBA-15 support prepared by hydrothermal technique. BRM reactions were conducted under atmospheric condition with varying reactant partial pressure in the range of 10–45 kPa and 1073 K in fixed-bed reactor. The ordered hexagonal mesoporous SBA-15 support possessing large specific surface area of 669.5 m2 g−1 was well preserved with NiO addition during incipient wetness impregnation. Additionally, NiO species with mean crystallite dimension of 14.5 nm were randomly distributed over SBA-15 support surface and inside its mesoporous channels. Thus, these particles were reduced at various temperatures depending on different degrees of metal-support interaction. At stoichiometric condition and 1073 K, CH<inf>4</inf> and CO<inf>2</inf> conversions were about 61.6% and 58.9%, respectively whilst H<inf>2</inf>/CO ratio of 2.14 slightly superior to theoretical value for BRM would suggest the predominance of methane steam reforming. H<inf>2</inf> and CO yields were significantly enhanced with increasing CO<inf>2</inf>/(CH<inf>4</inf> + H<inf>2</inf>O) ratio due to growing CO<inf>2</inf> gasification rate of partially dehydrogenated species from CH<inf>4</inf> decomposition. Additionally, a considerable decline of H<inf>2</inf> to CO ratio from 2.14 to 1.83 was detected with reducing H<inf>2</inf>O/(CH<inf>4</inf> + CO<inf>2</inf>) ratio due to dominant reverse water-gas shift side reaction at H<inf>2</inf>O-deficient feedstock. Interestingly, 10%Ni/SBA-15 catalyst was resistant to graphitic carbon formation in the co-occurrence of H<inf>2</inf>O and CO<inf>2</inf> oxidizing agents and the mesoporous catalyst structure was still maintained after BRM. A strong correlation between formation of carbonaceous species and catalytic activity was observed. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: V.H., Tu, Vo Hong; N., Can, Nguyenduy; Y., Takahashi, Yoshifumi; M., Yabe, Mitsuyasu
Author full names: Tu, Vo Hong (56941663800); Can, Nguyenduy (55962233000); Takahashi, Yoshifumi (57190179860); Yabe, Mitsuyasu (7005872026)
Title: Water Use Efficiency in Rice Production: Implications for Climate Change Adaptation in the Vietnamese Mekong Delta
Source title: Process Integration and Optimization for Sustainability
Affiliations: Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tu, Vo Hong, Department of Rural Socio-Economics, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Can, Nguyenduy, Department of Rural Socio-Economics, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Takahashi, Yoshifumi, Department of Agricultural and Resource Economics, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Yabe, Mitsuyasu, Department of Agricultural and Resource Economics, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan
Abstract: Water scarcity and competition in the Vietnamese Mekong Delta becomes a great matter of concern under the contexts of climate change and tributary dam construction in upstream countries. Moreover, water productivity or water use efficiency in rice production was quite low in the region due to free-rider problem. Therefore, the study was aimed at measuring water use efficiency at farm level and investigating the factors affecting water use efficiency. The study applied stochastic frontier analysis to estimate water use efficiency for 159 rice farmers in the upstream of the Vietnamese Mekong Delta. The study shows that the average water use efficiency was 18.81%, indicating that rice farmers did consume water very inefficiently. On the average, the rice farmers could reduce their water consumption about 81.19%, keeping their output level and other inputs constant. To improve water use efficiency, the study found that land accumulation or large-scaled production is essential. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Real-Time Lossless Compression of Waveforms Using an FPGA
Affiliations: The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; High Energy Accelerator Research Organization, Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; Institute of High Energy Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China; Institute for Basic Science, Daejeon, Daejeon, South Korea; Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Truong, N. M., The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Aoki, Masaharu, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Igarashi, Youichi, High Energy Accelerator Research Organization, Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Saito, Masatoshi, High Energy Accelerator Research Organization, Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Ito, Shintaro, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; Nagao, D., The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Nakatsugawa, Yohei, High Energy Accelerator Research Organization, Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan, Institute of High Energy Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China; Natori, Hiroaki, High Energy Accelerator Research Organization, Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan, Institute for Basic Science, Daejeon, Daejeon, South Korea; Seiya, Yoshihiro, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Teshima, Natsuki, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan
Abstract: High-energy physics experiments must usually handle large transfer rates of experimental data. In particular, in recent years, the amount and speed of data handled in high-energy physics experiments have significantly increased, because signal waveforms from detectors are often recorded without reduction to maximize the flexibility of the offline analysis. To best exploit the available bandwidth of such data acquisition systems with waveform recording, we developed the real-time lossless waveform-compression firmware that is based on a delta-encoding technique. The firmware provides a compression ratio of 34% of the raw data produced, the fast analog-to-digital converter (FADC) boards of our application before transmission to a host computer. The resource consumption of a field-programmable gate array (FPGA) is not large, and a low-cost mid-range FPGA is sufficient to implement this proposed firmware. The firmware has been successfully implemented on an FADC board and was utilized to record signals from multiwire proportional chambers for the DeeMe experiment. In this paper, we present the theory related to the firmware design and its implementation on the FPGA. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Abstract: Optical properties of core-shell-shell Au@SiO<inf>2</inf>@Au nanostructures and their solar energy harvesting applications are theoretically investigated using Mie theory and heat-transfer equations. The theoretical analysis associated with size-dependent modification of the bulk gold dielectric function agrees well with previous experimental results. We use the appropriate absorption cross section to determine the solar energy absorption efficiency of the nano-heterostructures, which is strongly structure-dependent, and to predict the time-dependent temperature increase of the nanoshell solution under simulated solar irradiation. Comparisons to prior temperature measurements and theoretical evaluation of the solar power conversion efficiency are discussed to provide new insights into underlying mechanisms. Our approach would accelerate materials and structure testing in solar energy harvesting. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T., Masuta, Taisuke; D., Kobayashi, Daiki; N.H., Viet, Nguyen Hoang; H., Ohtake, Hideaki
Author full names: Masuta, Taisuke (24178442100); Kobayashi, Daiki (57194462738); Viet, Nguyen Hoang (57520268700); Ohtake, Hideaki (55469287600)
Title: Annual evaluation of supply-demand with BESS charging/discharging schedule and uc updating based on intraday forecasted pv power outputs
Affiliations: Meijo University, Nagoya, Japan; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Masuta, Taisuke, Meijo University, Nagoya, Japan; Kobayashi, Daiki, Meijo University, Nagoya, Japan; Viet, Nguyen Hoang, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Ohtake, Hideaki, Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan
Abstract: In recent years, photovoltaic (PV) systems have been installed in Japan at an accelerated rate. The application of PV generation forecasts and the utilization of energy storage devices in power system operation are essential to reduce supply-demand imbalances and enable the use of more PV energy without curtailment. In this paper, assuming extremely high PV generation after 2030, we focus on the coordinated operation of a battery energy storage system (BESS) and conventional power plants. We propose a method of determining and updating the BESS charging/discharging schedule and generator unit commitment based on the day-ahead and intraday PV generation forecasts. We present an evaluation of this method based on the results of numerical simulations conducted for one year on a bulk power system model to demonstrate the effectiveness with which it reduces energy shortfall and PV power curtailment. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H.T.H., Quynh, Hoang Thi Huong; K., Shima, Kazuto
Author full names: Quynh, Hoang Thi Huong (57189041907); Shima, Kazuto (25230727500)
Title: Title "organic fertilizers" in Vietnam's markets: Nutrient composition and efficacy of their application
Affiliations: Vietnam Institute of Meteorology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Okayama University, Okayama, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Quynh, Hoang Thi Huong, Hydrology and Climate Change, Vietnam Institute of Meteorology, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Department of Environmental Ecology, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; Shima, Kazuto, Department of Environmental Ecology, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan
Abstract: Organic fertilizers have recently been gaining popularity; however, their governance is not completely assessed in developing countries. This study investigated the nutrient composition of so-called organic fertilizers in Vietnam's markets and issues related to their production, and evaluated their potential to contaminate the groundwater. We analyzed the physicochemical properties of 12 domestic and four imported products of the fertilizers, and conducted a cultivation experiment in sandy soil with the fertilizer applied at a rate of 200 mg N kg-1 soil using an automatic watering apparatus in a greenhouse. We further studied the production of an "organic fertilizer" from coffee by-products. The nutrient content greatly varied among domestic products, whereas they were quite similar among imported products. The product packaging of the collected samples lacked information regarding raw materials. Two thirds of the domestic products contained over 30% of the total N in the inorganic form, implying that the N content dramatically increased in the fertilizers rather than in their supposed raw materials. The stages involved in the production were composting, the addition of extra soil as a bulking agent, and the mixing-in of chemical substances to increase the nutrient content before packing. The remarkably high ratio of inorganic N to total N was attributed to excessive N leaching from soil by the application of domestic fertilizers. These results suggested the need for quality criteria guidelines for organic fertilizers in Vietnam that underline not only nutrient levels, but also the control of raw materials and production process of compost, because they are closely related to nutrient uptake and the leaching loss of nutrients. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: A.T.T., Le, Anh Tu Thi; T., Kasahara, Tamao; V., Vudhivanich, Varawoot
Author full names: Le, Anh Tu Thi (57216040475); Kasahara, Tamao (15032885000); Vudhivanich, Varawoot (6603501119)
Title: Seasonal variation and retention of ammonium in small agricultural streams in central Thailand
Affiliations: Faculty of Environment and Resource Studies, Mahidol University, Nakhon Pathom, Thailand; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Kasetsart University, Kamphaeng Saen Campus, Kamphaeng Saen, Thailand
Authors with affiliations: Le, Anh Tu Thi, Faculty of Environment and Resource Studies, Mahidol University, Nakhon Pathom, Thailand, Center for Environmental Fluid Dynamics, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kasahara, Tamao, Laboratory of Ecosystem Management, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Vudhivanich, Varawoot, Department of Irrigation Engineering, Kasetsart University, Kamphaeng Saen Campus, Kamphaeng Saen, Thailand
Abstract: Elevated nutrient concentrations are of concern in many agricultural streams. This study observed seasonal variation of inorganic nitrogen concentrations in small drainage streams that receive discharge predominantly from three different types of agricultural practices, swine farms, aquaculture, and paddy fields, in the Tha Chin River Basin in central Thailand. The drainage streams had high inorganic nitrogen concentrations, low dissolved oxygen concentrations (<3 mg L−1), and ammonium was the dominant form of inorganic nitrogen. The highest ammonium concentrations were observed in the drainage streams through swine farm areas, exceeding 4 mg L−1 throughout the year. In-stream ammonium retention was examined using pulse co-injections of ammonium and chloride in a drainage stream, and the effects of in-channel vegetation on ammonium retention were evaluated. This study showed that a considerable amount of ammonium was retained with the presence of in-channel vegetation. After vegetation removal, both the hydraulic and ammonium uptake length increased by >50 m, and the ammonium retention declined by approximately 50%. These results suggest that small agricultural streams experience a high concentration of inorganic nitrogen, similar or even more than larger streams, and that in-channel vegetation plays important role in nitrogen retention. The management of in-channel vegetation will have considerable effects on nitrogen transport. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Agricultural Streams; Ammonium Retention; Tracer Injection; Tropical Streams

Authors: G., Kumar, Gopalakrishnan; D.D., Nguyen, Dinh D.; P., Sivagurunathan, Periyasamy; T., Kobayashi, Takurou; K., Xu, Kaiqin; S., Chang, Soonwoong
Author full names: Kumar, Gopalakrishnan (7202418804); Nguyen, Dinh D. (55749243300); Sivagurunathan, Periyasamy (57050451800); Kobayashi, Takurou (55724307100); Xu, Kaiqin (55570728500); Chang, Soonwoong (8931821100)
Title: Cultivation of microalgal biomass using swine manure for biohydrogen production: Impact of dilution ratio and pretreatment
Affiliations: Yonsei University, Seoul, South Korea; Kyonggi University, Suwon, South Korea; Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; National Institute for Environmental Studies of Japan, Tsukuba, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kumar, Gopalakrishnan, School of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Yonsei University, Seoul, South Korea; Nguyen, Dinh D., Department of Environmental Energy Engineering, Kyonggi University, Suwon, South Korea; Sivagurunathan, Periyasamy, Green Energy Technology Research Group, Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Faculty of Environment and Labour Safety, Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Kobayashi, Takurou, Center for Material Cycles and Waste Management Research, National Institute for Environmental Studies of Japan, Tsukuba, Japan; Xu, Kaiqin, Center for Material Cycles and Waste Management Research, National Institute for Environmental Studies of Japan, Tsukuba, Japan; Chang, Soonwoong, Department of Environmental Energy Engineering, Kyonggi University, Suwon, South Korea
Abstract: This study assessed the impact of swine manure (SM) dilution ratio on the microalgal biomass cultivation and further tested for biohydrogen production efficiency from the mixed microalgal biomass. At first, various solid/liquid (S/L) ratio of the SM ranged from 2.5 to 10 g/L was prepared as a nutrient medium for the algal biomass cultivation without addition of the external nutrient sources over a period of 18 d. The peak biomass concentration of 2.57 ± 0.03 g/L was obtained under the initial S/L loading rates of 5 g/L. Further, the cultivated biomass was subjected to two-step (ultrasonication + enzymatic) pretreatment and evaluated for biohydrogen production potential. Results showed that the variable amount of hydrogen production was observed with different S/L ratio of the SM. The peak hydrogen yield of 116 ± 6 mL/g TS<inf>added</inf> was observed at the 5 g/L grown SM mixed algal biomass. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.T.V., Tran, Thi Tuong Vi; S., Kongparakul, Suwadee; P., Reubroycharoen, Prasert; G., Guan, Guoqing; M.H., Nguyen, Manh Huan; N., Chanlek, Narong; C., Samart, Chanatip
Author full names: Tran, Thi Tuong Vi (59269885600); Kongparakul, Suwadee (24074703800); Reubroycharoen, Prasert (6507272038); Guan, Guoqing (36026624000); Nguyen, Manh Huan (57188633416); Chanlek, Narong (24775167600); Samart, Chanatip (26436343700)
Title: Production of furan based biofuel with an environmental benign carbon catalyst
Affiliations: Thammasat University, Pathum Thani, Thailand; Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok, Thailand; Hirosaki University, Hirosaki, Japan; Vietnam Petroleum Institute, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Synchrotron Light Research Institute (SLRI), Nakhon Ratchasima, Thailand
Authors with affiliations: Tran, Thi Tuong Vi, Department of Chemistry, Thammasat University, Pathum Thani, Thailand; Kongparakul, Suwadee, Department of Chemistry, Thammasat University, Pathum Thani, Thailand; Reubroycharoen, Prasert, Department of Chemical Technology, Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok, Thailand; Guan, Guoqing, North Japan Research Institute for Sustainable Energy (NJRISE), Hirosaki University, Hirosaki, Japan; Nguyen, Manh Huan, Petrovietnam Research and Development Center for Petroleum Processing, Vietnam Petroleum Institute, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Chanlek, Narong, Synchrotron Light Research Institute (SLRI), Nakhon Ratchasima, Thailand; Samart, Chanatip, Department of Chemistry, Thammasat University, Pathum Thani, Thailand
Abstract: A sulfonated carbon material was developed and investigated as an environmentally benign catalyst for furfural production. The sulfonic acid functionality was introduced by sequential hydrothermal carbonization and sulfonation of xylose. The morphology and textural properties were examined by scanning electron microscopy and N<inf>2</inf> sorption measurements, respectively. The presence of sulfonic acid on the surface was proven by both Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analysis. Meanwhile, the acid properties were studied using an NH<inf>3</inf>-TPD profile. Two different sulfonated carbons that was activated with KOH before sulfonation and one that was compared. The KOH-activated sulfonated carbon contained both a porous structure and a high sulfonic acid content that improved the furfural yield and selectivity by more than 50% compared to the nonactivated sulfonated carbon. The reusability of the catalyst was investigated by monitoring the furfural selectivity over several reaction cycles, and after the 3rd cycle, a reduction in the selectivity from 72 to 30% was observed. However, the acid-functionalized carbon could still be useful for furfural production due to its low environmental impact in both the preparation and disposal steps. © 2017 American Institute of Chemical Engineers Environ Prog, 37: 1455–1461, 2018. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Abstract: This study assessed the co-digestion of macro and microalgal biomass towards the improvement of hydrogen production. The red macroalgal biomass (Gelidium amansii) and green mixed microalgal biomass was mixed in a ratio of 8:2, with an initial substrate concentration of 10 g/L, and various amount of inoculum addition range from 3 to 15% (v/v) was evaluated to assess the feasible substrate to inoculum ratio for the effective co-digestion of the algal biomass. The results showed that the co-digestion with 6% inoculum addition provided the peak hydrogen yield of 45 mL/g dry biomass added with a high hydrogen content of 24% in the gas phase. The other tested conditions showed moderate hydrogen content in the range of 17–22%, respectively. These results suggest that anaerobic co-digestion of macro and microalgal biomass, with appropriate initial biomass loading (6%) is essential for enhanced hydrogen production. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author full names: Pham, Thanh Ngoc (57202194674); Sugiyama, Masahiro (57202755347); Muttaqien, Fahdzi (55646415100); Putra, Septia Eka Marsha (57202188430); Inagaki, Kouji (35513238700); Son, Dongoc (15837905600); Hamamoto, Yuji (23990614100); Hamada, Ikutaro (7005614511); Morikawa, Yoshitada (56042230400)
Title: Hydrogen Bond-Induced Nitric Oxide Dissociation on Cu(110)
Affiliations: The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Pham, Thanh Ngoc, Department of Precision Science and Technology, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Sugiyama, Masahiro, Department of Precision Science and Technology, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Muttaqien, Fahdzi, Department of Precision Science and Technology, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Putra, Septia Eka Marsha, Department of Precision Science and Technology, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Inagaki, Kouji, Department of Precision Science and Technology, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan, Elements Strategy Initiative for Catalysts and Batteries (ESICB), Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan; Son, Dongoc, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Hamamoto, Yuji, Department of Precision Science and Technology, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan, Elements Strategy Initiative for Catalysts and Batteries (ESICB), Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan; Hamada, Ikutaro, Department of Precision Science and Technology, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan, Elements Strategy Initiative for Catalysts and Batteries (ESICB), Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan; Morikawa, Yoshitada, Department of Precision Science and Technology, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan, Research Center for Ultra-Precision Science and Technology, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan, Elements Strategy Initiative for Catalysts and Batteries (ESICB), Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan
Abstract: We have studied the dissociation process of nitric oxide (NO) on Cu(110) and the influence of the hydrogen bond with water by means of density functional theory calculations. We have found that an upright NO adsorbed at a short-bridge site and a side-on NO at a hollow site connecting two short-bridge sites are the two most stable molecularly adsorbed states, and the latter is the precursor for the dissociation process. Various NO dissociation pathways under the influences of the hydrogen bonds with water have been investigated. We have found that hydrogen bonds efficiently reduce the activation energy of NO dissociation by the introductions of a water dimer to O and water dimers to both sides of the side-on NO, respectively. More importantly, the promoting effect of water molecules on NO dissociation is dominant only when one of water molecules in a water dimer forms a hydrogen bond with O of the side-on NO. Our results provide a physical insight into the promoting effect of hydrogen bonds with water, which may be helpful in improving the catalytic activity as well as designing novel catalysts for NO reduction. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Y., Lu, Yingching; N., Dimov, Nikolay; S., Okada, Shigeto; T.H., Bui, Thi Hang

Title: SnSb alloy blended with hard carbon as anode for na-ion batteries
Affiliations: Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; International Training Institute for Materials Science, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Lu, Yingching, Department of Chemical Engineering, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Dimov, Nikolay, International Institute for Carbon-Neutral Energy Research, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Okada, Shigeto, Institute for Materials Chemistry and Engineering, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Bui, Thi Hang, International Training Institute for Materials Science, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: SnSb binary alloys blended with reduced graphene oxide (SnSb/RGO) or mixtures of SnSb/RGO with hard carbon (SnSb/RGO+HC) were tested as anode materials for sodium-ion batteries. The presence of hard carbon in the SnSb/RGO+HC blend improves its cycle efficiency and rate performance substantially. The synergy between the SnSb/RGO and the hard carbon phase is explained by the buffer action of the hard carbon, preventing SnSb interparticle agglomeration during the repeated recharge cycles. The feasibility of SnSb alloy anode for sodium-ion batteries was confirmed in full cell configuration vs. Na<inf>3</inf>V<inf>2</inf>(PO<inf>4</inf>)<inf>2</inf>F<inf>3</inf> cathode. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: K.P., Nguyen, Khai Phuc; G., Fujita, Goro
Author full names: Nguyen, Khai Phuc (55596378500); Fujita, Goro (36186886000)
Title: Self-Learning Cuckoo search algorithm for optimal power flow considering tie-line constraints in large-scale systems
Affiliations: Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Khai Phuc, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Fujita, Goro, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: This study proposes the Self-Learning Cuckoo search algorithm (SLCSA) and applies it for solving optimal power flow problems in large-scale power systems. The proposed method is an improvement of the Cuckoo search algorithm by employing a new strategy to focus Cuckoo eggs on the global optima. Cuckoo eggs have to learn and modify themselves to enhance their performance. The learning strategy of Cuckoo eggs is also controlled by a learning factor to prevent the search engine falling into local optima. The proposed method is applied for solving optimal power flow problems to figure the effectiveness out. The aim of the problem is to determine the minimized fuel cost while satisfying equal and unequal operating constraints of elements. The proposed SLCSA is also evaluated the problem on three IEEE 57-, 118- and 300-bus systems. According to numerical results, the proposed method is more efficient than the conventional Cuckoo search algorithm and other compared algorithms in literature. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Cuckoo Search Algorithm; Optimal Power Flow; Teaching-learning Based Optimization; Tie-line Constraints

Title: Modeling the UO2 ex-AUC pellet process and predicting the fuel rod temperature distribution under steady-state operating condition
Affiliations: Institute for Technology of Radioactive and Rare Elements, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnam Atomic Energy Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Japan Atomic Energy Agency, Kashiwa, Japan; Korea Institute of Geoscience and Mineral Resources, Daejeon, South Korea

Abstract: Modeling uranium dioxide pellet process from ammonium uranyl carbonate - derived uranium dioxide powder (UO<inf>2</inf> ex-AUC powder) and predicting fuel rod temperature distribution were reported in the paper. Response surface methodology (RSM) and FRAPCON-4.0 code were used to model the process and to predict the fuel rod temperature under steady-state operating condition. Fuel rod design of AP-1000 designed by Westinghouse Electric Corporation, in these the pellet fabrication parameters are from the study, were input data for the code. The predictive data were suggested the relationship between the fabrication parameters of UO<inf>2</inf> pellets and their temperature image in nuclear reactor. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author full names: Tran, Ngoc Quang (57027039200); Bui, Viet Quoc (55602465800); Le, Hungminh (24332141100); Kawazoe, Yoshiyuki (57208764411); Lee, Hyoyoung (8557576700)
Title: Anion–Cation Double Substitution in Transition Metal Dichalcogenide to Accelerate Water Dissociation Kinetic for Electrocatalysis
Affiliations: Sungkyunkwan University, Seoul, South Korea; Sungkyunkwan University, Seoul, South Korea; Sungkyunkwan University, Seoul, South Korea; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tran, Ngoc Quang, Sungkyunkwan University, Seoul, South Korea, Department of Energy Science, Sungkyunkwan University, Seoul, South Korea; Bui, Viet Quoc, Sungkyunkwan University, Seoul, South Korea, Department of Chemistry, Sungkyunkwan University, Seoul, South Korea; Le, Hungminh, Division of Molecular Modeling, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Kawazoe, Yoshiyuki, New Industry Creation Hatchery Center, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Lee, Hyoyoung, Sungkyunkwan University, Seoul, South Korea, Department of Energy Science, Sungkyunkwan University, Seoul, South Korea, Department of Chemistry, Sungkyunkwan University, Seoul, South Korea
Abstract: Until now, many works have shown that the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) performance can be improved by anion or cation substitution into the crystal lattice of pyrite-structure materials. However, the synergistic effects of anion–cation double substitution for overall enhancement of the catalytic activity remains questionable. Here, the simultaneous incorporation of vanadium and phosphorus into the CoS<inf>2</inf> moiety for preparing 3D mesoporous cubic pyrite-metal Co<inf>1-</inf><inf>x</inf>V<inf>x</inf>SP is presented. It is demonstrated that the higher catalytic activity of CoS<inf>2</inf> after V incorporation can be primarily attributed to abundance active sites, whereas P substitution is responsible for improving HER kinetics and intrinsic catalyst. Interestingly, due to the synergistic effect of P–V double substitution, the 3D Co<inf>1-</inf><inf>x</inf>V<inf>x</inf>SP shows superior electrocatalysis toward the HER with a very small overpotential of 55 mV at 10 mA cm−2, a small Tafel slope of 50 mV dec−1, and a high turnover frequency of 0.45 H<inf>2</inf> s−1 at 10 mA cm−2, which is very close to commercial 20% Pt/C. Density functional theory calculation reveals that the superior catalytic activity of the 3D Co<inf>1-</inf><inf>x</inf>V<inf>x</inf>SP is contributed by the reduced kinetic energy barrier of rate-determining HER step as well as the promotion of the desorption H<inf>2</inf> gas process. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H.N.T., Le, Hanh Ngoc Thi; K., Imamura, Kiyoshi; M., Furuta, Masakazu; L., van Boi, Luu; Y., Maeda, Yasuaki
Author full names: Le, Hanh Ngoc Thi (57201462555); Imamura, Kiyoshi (57202410922); Furuta, Masakazu (7103086416); van Boi, Luu (6507028401); Maeda, Yasuaki (55797766600)
Title: Production of biodiesel from Vernicia Montana Lour. Oil using a co-solvent method and the subsequent evaluation of its stability during storage
Affiliations: Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; An Giang University, Long Xuyen City, An Giang, Viet Nam; Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Le, Hanh Ngoc Thi, Department of Quantum and Radiation Engineering, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan, Faculty of Education, An Giang University, Long Xuyen City, An Giang, Viet Nam; Imamura, Kiyoshi, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Furuta, Masakazu, Department of Quantum and Radiation Engineering, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; van Boi, Luu, Faculty of Chemistry, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Maeda, Yasuaki, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan
Abstract: The costs associated with the production of biodiesel fuel (BDF) are directly affected by the nature of the feedstock material and the methods used during the production process. In Southeast Asia, many non-edible oils are used to produce BDFs, as exemplified by the recent use of the non-edible oil derived from Vernicia montana Lour. in Laos and Vietnam for the production of BDF. In this work, we developed an improved procedure for the production of BDF from Vernicia montana oil consisting of 80.3%±0.5% α-eleostearic acid moiety (C18:3) using a co-solvent method. Furthermore, the stability of the BDF was evaluated based on its iodine value and unsaturated ester content. The optimized production conditions were determined to be as follows: methanol/oil molar ratio of 6:1, 1% (wt/wt) KOH, 20% (wt/wt) acetone as a co-solvent, and a reaction temperature of 40°C. Under these conditions, we achieved a BDF conversion efficiency of 99%±0.3% within 30 min of initiating the transesterification process. Notably, the BDF produced from Vernicia montana oil showed good stability to air at temperatures ≤30°C for 1 month, showing similar stability properties to the BDF produced from rapeseed oil. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: D.D., Nguyen, Duy Dinh; D.H., Nguyen, Dinh Hoa; T., Funabashi, Toshihisa; G., Fujita, Goro
Author full names: Nguyen, Duy Dinh (57190812356); Nguyen, Dinh Hoa (26024240100); Funabashi, Toshihisa (7005032678); Fujita, Goro (36186886000)
Title: Sensorless control of dual-active-bridge converter with reduced-order proportional-integral observer
Affiliations: Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Nagoya University, Nagoya, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Duy Dinh, Department of Electrical Engineering, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan, School of Electrical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Dinh Hoa, International Institute for Carbon-Neutral Energy Research (WPI-I2CNER), Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Funabashi, Toshihisa, Institute of Materials and Systems for Sustainability (IMaSS), Nagoya University, Nagoya, Japan; Fujita, Goro, Department of Electrical Engineering, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: When controlling a Dual-Active-Bridge (DAB) DC/DC converter, the high frequency terminal current is usually measured for use in the current feedback controller. In order to measure that current, a wide bandwidth sensor accompanied with high-speed amplifiers are required. Furthermore, a high Analog-to-Digital sampling rate is also necessary for sampling and processing the measured data. To avoid those expensive requirements, this paper proposes an alternative control method for the DAB converter. In the proposed method, the terminal current is estimated by a reduced-order proportional integral observer. A technique is also proposed to reduce the phase drift effect when the voltages at two terminals are not matched. Afterwards, a combined current feedforward-voltage feedback control system is developed to enhance the system dynamics and to regulate the output voltage. This control system needs only the information of the terminal voltages and no current sensor is required. Experimental results show that the observer can estimate the terminal current very quickly with the accuracy of more than 98%. In addition, the output voltage is well regulated with a fluctuation of less than 2.6% and a settling time of less than 6.5 ms in the presence of a 30% load change. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author full names: Nguyen, T. G.H. (57198024814); Tran, Dang Long (57194411330); Sakamoto, Mio (55787496100); Uchida, Tomomi (56555768200); Sasaki, Kazunari (24315284300); To, Thien Dien (57002659100); Doan, Duc Chanh Tin (24722859200); Dang, Chien Mau (54406655100); Shiratori, Yusuke (14525920400)
Title: Ni-loaded (Ce,Zr)O2–Δ-dispersed paper-structured catalyst for dry reforming of methane
Affiliations: Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, T. G.H., Department of Hydrogen Energy Systems, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Tran, Dang Long, International Research Center for Hydrogen Energy, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Sakamoto, Mio, International Research Center for Hydrogen Energy, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Uchida, Tomomi, International Research Center for Hydrogen Energy, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Sasaki, Kazunari, Department of Hydrogen Energy Systems, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan, International Research Center for Hydrogen Energy, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; To, Thien Dien, Institute for Nanotechnology (INT), Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Doan, Duc Chanh Tin, Institute for Nanotechnology (INT), Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Dang, Chien Mau, Institute for Nanotechnology (INT), Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Shiratori, Yusuke, Department of Hydrogen Energy Systems, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan, International Research Center for Hydrogen Energy, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan
Abstract: A paper-structured catalyst (PSC) for biogas reforming was prepared with the aim of improving coking tolerance. During the paper-making process using inorganic fibers, Ni-loaded (Ce,Zr)O<inf>2–δ</inf> particles were synthesized via co-precipitation and subsequent chemical reduction (on-paper synthesis). The effects of the CeO<inf>2</inf>/ZrO<inf>2</inf> weight ratio during preparation and the Ni loading amount on the catalytic activity for dry reforming of CH<inf>4</inf> were investigated at 750 °C. A Ni loading of 6 wt% with CeO<inf>2</inf>/ZrO<inf>2</inf> ≥ 1 led to stable CH<inf>4</inf> conversion of 85% without coking under a gas hourly space velocity of 3800 h−1. The oxygen storage capacity of the (Ce,Zr)O<inf>2–δ</inf> particles dispersed in the inorganic fiber network may contribute to the oxidation of carbonaceous species deposited on the catalyst surface. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: F.P., Mahdi, Fahad Parvez; P.M., Vasant, Pandian M.; M., Abdullah-Al-Wadud, M.; J., Watada, Junzo; V.P., Kallimani, Vish P.
Author full names: Mahdi, Fahad Parvez (57192376333); Vasant, Pandian M. (8948616300); Abdullah-Al-Wadud, M. (15130471800); Watada, Junzo (57189052014); Kallimani, Vish P. (24822536600)
Title: A quantum-inspired particle swarm optimization approach for environmental/economic power dispatch problem using cubic criterion function
Source title: International Transactions on Electrical Energy Systems
Affiliations: Universiti Teknologi PETRONAS, Seri Iskandar, Malaysia; University of Hyogo, Kobe, Japan; Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; King Saud University, Riyadh, Saudi Arabia; Universiti Teknologi PETRONAS, Seri Iskandar, Malaysia
Authors with affiliations: Mahdi, Fahad Parvez, Department of Fundamental and Applied Sciences, Universiti Teknologi PETRONAS, Seri Iskandar, Malaysia, Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Sciences, University of Hyogo, Kobe, Japan; Vasant, Pandian M., Department of Fundamental and Applied Sciences, Universiti Teknologi PETRONAS, Seri Iskandar, Malaysia, Modeling Evolutionary Algorithms Simulation and Artificial Intelligence, Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Abdullah-Al-Wadud, M., Department of Software Engineering, King Saud University, Riyadh, Saudi Arabia; Watada, Junzo, Department of Computer and Information Science, Universiti Teknologi PETRONAS, Seri Iskandar, Malaysia; Kallimani, Vish P., Department of Computer and Information Science, Universiti Teknologi PETRONAS, Seri Iskandar, Malaysia
Abstract: In electrical power dispatch problem, economic dispatch (ED) and environmental dispatch problems play a crucial part. Economic dispatch problem refers to the minimization of generation cost, where environmental dispatch problem refers to the minimization of emission of pollutants like CO<inf>2</inf>, SO<inf>2</inf>, and NO<inf>x</inf> from the power generation system. A quantum-inspired particle swarm optimization (QPSO) technique is presented in this paper to solve many-objective environmental economic dispatch (EED) problems. Emissions of CO<inf>2</inf>, SO<inf>2</inf>, and NO<inf>x</inf> are considered 3 different objectives, thus making it a 4-objective problem considering ED. Many-objective EED problems are defined by using a cubic criterion function, and a max/max price penalty factor is considered to convert all the objectives into a single objective to compare the final results with other well-known methods found in the literature like Lagrangian relaxation, particle swarm optimization, simulated annealing, and quantum-behaved bat algorithm. Quantum-inspired particle swarm optimization is implemented on a 6-unit system to solve many-objective EED problems, and at the same time, to show the effectiveness of QPSO in large systems, it is also implemented in a 26-unit power generation system for ED problem. The obtained results demonstrate and verify the effectiveness and robustness of QPSO to solve many-objective EED problems. This also shows that QPSO can effectively be implemented in such power dispatch problems. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H., Nomura, Hisako; N.B., Hong, Nguyen Bich; M., Yabe, Mitsuyasu
Author full names: Nomura, Hisako (35091443200); Hong, Nguyen Bich (56754720600); Yabe, Mitsuyasu (7005872026)
Title: Effective use and management of Kunisaki Peninsula Usa GIAHS long trail-A sustainable tourism model leading to regional development
Affiliations: Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Thai Nguyen University, Thai Nguyen, Viet Nam; Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nomura, Hisako, Center for Promotion of International Education and Research, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Hong, Nguyen Bich, Faculty of Economics, Thai Nguyen University, Thai Nguyen, Viet Nam; Yabe, Mitsuyasu, Department of Agricultural and Resource Economics, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan
Abstract: Despite increasing recognition of the importance of maintaining environmental public goods such as rural landscapes and their ecological systems, it remains challenging to implement a management system where the value of maintaining such public goods is reflected by a means of a support payment. We proposed a tourism model for the regional promotion of footpaths as the main axis in the "Agri-culture System" designated as part of the Globally Important Agricultural Heritage Systems (GIAHS). Applying a Contingent Valuation Method, we asked walkers how much they were willing to contribute to various GIAHS-related activities through volunteering in addition to the participation fee for the walk. We hypothesized that the diverse means and activities to support conservation would contribute to sustainable management of GIAHS. The research findings showed that walkers had options to choose which activity to support. For track maintenance, WTCL in volunteering is 4.23 days a year. In the case of walkers who had no options, their Willingness to Contribute in Labor (WTCL) by volunteering is 3.34 days a year. To link the regional resources used for tourism with GIAHS require their effective management and conservation. Thus, it is desirable to formulate a combined approach such as payments by users of the trails and contributions through volunteer activities. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: M., Nguyen, Minhhue; C., Phan, Chianh; Y., Matsui, Yoshiki
Author full names: Nguyen, Minhhue (58252089400); Phan, Chianh (36998615600); Matsui, Yoshiki (7402827345)
Title: Contribution of quality management practices to sustainability performance of Vietnamese firms
Affiliations: Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Graduate School of International Social Sciences, Yokohama, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Minhhue, Center for Business Administration Studies, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Department of Business Administration, Graduate School of International Social Sciences, Yokohama, Japan; Phan, Chianh, Center for Business Administration Studies, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Matsui, Yoshiki, Department of Business Administration, Graduate School of International Social Sciences, Yokohama, Japan
Abstract: This study seeks to investigate the relationship between quality management practices and sustainability performance as well as the moderating effects from quality management implementation timeline, type of industry, and firm size on this relationship. Data were collected from enterprises in Vietnam from July 2016 to March 2017. Based on a sample of 144 valid responses, empirical results indicate that quality management practices have mixed impacts on economic performance and environmental performance, while show positive impact on social performance. The results found four quality management practices that have significantly positive impact on sustainability performance: top management support for quality management, design for quality, quality data and reporting, and continuous improvement. These practices could be considered as critical quality management factors that significantly contribute to sustainability goals. Furthermore, the study found significant moderating effects of three contextual factors on the relationship between quality management practices and sustainability performance. The study enriches the literature on quality management and sustainability management, and offers some important insights into efficient allocation of resources to achieve sustainability goals. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T., van do, Tranvan; P.D., Trung, Phung Dinh; M., Yamamoto, Mamoru; O., Kozan, Osamu; N.T., Thang, Nguyen Toan; D.V., Thuyet, Dang Van; H.V., Thang, Hoang Van; N.T.T., Phuong, Nguyen Thi Thu; N.V., Khuong, Ninh Viet; N.V., Cam, Ngo Van
Author full names: van do, Tranvan (57200125221); Trung, Phung Dinh (57195927306); Yamamoto, Mamoru (9274833100); Kozan, Osamu (56145058200); Thang, Nguyen Toan (35768385400); Thuyet, Dang Van (57195933020); Thang, Hoang Van (57224480568); Phuong, Nguyen Thi Thu (57195927915); Khuong, Ninh Viet (57195932144); Cam, Ngo Van (57195929026)
Title: Aboveground biomass increment and stand dynamics in tropical evergreen broadleaved forest
Affiliations: Research Institute for Sustainable Humanosphere, Uji, Japan; Vietnamese Academy of Forest Sciences, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan; Vietnamese Academy of Forest Sciences, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnamese Academy of Forest Sciences, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: van do, Tranvan, Center for Exploratory Research on the Humanosphere, Research Institute for Sustainable Humanosphere, Uji, Japan, Silviculture Research Institute, Vietnamese Academy of Forest Sciences, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Trung, Phung Dinh, Silviculture Research Institute, Vietnamese Academy of Forest Sciences, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Yamamoto, Mamoru, Center for Exploratory Research on the Humanosphere, Research Institute for Sustainable Humanosphere, Uji, Japan; Kozan, Osamu, Center for Southeast Asian Studies, Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan; Thang, Nguyen Toan, Silviculture Research Institute, Vietnamese Academy of Forest Sciences, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Thuyet, Dang Van, Silviculture Research Institute, Vietnamese Academy of Forest Sciences, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Thang, Hoang Van, Vietnamese Academy of Forest Sciences, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Phuong, Nguyen Thi Thu, Silviculture Research Institute, Vietnamese Academy of Forest Sciences, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Khuong, Ninh Viet, Silviculture Research Institute, Vietnamese Academy of Forest Sciences, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Cam, Ngo Van, Tropical Forest Research Centre, Vietnamese Academy of Forest Sciences, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: Forest ecosystems can modify the atmospheric CO<inf>2</inf> through biomass accumulation mostly in tree stems with diameter at breast height (DBH) ≥ 10 cm. Aboveground biomass increment (ΔAGB), and changes in stand AGB, no. stems and basal area (BA) were calculated from mortality, recruitment, and growth data of tree stems in tropical evergreen broadleaved forest, Central Highland Vietnam. Data were derived from ten 1-ha permanent plots established in 2004, where all stems with DBH ≥ 10 cm were tagged, identified to species, and measured for DBH in 2004 and 2012. In an 8-year duration, the increment was 53 ± 10 stems ha–1, 7.8 ± 0.3 m2 ha–1 for BA and 86.0 ± 4.6 Mg ha–1 for AGB. The stem mortality rate was 0.9% year–1 and the stem recruitment rate was 2.2% year–1. Annual ΔAGB was 10.8 Mg ha–1 year–1, equaling to 5.4 Mg C ha–1 year–1. Of which, tree stems of 35–80 cm DBH classes accounted for 65%. The results indicated that the forest is in stage of carbon sequestration. Any disturbances causing death of 35–80 cm DBH tree stems will much reduce carbon sequestration capacity and it will take a long time for AGB to return to pre-disturbance stage. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: M.S., Asadi, Mohammad Sadegh; K.K., Rahman, Khalil Khalilur; Q.D., Ta, Q. D.; V., Ha, V.; H., Phuong, H.
Author full names: Asadi, Mohammad Sadegh (55050997700); Rahman, Khalil Khalilur (16231043600); Ta, Q. D. (57203415646); Ha, V. (57203411351); Phuong, H. (57203416712)
Title: Mitigating wellbore stability challenges of extended-reach drilling in overpressure and naturally fractured formations
Affiliations: Baker Hughes, a GE company, Houston, United States; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HUTECH, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Japan Vietnam Petroleum Company, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Asadi, Mohammad Sadegh, Baker Hughes, a GE company, Houston, United States; Rahman, Khalil Khalilur, Baker Hughes, a GE company, Houston, United States; Ta, Q. D., Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HUTECH, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Ha, V., Japan Vietnam Petroleum Company, Japan; Phuong, H., Japan Vietnam Petroleum Company, Japan
Abstract: When building a 1D geomechanical model for the Rang Dong field in Cuulong basin, offshore Vietnam, the rock structure was found to be very complex. In addition to inter-bedded shale and sand sequences in the overburden, there is an overpressured stratum immediately below and above the normally-pressured and highly fractured sandstones and volcanic rocks at the target depth. During the drilling of offset wells, multiple tight spots were experienced in the overburden. An inflow was detected in the volcanic rocks, and consequently the mud weight was increased in the deeper section of overpressured zone. Further, severe mud losses occurred in the underlying normally-pressured and highly fractured sandstones, and eventually stuck pipe was experienced. This study shows the development of a field-wide geomechanical model that is able to match all the drilling experiences in the offset wells. A geomechanical model was developed for the field in which in-situ stresses and rock mechanical properties were calibrated with field data and lab measurements. The model predicted different types of borehole failures such as breakouts and drilling-induced fractures that contributed to different types of wellbore instability events in existing wells. Analysis showed that drilling with a significantly high overbalance pressure in the fractured zone increased the risk of tool string differential sticking and stuck pipe. To investigate the root causes of dynamic mud losses in the fractured intervals with major intersecting faults, a Mohr-Coulomb friction sliding criterion was applied. The analysis showed that the majority of natural fractures and faults, which are oriented in the north-east and south-west (NE-SW) direction, are critically stressed and may become conduits for drilling fluid and cause mud losses. The geomechanical model was used to design a mud weight program for an upcoming well. This program was optimized to mitigate the issues experienced during drilling of the offset wells. The results of this study led to an optimized mud program to minimize shale breakouts in the overburden, control the risk of kicks in the overpressured zone, and reduce the risk of mud losses in the fractured formation. Additionally, an optimized casing program and the use of lower mud weight were recommended, with the addition of loss circulation material (LCM), to drill a highly deviated wellbore within the fractured formation. The drilling campaign of the planned well was successful with good drilling practices such as equivalent circulating density (ECD) control, good hole cleaning and use of the recommended mud weight programs and optimised drilling fluids suggested by this study. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T., van do, Tran; T., Sato, Tamotsu
Author full names: van do, Tran (35489346300); Sato, Tamotsu (7406979362)
Title: Toward carbon certificate in vietnam: Net ecosystem production and basic income for the local community
Affiliations: Research Institute for Sustainable Humanosphere, Uji, Japan; Vietnamese Academy of Forest Sciences, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Forestry and Forest Products Research Institute, Tsukuba, Japan
Authors with affiliations: van do, Tran, Research Institute for Sustainable Humanosphere, Uji, Japan, Silviculture Research Institute, Vietnamese Academy of Forest Sciences, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Sato, Tamotsu, Department of Forest Vegetation, Forestry and Forest Products Research Institute, Tsukuba, Japan
Abstract: In recent years, ecologists have focused on estimating Net Ecosystem Production (NEP) to understand the role of forests against increasing concentrations of CO<inf>2</inf> in the atmosphere, a major concern in researches and debates on global warming. This is due to the fact that NEP of a forest is the amount of carbon accumulated in a unit of area and time. This chapter discusses NEP in tropical broad-leaved forests of the Copia Natural Reserve, northwest Vietnam and the need for a carbon certificate to support the local community. Based on field research in northwest Vietnam, this chapter proposes a modified and easily applicable method for estimating NEP. Research results indicate that one hectare of secondary broad-leaved forest in Vietnam can accumulate 6.57 Mg C y−1, more than twice that of old-growth forest at 2.57 Mg C y−1. Research suggests that NEP is higher than some other forests around the world. We suggest that a price should minimally sustain the livelihood of forest protectors, at around 10 US$/ton carbon, a price much higher than current government payments of 10 US$ ha y−1, regardless of carbon accumulation. This chapter asserts the importance of issuing forest carbon certificate to forest protectors so that local communities can raise their bargaining power to improve their income while at the same time, protect the natural forests sustainably. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Carbon Market; Carbon Sequestration; Poverty Reduction; Southeast Asia; Tropical Forests

Authors: S.M.K., Paskalis, Sahaya Murphin Kumar; P.K., Vinoth Kumar, Ponnusamy Kumar; K.R., Deepthi, Koolath Ramakrishnan; G., Kumar, Gopalakrishnan; P., Arivalagan, Pugazhendhi; H., Abe, Hideki; T., Sivakumar, Thiripuranthagan; U., Pal, Umapada; S., Kumar-Krishnan, Siva

Title: Controlled synthesis of Pt nanoparticle supported TiO2 nanorods as efficient and stable electrocatalysts for the oxygen reduction reaction
Affiliations: National Institute for Materials Science, Tsukuba, Japan; Anna University, Chennai, India; Kaohsiung Medical University, Kaohsiung, Taiwan; Kaohsiung Medical University, Kaohsiung, Taiwan; Universitetet i Stavanger, Stavanger, Norway; Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Benemérita Universidad Autónoma de Puebla, Puebla, Mexico; Benemérita Universidad Autónoma de Puebla, Puebla, Mexico
Authors with affiliations: Paskalis, Sahaya Murphin Kumar, National Institute for Materials Science, Tsukuba, Japan, Department of Applied Science and Technology, Anna University, Chennai, India, Research Center for Environmental Medicine, Kaohsiung Medical University, Kaohsiung, Taiwan; Vinoth Kumar, Ponnusamy Kumar, Research Center for Environmental Medicine, Kaohsiung Medical University, Kaohsiung, Taiwan, Department of Medicinal and Applied Chemistry, Kaohsiung Medical University, Kaohsiung, Taiwan; Deepthi, Koolath Ramakrishnan, National Institute for Materials Science, Tsukuba, Japan; Kumar, Gopalakrishnan, Bioscience and Environmental Engineering, Universitetet i Stavanger, Stavanger, Norway; Arivalagan, Pugazhendhi, Faculty of Environment and Labour Safety, Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Abe, Hideki, National Institute for Materials Science, Tsukuba, Japan; Sivakumar, Thiripuranthagan, Department of Applied Science and Technology, Anna University, Chennai, India; Pal, Umapada, Institute of Physics, Benemérita Universidad Autónoma de Puebla, Puebla, Mexico; Kumar-Krishnan, Siva, CONACYT-Instituto de Física, Benemérita Universidad Autónoma de Puebla, Puebla, Mexico
Abstract: The development of adequate cathode materials is one of the principal tasks for the fabrication of efficient proton-exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs), which are envisaged as clean energy sources for future transport and portable electrodomestic applications. Here, we present a platinum nanoparticle (NPs)-decorated one-dimensional (1D) titanium dioxide nanorod (PtNPs/TiO<inf>2</inf>NRs) nanocomposite with enhanced electrocatalytic performance towards the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). The TiO<inf>2</inf>NRs were prepared through a green approach, utilizing seaweed extract that not only acts as a reducing agent but also serves as a soft template for the directional growth of TiO<inf>2</inf> nanostructures. PtNPs of about 3.0 nm average size were decorated over pre-synthesized TiO<inf>2</inf>NRs through the chemical reduction of Pt ions using sodium borohydride. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and Raman spectroscopy analyses confirmed the presence of strong metal-support interactions (SMSI) in the prepared hybrid nanocomposite. The as-prepared PtNPs/TiO<inf>2</inf>NRs composite nanostructures exhibited significantly enhanced electrocatalytic performance and stability towards the ORR, with specific and mass activities of 0.428 mA cm−2 at 0.55 V and 128 mA mg−1 Pt, respectively. These values are 7.2 and 3.5 fold higher than that of standard Pt/C catalysts (0.059 mA cm−2 and 36 mA mg−1 Pt), respectively. The enhanced catalytic activity and high stability of the composite catalyst are mainly due to the unique 1D morphology of the TiO<inf>2</inf> nanostructures, which provides a greater surface area, and the SMSI enhancing electron transfer rate at their functional interface. The green approach utilized to fabricate the Pt/TiO<inf>2</inf>NRs composite in the present study provides a new, low-cost strategy for the development of metal-oxide hybrid nanostructures of high electrocatalytic activity for fuel cell applications. © 2019 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: K.U., Do, K. U.; H., Harada, Hidenori; I., Saizen, Izuru
Title: Enhancement of biogas production from anaerobic digestion of disintegrated sludge: A techno-economic assessment for sludge management of wastewater treatment plants in Vietnam
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Do, K. U., School of Environmental Science and Technology, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Harada, Hidenori, Graduate School of Global Environmental Studies, Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan; Saizen, Izuru, Graduate School of Global Environmental Studies, Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan
Abstract: Currently, in Vietnam 35 urban WWTPs had been constructed with a total capacity of 850,000 m3/day. Some 40 new WWTPs are in the design or construction phase with a capacity of 1,600,000 m3/day. During operation, a lot of excess sludge must be wasted out of the system. It is well recognized that sludge disposal is one of the most critical issues for WWTPs as the cost of the excess sludge treatment and disposal can account for 50–60% of the operating cost. In Vietnam, sludge discharged from wastewater treatment plants were mostly disposed by the conventional method such as landfill. Therefore, reduction of sludge volume before disposal is very important for sludge transportation and management. In this study, the sludge was disintegrated by alkalis to enhance the sludge biodegradability before adding to the anaerobic digestion. As a result, MLSS reduced from 6600 mg/L down to about 4800 mg/L when alkalis dosage was increased from 1 to 1.8 g/L. Soluble COD was increased from less than 100 mg/L to over 1800 mg/L. The sludge biodegradability enhancement is linearly correlated to COD solubilization. The biogas production of the disintegrated sludge was higher compared to the sludge without the alkali disintegration (358 and 245 mL biogas/g sludge added), representing a 46% increase in the biogas production. The cost of chemical consumption for sludge disintegration was about 0.36 US $/kg TSS. The alkali sludge disintegration combined with anaerobic digestion process could be considered as a potential approach for sludge management of wastewater treatment plants in Vietnam. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: V.M., Phap, Vu Minh; N., Yamamura, Naoki; M., Ishida, Muneaki; N.T., Nga, Nguyen Thuy
Author full names: Phap, Vu Minh (57193230888); Yamamura, Naoki (7005239315); Ishida, Muneaki (35495280600); Nga, Nguyen Thuy (57193227455)
Title: Impact of solar irradiation on PV cell emulating system in series connection mode
Affiliations: Mie University, Tsu, Japan; Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Phap, Vu Minh, Faculty of Engineering, Mie University, Tsu, Japan; Yamamura, Naoki, Faculty of Engineering, Mie University, Tsu, Japan; Ishida, Muneaki, Faculty of Engineering, Mie University, Tsu, Japan; Nga, Nguyen Thuy, Institute of Energy Science, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: Nowadays, the solar power systems are quickly developing in many countries to replace the fossil power sources and mitigate the environment pollution. The working efficiency of the power conditioner system in the solar power system is not high because the energy supply from solar array depends on the weather. The utilization rate of the power conditioner system can be increased by supplementing the small wind turbine to the existent grid-Tied solar power system with the support of the control system to imitate characteristic of the solar panel. In this research, we analyze the power converter circuit of the photovoltaic (PV) cell emulating system and present study results of operation of this system in series connection mode under the different levels of solar irradiation. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

(56002650800); Abe, Hideki (7404482056); Kumar-Krishnan, Siva (56108455800)
Title: Pt Nanoparticles Supported on Mesoporous CeO2 Nanostructures Obtained through Green Approach for Efficient Catalytic Performance toward Ethanol Electro-oxidation
Affiliations: National Institute for Materials Science, Tsukuba, Japan; Anna University, Chennai, India; Daegu University, Gyeongsan, South Korea; Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Bharathidasan University, Tiruchirappalli, India; UNAM campus Juriquilla, Juriquilla, Mexico; Benemérita Universidad Autónoma de Puebla, Puebla, Mexico
Authors with affiliations: Paskalis, Sahaya Murphin Kumar, National Institute for Materials Science, Tsukuba, Japan, Department of Applied Science and Technology, Anna University, Chennai, India; Sivakumar, Thiripuranthagan, Department of Applied Science and Technology, Anna University, Chennai, India; Imai, Tsubasa, National Institute for Materials Science, Tsukuba, Japan; Kumar, Gopalakrishnan, Department of Environmental Engineering, Daegu University, Gyeongsan, South Korea; Arivalagan, Pugazhendhi, Faculty of Environment and Labour Safety, Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Ramkumar, Vijayan Sri, Department of Environmental Biotechnology, Bharathidasan University, Tiruchirappalli, India; Esparza, Rodrigo A., Centro de Física Aplicada y Tecnología Avanzada, UNAM campus Juriquilla, Juriquilla, Mexico; Abe, Hideki, National Institute for Materials Science, Tsukuba, Japan; Kumar-Krishnan, Siva, Centro de Física Aplicada y Tecnología Avanzada, UNAM campus Juriquilla, Juriquilla, Mexico, Institute of Physics, Benemérita Universidad Autónoma de Puebla, Puebla, Mexico
Abstract: In this report, an easy and green approach to the synthesis of mesoporous cerium oxide (CeO<inf>2</inf>) nanostructures and followed by supporting platinum nanoparticles (NPs) on CeO<inf>2</inf> nanostructures (Pt/CeO<inf>2</inf>) and their application as versatile electrocatalysts for ethanol electrooxidation has been established. The synthesis of mesoporous Pt/CeO<inf>2</inf> nanostructures involves two steps. First, mesoporous CeO<inf>2</inf> nanostructures were synthesized via macroalgae polymer mediated approach and followed by supporting of PtNPs of ca. 5-10 nm over the mesoporous CeO<inf>2</inf> nanostructures using seed-mediated chemical reduction process. The structural and spectroscopic characterization techniques such as transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), Raman, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and small-angle X-ray scattering (SAXS) studies confirm the strong coupling between PtNPs and the mesoporous CeO<inf>2</inf> support resulting in the generation of more oxygen vacancies, which can facilitate the enhanced charge transport at their functional interface. Significantly, the synthesized mesoporous Pt/CeO<inf>2</inf> nanostructures were found to show enhanced electrocatalytic activity for ethanol electrooxidation reaction. The enhanced performance is attributed to the synergistic effect of both mesoporous structure and the formation of more oxygen vacancies in the resultant Pt/CeO<inf>2</inf> nanostructures. Our facile and eco-friendly approach to the synthesis of mesoporous CeO<inf>2</inf> nanostructures that supports PtNPs with an excellent catalytic activity is validated as a promising strategy for potential applications in fuel cells. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H., Lam, Hoangtrong; H., Katsuchi, Hiroshi; H., Yamada, Hitoshi

Title: Investigation of Turbulence Effects on the Aeroelastic Properties of a Truss Bridge Deck Section
Affiliations: University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Yokohama National University, Yokohama, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Lam, Hoangtrong, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Katsuchi, Hiroshi, Yokohama National University, Yokohama, Japan; Yamada, Hitoshi, Yokohama National University, Yokohama, Japan
Abstract: This paper presents the flutter derivatives (FDs) extracted from a stochastic system identification (SSI) method under different turbulent flows. The objective of the study is to investigate the effects of oncoming turbulence on the flutter of suspended long-span bridges using a section model wind-tunnel test. Several wind-tunnel tests were performed on a truss bridge deck section with different oncoming turbulent properties involving reduced turbulence intensities and turbulent scales. This study includes an investigation of the effect of oncoming flows on modal dynamic responses. The transient and buffeting response data from the wind-tunnel test are analyzed using the system identification technique in extracting FDs, and the difficulties involved in this method are discussed. The time-domain SSI is applied to extract all FDs simultaneously from one and two degree-of-freedom (1DOF and 2DOF) systems. Finally, the results under different conditions are discussed and conclusions are formed. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author full names: Shobana, S. (6603192288); Dattatraya Saratale, Ganesh Dattatraya (24172719100); Arivalagan, Pugazhendhi (57191625854); Arvindnarayan, Sundaram (57131064800); Sivagurunathan, Periyasamy (57050451800); Kumar, Gopalakrishnan (7202418804); Kim, Sang Hyoun (57223417806)
Title: Fermentative hydrogen production from mixed and pure microalgae biomass: Key challenges and possible opportunities
Affiliations: Aditanar College of Arts and Science, Tiruchendur, India; Dongguk University, Seoul, Seoul, South Korea; Daegu University, Gyeongsan, South Korea; RMK Engineering College, Kavaraipettai, India; National Institute for Environmental Studies of Japan, Tsukuba, Japan; Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Shobana, S., Department of Chemistry and Research Centre, Aditanar College of Arts and Science, Tiruchendur, India; Dattatraya Saratale, Ganesh Dattatraya, Department of Food Science and Biotechnology, Dongguk University, Seoul, Seoul, South Korea; Arivalagan, Pugazhendhi, Department of Environmental Engineering, Daegu University, Gyeongsan, South Korea; Arvindnarayan, Sundaram, Department of Mechanical Engineering, RMK Engineering College, Kavaraipettai, India; Sivagurunathan, Periyasamy, Center for Material Cycles and Waste Management Research, National Institute for Environmental Studies of Japan, Tsukuba, Japan; Kumar, Gopalakrishnan, Green Processing, Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Kim, Sang Hyoun, Department of Environmental Engineering, Daegu University, Gyeongsan, South Korea
Abstract: Dark bioH<inf>2</inf> fermentation from microalgae is a propitious technology to reduce the global CO<inf>2</inf> emission and environmental pollution problems. This review provides the wide varieties of microalgal biomass available in the environment and also analyses the relevant studies focused on the microalgal biomass to bioH<inf>2</inf> fermentation pathway. In this review, major enzymes and metabolic pathways involved in the dark fermentative hydrogen production has been reported. Major enzymes involved in the process are hydrogenases (Fe–Fe and Ni–Fe), besides, their thermo-tolerance and other aspects have been discussed. Metabolic and mechanistic pathway like acetate, butyrate (hydrogen accelerating reactions) and propionate (hydrogen consuming reactions) were highlighted. Recently microalgal biofuels along with bio refinery approach has been put forth as propitious technology for the future to solve the looming energy crisis. Major drawback in the extraction of sugars and other organic constituents from the microalgal cells are limiting their applications in various fields including bioenergy. A wide range of pretreatment methods has been applied so far and every treatment has their unique features. This report analyzes a comparative assessment of the pretreatment technologies and provides the key insights. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Abstract: Basic research on the accelerator-driven system is conducted by combining 235U-fueled and 232Th-loaded cores in the Kyoto University Critical Assembly with the pulsed neutron generator (14 MeV neutrons) and the proton beam accelerator (100 MeV protons with a heavy metal target). The results of experimental subcriticality are presented with a wide range of subcriticality level between near critical and 10,000 pcm, as obtained by the pulsed neutron source method, the Feynman-α method, and the neutron source multiplication method. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: A new soft-switching strategy for Three-Port Converter to be applied in EV application
Affiliations: Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Duy Dinh, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan; Fujita, Goro, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan; Ta, Cao Minh, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: This paper proposes a new soft-switching strategy for an isolated Three-Port bidirectional DC/DC Converter (TPC). Two inner phase shift angles will be introduced to two secondary inverters to make the modulation more flexible. Unlike published researches on TPC, this paper analyzes the converter in the frequency domain based on the fundamental harmonic approximation method. The simulation results confirm that, the maximum error between the calculated and the simulation powers is 31.2 W in the scale of 500 W (6.24%). After that, a new modulation strategy is proposed to help achieve zero-voltage switching (ZVS) characteristics. As confirmed by experiment, ZVS is achieved for all MOSFETs. The maximum efficiency of 95.58% is recorded, whereas, in the investigated power range, the average efficiency is 94.66%. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Design and implementation of digital controlled boost PFC converter under boundary conduction mode
Affiliations: National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, Taipei, Taiwan; University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Tokushima University, Tokushima, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Binh Nam, Department of Electrical & Computer Engineering, National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, Taipei, Taiwan, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Dung, Nguyen Anh, Department of Electrical & Computer Engineering, National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, Taipei, Taiwan; Liu, Yuchen, Department of Electrical & Computer Engineering, National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, Taipei, Taiwan; Hsieh, Yao Ching, Department of Electrical & Computer Engineering, National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, Taipei, Taiwan; Chiu, Huangjen, Department of Electrical & Computer Engineering, National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, Taipei, Taiwan; Hojo, Masahide, Tokushima University, Tokushima, Japan; Yamanaka, Kenji, Tokushima University, Tokushima, Japan
Abstract: The use of power factor correction (PFC) converters is widely discussed and considered for most off-line power supplies. For low power applications, boost PFC converters operated in discontinuous conduction mode (DCM) or boundary conduction mode (BCM) mode are usually employed. The main advantage of BCM mode is the reduction of reversal recovery loss of diode and simple control, especially at the high-line light-load condition. In this paper, a digital-controlled method for boost PFC operating under boundary conduction mode without input voltage sensing is proposed. The digital PI controller voltage is used to determine the constant on-time period and the comparator block inside the DSP controller is employed to detect the zero-crossing of inductor current for turning on the main switch. Therefore, the size and cost are reduced significantly. A 200W boost PFC prototype is implemented and tested to verify the feasibility of the proposed control scheme. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H.X., Nguyen, Hieu Xuan; T., Tsuji, Takao
Author full names: Nguyen, Hieu Xuan (57197779463); Tsuji, Takao (35354735900)
Title: Voltage control in distribution system by load transfer and optimal dispatch of photovoltaic
Affiliations: Yokohama National University, Yokohama, Japan; Vietnam National University of Agriculture, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Hieu Xuan, Graduate School of Engineering, Yokohama National University, Yokohama, Japan, Vietnam National University of Agriculture, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tsuji, Takao, Graduate School of Engineering, Yokohama National University, Yokohama, Japan
Abstract: The increasingly introduction of Photovoltaic (PV) systems into residential power system because of customers' desire to reduce electricity supply cost causes detrimental impacts, e.g. voltage operation and voltage unbalance (VU) issues. In order to cope with these problems, the control strategy of PV units where both reactive power control and active power curtailment are allowed has been proposed and it seems quite effective. However, much more active power curtailment is required to satisfy control requirement and this is not desired by customers on account that they will lose revenue. Besides, network configuration through sectionalizing switches is not really efficient with regard to intermittent power output of PVs and load variation throughout the day. Hence, this paper proposes a new control strategy which is the combination of dynamic-switch based load transfer (LT) and optimal inverter dispatch (OID) of PV units to eliminate VU while minimizing PVs' active power curtailment. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
