Title: Suppression of Surface-Enhanced Raman Scattering on Gold Nanostructures by Metal Adhesion Layers
Affiliations: Quy Nhon University, Quy Nhon, Viet Nam; Rijksuniversiteit Groningen, Groningen, Netherlands; Universiteit Twente, Enschede, Netherlands; University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Le Thi Ngoc, Loan Le Thi, Department of Physics, Quy Nhon University, Quy Nhon, Viet Nam, BIOS Lab on a Chip Group, Universiteit Twente, Enschede, Netherlands; Yuan, Tao, Department of Analytical Biochemistry, Rijksuniversiteit Groningen, Groningen, Netherlands; Oonishi, Naoto, Graduate School of Pure and Applied Sciences, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; van Nieuwkasteele, Jan W., BIOS Lab on a Chip Group, Universiteit Twente, Enschede, Netherlands; Van Den Berg, Albert H.J., BIOS Lab on a Chip Group, Universiteit Twente, Enschede, Netherlands; Permentier, Hjalmar P., Department of Analytical Biochemistry, Rijksuniversiteit Groningen, Groningen, Netherlands; Bischoff, Rainer P.H., Department of Analytical Biochemistry, Rijksuniversiteit Groningen, Groningen, Netherlands; Carlen, Edwin T., Graduate School of Pure and Applied Sciences, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan
Abstract: We report on the suppression of localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) and surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) of 60 nm thick gold nanostructures by titanium adhesion layers. Significant plasmon damping is observed for titanium layer thicknesses up to t<inf>Ti</inf> = 5 nm, which cannot be fully explained by simulation models that account for the overlap of the electric field in the bimetal layer with the titanium layer. Furthermore, the relationship between the SERS enhancement factor and the LSPR quality-factor G Q4 breaks down as t<inf>Ti</inf> is increased beyond 1 nm. We attribute the LSPR and SERS suppression to plasmon damping and spectral broadening of interband absorption due to the field overlap with the titanium layer and titanium impurities that interdiffuse through the grain boundaries of the polycrystalline gold layer during the deposition of the Au-Ti bimetal. These observations and analyses serve as a guide for improving the reliability of gold nanoplasmonic sensors. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author full names: Baghban, Alireza (57033992300); Namvarrechi, Saman (57191156136); Phung, Le Thi Kim (57189868331); Lee, Moonyong (56967110700); Bahadori, Alireza (56613643000); Kashiwao, Tomoaki (24724440300)
Title: Phase equilibrium modelling of natural gas hydrate formation conditions using LSSVM approach
Affiliations: Islamic Azad University, Tehran, Iran; Petroleum University of Technology, Abadan, Iran; University of Technology, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Yeungnam University, Gyeongsan, South Korea; Southern Cross University, Lismore, Australia; National Institute of Technology, Niihama College, Niihama, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Baghban, Alireza, Fasa Branch, Islamic Azad University, Tehran, Iran; Namvarrechi, Saman, Gas Engineering Department, Petroleum University of Technology, Abadan, Iran; Phung, Le Thi Kim, Department of Chemical process and Equipment, University of Technology, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Lee, Moonyong, School of Chemical Engineering, Yeungnam University, Gyeongsan, South Korea; Bahadori, Alireza, Science and Engineering, Southern Cross University, Lismore, Australia; Kashiwao, Tomoaki, Department of Electronics and Control Engineering, National Institute of Technology, Niihama College, Niihama, Japan
Abstract: The formation of gas hydrates in industries and chemical plants, especially in natural gas production and transmission, is an important factor that can lead to operational and economic risks. Hence, if the hydrate conditions are well addressed, it is possible overcome hydrate-related problems. To that end, evolving an accurate and simple-to-apply approach for estimating gas hydrate formation is vitally important. In this contribution, the least square support vector machine (LSSVM) approach has been developed based on Katz chart data points to estimate natural gas hydrate formation temperature as function of the pressure and gas gravity. In addition, a genetic algorithm has been employed to optimize hyper parameters of the LSSVM. Moreover, the present model has been compared with five popular correlations and was concluded that the LSSVM approach has fewer deviations than these correlations so to estimate hydrate formation temperature. According to statistical analyses, the obtained values of MSE and R2 were 0.278634 and 0.9973, respectively. This predictive tool is simple to apply and has great potential for estimating natural gas hydrate formation temperature and can be of immense value for engineers who deal with the natural gas utilities. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: M.B., Promentilla, M. B.; H.T., Nguyen, Hoc Thang; P.T., Kien, Pham Trung; H., Hinode, Hirofumi; F.T., Bacani, Florinda T.; S.M., Gallardo, Susan M.
Author full names: Promentilla, M. B. (15045622100); Nguyen, Hoc Thang (57312316600); Kien, Pham Trung (55984993300); Hinode, Hirofumi (6603680612); Bacani, Florinda T. (16038876700); Gallardo, Susan M. (7004678447)
Title: Optimizing Ternary-blended Geopolymers with Multi-response Surface Analysis
Affiliations: De La Salle University, Manila, Philippines; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Promentilla, M. B., De La Salle University, Manila, Philippines; Nguyen, Hoc Thang, De La Salle University, Manila, Philippines, Faculty of Materials Technology, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Kien, Pham Trung, Faculty of Materials Technology, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Hinode, Hirofumi, Department of International Development Engineering, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Bacani, Florinda T., De La Salle University, Manila, Philippines; Gallardo, Susan M., De La Salle University, Manila, Philippines
Abstract: Geopolymers, also known as alkali-activated pozzolan cements, have been recently gaining attention as an alternative binder for concrete because of its potential to lower the environmental impact of construction, to utilize waste as raw materials of alumino-silicates, and to enhance the material performance. In this study, engineering properties of lightweight geopolymer-based material produced from the ternary blend of red mud (RM) waste, rice husk ash (RHA) and diatomaceous earth (DE) are optimized with statistical multi-response surface method. Using the augmented simplex lattice mixture design, ten mix proportions of RM, RHA and DE were prepared and mixed with 15 % (by weight of the solid) water glass solution to produce the specimens. After 28 days of curing at room temperature, these specimens were tested for compressive strength (MPa), volumetric weight (kg/m3), and water absorption (kg/m3) including the mass loss (%), volumetric shrinkage (%) and change in compressive strength (%) when subjected to an elevated temperature of 1000 °C. By using the desirability function approach on multiple responses, the optimum ternary blend was found to be 14.5 % RM, 67.2 % RHA and 18.3 % DE to obtain the desirable engineering properties of a lightweight heat resistant material. Using this mix proportion, confirmatory runs were also done and the experimental values were found to be in good agreement with the predicted values. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: P.Q., Thang, Phan Quang; Y., Maeda, Yasuaki; N.Q., Trung, Nguyen Quang; N., Takenaka, Norimichi
Author full names: Thang, Phan Quang (55961858300); Maeda, Yasuaki (55797766600); Trung, Nguyen Quang (55961888000); Takenaka, Norimichi (7007012272)
Title: Detailed chemical kinetics for thermal decomposition of low molecular weight-methyl esters generated by using biodiesel fuel
Affiliations: Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Thang, Phan Quang, Department of Applied Chemistry, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan, Institute of Environmental Technology, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Maeda, Yasuaki, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Trung, Nguyen Quang, Institute of Environmental Technology, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Takenaka, Norimichi, Department of Applied Chemistry, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan
Abstract: Low molecular weight-methyl ester (LMW-ME), which was reported in our previous study [1], was generated by the use of biodiesel fuel (BDF) with a diesel power generator. In this article, the detailed chemical kinetics for the thermal decomposition of LMW-MEs was investigated at atmospheric pressure and a temperature range of 773 to 973 K. Six standards of LMW-MEs were used for thermal decomposition in a continuous flow reactor. The kinetic data, such as reaction orders, activation energies, and rate constants, were then calculated. The reaction orders and activation energies of the thermal decomposition reactions of C<inf>4</inf>, C<inf>5</inf>, C<inf>6</inf>, C<inf>7</inf>, C<inf>8,</inf> and C<inf>9</inf> were 1.13, 0.96, 1.17, 0.80, 0.99, 0.84, and 312.04, 117.37, 87.29, 62.94, 74.80, 75.79 kJ mol−1, respectively. The decomposition of LMW-MEs with higher carbon numbers was faster than those with smaller carbon numbers, except for C<inf>8</inf>. The C<inf>4</inf> methyl ester was stable and abundant in the product of the decomposition as well as in the exhausted gas from the engine combustion using BDF. This kinetic data will be applied to modeling study on BDF decomposition and engine technologies to mitigate toxic emissions from BDF combustion. © 2016 American Institute of Chemical Engineers Environ Prog, 35: 1190–1197, 2016. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: M., Ahmadi, Mohammadali; Z., Ahmad, Z.; L.T.K., Phung, Le Thi Kim; T., Kashiwao, Tomoaki; A., Bahadori, Alireza
Author full names: Ahmadi, Mohammadali (57218622761); Ahmad, Z. (55276521200); Phung, Le Thi Kim (57189868331); Kashiwao, Tomoaki (24724440300); Bahadori, Alireza (56613643000)
Title: Experimental investigation the effect of nanoparticles on micellization behavior of a surfactant: Application to EOR
Affiliations: Petroleum University of Technology, Abadan, Iran; Universiti Sains Malaysia, Gelugor, Malaysia; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; National Institute of Technology, Niihama College, Niihama, Japan; Southern Cross University, Lismore, Australia

Abstract: ABSTRACT: Chemical stimulation such as surfactant flooding in petroleum reservoirs makes efforts to produce remained oil and improve sweep efficiency by means of different phenomena such as lowering interfacial tension and wettability alteration of reservoir rock. Implementing concentration of surfactant through surfactant flooding is one of the big challenges while interfacial tension between surfactant solution and oil after certain concentration involves little changes such as critical micelle concentration (CMC). This article highlights the effect of nanosilica on CMC of Zyziphus Spina Christi, as sugar-based surfactant, in aqueous solutions for enhanced oil recovery and reservoir stimulation purposes. A conductivity approach was selected to assess the CMC of the introduced surfactant in aqueous solution at 25°C. The influence of nanosilica concentrations on CMC variation of introduced surfactant is considered. It is found that CMC of introduced surfactant decreased while the concentration of the nanosilica increased. Results from this study can aim in optimum condition selection of surfactant flooding as an enhanced oil recovery ends. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: M., Ahmadi, Mohammadali; Z., Ahmad, Z.; L.T.K., Phung, Le Thi Kim; T., Kashiwao, Tomoaki; A., Bahadori, Alireza
Author full names: Ahmadi, Mohammadali (57218622761); Ahmad, Z. (55276521200); Phung, Le Thi Kim (57189868331); Kashiwao, Tomoaki (24724440300); Bahadori, Alireza (56613643000)
Title: Evaluation of the ability of the hydrophobic nanoparticles of SiO2 in the EOR process through carbonate rock samples
Affiliations: Petroleum University of Technology, Abadan, Iran; Universiti Sains Malaysia, Gelugor, Malaysia; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; National Institute of Technology, Niihama College, Niihama, Japan; Southern Cross University, Lismore, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Ahmadi, Mohammadali, Department of Petroleum Engineering, Petroleum University of Technology, Abadan, Iran; Ahmad, Z., Universiti Sains Malaysia, Gelugor, Malaysia; Phung, Le Thi Kim, Department of Chemical Process and Equipment, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Kashiwao, Tomoaki, Department of Electronics and Control Engineering, National Institute of Technology, Niihama College, Niihama, Japan; Bahadori, Alireza, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Southern Cross University, Lismore, Australia
Abstract: ABSTRACT: More than 50% of oil remains in reservoirs after primary and secondary recovery processes. Consequently, methods of enhanced oil recovery (EOR) should be applied for more recovery from these reservoirs. In this study the ability of hydrophobic nanoparticles of sio<inf>2</inf> in EOR process through carbonate rock samples is studied. By employing hydrophobic nanosilica, we can lower interfacial tension between oil and nanofluid and then reduce the mobility ratio between oil and nanofluid in carbonate reservoirs; however, nanosilica can increase the viscosity of water exponentially. To evaluate this goal, core displacement experiment for carbonate core is conducted. These experiments are performed on the carbonate samples saturated with oil and brine that had got injected with nanosilica with six different concentrations. Investigating the outcomes shows that by rising nanoparticle concentration, the IFT between water and oil phases decreases and yields in decrease the mobility ratio between oil and nanofluid. For this, we measure the recovery level in different states of using 0.05, 0.1, 0.1, 0.15, 0.3, 0.6, 1.0, and 0 concentration of the nanoparticle. The outcomes achieved from our experiments reveals that employing hydrophobic nanosilica could increases the oil recovery factor. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H., Saito, H.; T.M., Quynh, Tran Minh; K., Furusawa, Kazuya; N., Nagasawa, Naotsugu; T., Dobashi, Toshiaki
Author full names: Saito, H. (57204945140); Quynh, Tran Minh (8617782900); Furusawa, Kazuya (8362328300); Nagasawa, Naotsugu (7007143686); Dobashi, Toshiaki (7006988134)
Title: Gelation of DNA and Bovine Serum Albumin (DNA-BSA gel) by gamma irradiation as bio-absorbent for acridine orange
Affiliations: Gunma University, Maebashi, Japan; Vietnam Atomic Energy Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hokkaido University, Sapporo, Japan; Japan Atomic Energy Agency, Kashiwa, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Saito, H., Faculty of Science and Technology, Gunma University, Maebashi, Japan; Quynh, Tran Minh, Hanoi Irradiation Center, Vietnam Atomic Energy Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Furusawa, Kazuya, Faculty of Advanced Life Science, Hokkaido University, Sapporo, Japan; Nagasawa, Naotsugu, Quantum Beam Science Directorate, Japan Atomic Energy Agency, Kashiwa, Japan; Dobashi, Toshiaki, Faculty of Science and Technology, Gunma University, Maebashi, Japan
Abstract: Together with their advantages, the availability of synthetic organic chemicals also caused many adverse effects to the environment due to the fact that they do not seem to be completely bio-degraded in nature. The residues of these synthetic organic compounds, such as polychlorinated biphenyl (PCBs), acridine orange (AO) and other aromatics, as well as their degraded intermediates, may become carcinogens or mutagens, which severely affect human health. In the cell, these organic compounds can intercalate into the major grooves and interstices between the base pair of DNA double helix, resulting in several diseases and cancers. In other words, DNA can be utilized as the most efficient bio-adsorbent of such toxic agents. For this purpose, DNA must be in water-insoluble state. Recently, radiation has been proven to be one of the effective methods of introducing the crosslinking network in the polymer matrix. Though DNA is easily broken by radiation, it can crosslink in the presence of suitable crosslinkers, or be immobilized onto the crosslinking gels. In this study, we have successfully prepared DNA/BSA complex gels from aqueous mixtures of DNA with BSA by gamma irradiation. Their gelation behaviors were characterized for utilization as adsorbents for AO. The results indicated that the adsorption was a time-dependent process and the adsorption capacity of AO increased with DNA amount in the DNA/BSA gels. © 2019 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: N., Hung, Nguyentrong; L.B., Thuan, Le Ba; D., Van Khoai, Do; J., Lee, Jinyoung; R.K., Jyothi, Rajesh Kumar
Author full names: Hung, Nguyentrong (57188694788); Thuan, Le Ba (57188706314); Van Khoai, Do (55630952500); Lee, Jinyoung (35233901600); Jyothi, Rajesh Kumar (57216781429)
Title: Brandon mathematical model describing the effect of calcination and reduction parameters on specific surface area of UO2 powders
Affiliations: Institute for Technology of Radioactive and Rare Elements, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Micro Emission Ltd, Nomi, Japan; Korea Institute of Geoscience and Mineral Resources, Daejeon, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Hung, Nguyentrong, Institute for Technology of Radioactive and Rare Elements, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Thuan, Le Ba, Institute for Technology of Radioactive and Rare Elements, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Van Khoai, Do, Micro Emission Ltd, Nomi, Japan; Lee, Jinyoung, Convergence Research Center for Development of Mineral Resources, Korea Institute of Geoscience and Mineral Resources, Daejeon, South Korea; Jyothi, Rajesh Kumar, Convergence Research Center for Development of Mineral Resources, Korea Institute of Geoscience and Mineral Resources, Daejeon, South Korea
Abstract: Uranium dioxide (UO<inf>2</inf>) powder has been widely used to prepare fuel pellets for commercial light water nuclear reactors. Among typical characteristics of the powder, specific surface area (SSA) is one of the most important parameter that determines the sintering ability of UO<inf>2</inf> powder. This paper built up a mathematical model describing the effect of the fabrication parameters on SSA of UO<inf>2</inf> powders. To the best of our knowledge, the Brandon model is used for the first time to describe the relationship between the essential fabrication parameters [reduction temperature (T<inf>R</inf>), calcination temperature (T<inf>C</inf>), calcination time (t<inf>C</inf>) and reduction time (t<inf>R</inf>)] and SSA of the obtained UO<inf>2</inf> powder product. The proposed model was tested with Wilcoxon's rank sum test, showing a good agreement with the experimental parameters. The proposed model can be used to predict and control the SSA of UO<inf>2</inf> powder. © 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Burnup performance of small-sized long-life CANDLE high temperature gas-cooled reactors with U-Th-Pa fuel
Affiliations: Nippon Advanced Information Service, Naka, Japan; Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Tokyo City University, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Liem, Peng Hong, Nippon Advanced Information Service, Naka, Japan; Tran, Hoai Nam, Institute of Research and Development, Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Sekimoto, Hiroshi, Tokyo City University, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: The innovative CANDLE (Constant Axial shape of Neutron flux, nuclide densities and power shape During Life of Energy producing reactor) burnup strategy has been successfully applied to both fast and thermal reactors. In particular for thermal reactor applications, CANDLE block-type high temperature gas-cooled reactors (HTGRs) with either U-Pu or U-Th fuel cycle had been proposed and investigated for their simple and safe reactor operation, and the ease of designing a long life reactor. In this work, we investigated the use of Pa-231 mixed homogeneously in the (Th-232/U-233)O<inf>2</inf> fuel kernel of the TRISO particles, that is the U-Th-Pa fuel, to obtain better CANDLE burnup performance. Some consideration on how to supply the required U-233 and Pa-231 was also thoroughly discussed. U-Th-Pa fuel decreases the required amount of natural Gd burnable poison in the fresh fuel for establishing a valid CANDLE HTGR design since Pa-231 has a large thermal absorption cross section. Besides the role as a burnable poison nuclide, Pa-231 also serves as a fertile nuclide during the CANDLE burning since Pa-231 is finally transmuted to a fissile U-233 nuclide. A promising analysis result shows that for U-233 and Pa-231 concentrations of 15 and 7.50 w/o, respectively, the discharged burnup can be increased from 138 (U-Th fuel) to 149 GWd/t. This extends the core life time about 16%, i.e. from 35 (U-Th fuel) to 41 years with CANDLE active core height of 800 cm and reactor thermal power of 30 MWth. © 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author full names: Tanikawa, Daisuke (57090684600); Syutsubo, Kazuaki (6602921043); Watari, T. (57089990800); Miyaoka, Yuma (56404348500); Hatamoto, M. (15925577300); Iijima, Sou (57125540000); Fukuda, Masao (7404038135); Nguyen, Ngoc Bich (57125380900); Yamaguchi, Takashi (55684226600)
Title: Greenhouse gas emissions from open-type anaerobic wastewater treatment system in natural rubber processing factory
Affiliations: National Institute of Technology, Kure College, Kure, Japan; National Institute for Environmental Studies of Japan, Tsukuba, Japan; Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; International Rubber Research and Development Board, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Tanikawa, Daisuke, Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering, National Institute of Technology, Kure College, Kure, Japan; Syutsubo, Kazuaki, Center for Regional Environmental Research, National Institute for Environmental Studies of Japan, Tsukuba, Japan; Watari, T., Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Miyaoka, Yuma, Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Hatamoto, M., Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Iijima, Sou, Department of Bioengineering, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Fukuda, Masao, Department of Bioengineering, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Nguyen, Ngoc Bich, Rubber Research Institute of Vietnam, International Rubber Research and Development Board, Viet Nam; Yamaguchi, Takashi, Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan
Abstract: We evaluated greenhouse gases (GHGs) emissions from an open-type anaerobic system (OAS) treating ribbed smoked sheets (RSS) wastewater in a processing factory. The emitted biogas comprised 57.7%-60.8% methane, 14.5%-31.5% carbon dioxide, 10.8%-24.7% nitrogen, and 329-423 ppm of nitrous oxide. In the OAS, the chemical oxygen demand (COD) degraded as the methane emission rate increased from influent to effluent. Finally, 94.4% of the total COD was removed. More than 90% of the removed COD converted to methane. Methane emitted from the bottom and the wall surface of the OAS. Methane-producing bacteria was detected by a cloning analysis of the 16S rRNA gene. The predominant species differed depending on the degradation characteristics of the RSS wastewater in the OAS. The emission rate of methane and nitrous oxide ranged between 2.58 and 8.85 NL/(m2 hr) and between 0.074 and 0.410 NL/(m2/hr), respectively. Moreover, 0.153 t-CO<inf>2eq</inf> of GHGs were emitted from 1 m3 of RSS wastewater treatment. Nitrous oxide accounted for 65% of the total GHGs emissions because of its high global warming potential. Therefore, both nitrous oxide and methane that emitted from the treatment of wastewater from a natural rubber processing factory must be considered as significant contributors to the GHGs. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: M., Ahmadi, Mohammadali; Z., Ahmad, Z.; L.T.K., Phung, Le Thi Kim; T., Kashiwao, Tomoaki; A., Bahadori, Alireza
Author full names: Ahmadi, Mohammadali (57218622761); Ahmad, Z. (55276521200); Phung, Le Thi Kim (57189868331); Kashiwao, Tomoaki (24724440300); Bahadori, Alireza (56613643000)
Title: Estimation of water content of natural gases using particle swarm optimization method
Affiliations: Petroleum University of Technology, Abadan, Iran; USM Engineering Campus, Nibong Tebal, Malaysia; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; National Institute of Technology, Niihama College, Niihama, Japan; Southern Cross University, Lismore, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Ahmadi, Mohammadali, Department of Petroleum Engineering, Petroleum University of Technology, Abadan, Iran; Ahmad, Z., School of Chemical Engineering, USM Engineering Campus, Nibong Tebal, Malaysia; Phung, Le Thi Kim, Department of Chemical Process and Equipment, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Kashiwao, Tomoaki, Department of Electronics and Control Engineering, National Institute of Technology, Niihama College, Niihama, Japan; Bahadori, Alireza, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Southern Cross University, Lismore, Australia
Abstract: ABSTRACT: A precise estimation of natural gas water content is a significant constraint in appropriate planning of natural gas production, processing services and transmission. The main contribution of this research is to develop a machine learning approach for predicting water content of sweet and sour natural gases. In this regard, a joining of particle swarm optimization and an artificial neural network was utilized. The suggested model presents good predictions of the sour natural gas water content with following circumstances, including CO<inf>2</inf> contents of 0–40 mol%, H<inf>2</inf>S contents of 0–50 mol%, pressures in range from atmospheric to 70,000 KPa for sour gas and 100,000 KPa for sweet gas, and temperatures from 10–200°C for sweet gases and 10–150°C for sour gases. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author full names: Kumar, Gopalakrishnan (7202418804); Zhen, Guangyin (43061714300); Sivagurunathan, Periyasamy (57050451800); Bakonyi, Péter (36871443100); Nemestóthy, Nándor (6506371540); Bélafi-Bakó, K. (55880404200); Kobayashi, Takurou (55724307100); Xu, Kaiqin (55570728500)
Title: Biogenic H2 production from mixed microalgae biomass: Impact of pH control and methanogenic inhibitor (BESA) addition
Affiliations: Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; National Institute for Environmental Studies of Japan, Tsukuba, Japan; Pannon Egyetem, Veszprem, Hungary; Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China
Authors with affiliations: Kumar, Gopalakrishnan, Sustainable Management of Natural Resources and Environment Research Group, Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Center for Material Cycles and Waste Management Research, National Institute for Environmental Studies of Japan, Tsukuba, Japan; Zhen, Guangyin, Center for Material Cycles and Waste Management Research, National Institute for Environmental Studies of Japan, Tsukuba, Japan; Sivagurunathan, Periyasamy, Center for Material Cycles and Waste Management Research, National Institute for Environmental Studies of Japan, Tsukuba, Japan; Bakonyi, Péter, Membrane Technology and Energetics, Pannon Egyetem, Veszprem, Hungary; Nemestóthy, Nándor, Membrane Technology and Energetics, Pannon Egyetem, Veszprem, Hungary; Bélafi-Bakó, K., Membrane Technology and Energetics, Pannon Egyetem, Veszprem, Hungary; Kobayashi, Takurou, Center for Material Cycles and Waste Management Research, National Institute for Environmental Studies of Japan, Tsukuba, Japan; Xu, Kaiqin, Center for Material Cycles and Waste Management Research, National Institute for Environmental Studies of Japan, Tsukuba, Japan, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China
Abstract: Hydrogen production from mixed microalgae biomass, predominantly containing Scendesmus and chlorella species, was investigated with a focus on enhancement strategies, in particular (i) pH control (at 5.5) and (ii) methanogenic inhibitor (BESA) addition along with pH control at 5.5. The results obtained showed that the later condition remarkably increased the performances. This was mainly ascribed to the occurrence of a suitable environment for the hydrogen producers to perform actively. Hydrogen production under these conditions (i.e., both pH 5.5 and pH 5.5+BESA) was significantly higher than that of the control experiment. Using the pH control at 5.5 and BESA addition, peak hydrogen production rate (HPR) and hydrogen yield (HY) were attained as 210 mL/L/d and 29.5 mL/g VS<inf>added,</inf> respectively. This improvement was nearly 3-folds higher compared with the control experiment with an HPR of 62 mL/L/d and an HY of 9.5 mL/g VS<inf>added</inf>. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.T., Tran, Thanh Tu; S., Fujimori, Shinichiro; T., Masui, Toshihiko
Author full names: Tran, Thanh Tu (57190758718); Fujimori, Shinichiro (36971176800); Masui, Toshihiko (35240780700)
Title: Realizing the intended nationally determined contribution: The role of renewable energies in Vietnam
Affiliations: International University - Vietnam National University HCM City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; National Institute for Environmental Studies of Japan, Tsukuba, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tran, Thanh Tu, Regional Centre of Expertise on Education for Sustainable Development in Southern Vietnam, International University - Vietnam National University HCM City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Fujimori, Shinichiro, National Institute for Environmental Studies of Japan, Tsukuba, Japan; Masui, Toshihiko, National Institute for Environmental Studies of Japan, Tsukuba, Japan
Abstract: This study contributes to the realization of intended nationally determined contributions (INDCs) by analyzing their implications for the energy production system and the economy, and determines the role of renewable energies (RE) in reducing the challenge of committing to the INDCs. The Asia-Pacific Integrated Model/Computable General Equilibrium (AIM/CGE) model was used to assess seven scenarios having the same socioeconomic development but different shares of RE in power generation. By comparing different relative reductions caused by the emission constraints vis-a-vis the business-as-usual (BaU) scenario, the mitigation costs can be estimated. Results show that the economic impact could be reduced by around 55% in terms of welfare loss (from 6.0% to 2.7%) and by around 36% in terms of gross domestic product (GDP) loss (from 3.4% to 2.1%) through the incorporation of high levels of renewable energy. Furthermore, the additional double deployment of wind and SPV to 5.4% and 12.0%, respectively, which currently comprise 43.1% of the renewable energies used in electricity generation, could reduce the GDP loss from 2.1% to 1.9% and reduce the welfare loss from 2.7% to 1.5% in order to achieve a 25.0% GHG emissions reduction. These losses are less than those in the pricing-only scenario (2.1% and 2.3%, respectively). © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: M., Hiratsuka, Motoshi; S.K., Paudel, Shyam Krishna; S., Iwanaga, Seiji; H., Yaginuma, Hirofumi; M., Amano, Masahiro
Author full names: Hiratsuka, Motoshi (10440069000); Paudel, Shyam Krishna (57220363161); Iwanaga, Seiji (56985425900); Yaginuma, Hirofumi (56985724900); Amano, Masahiro (16479812600)
Title: Prospects and challenges of reducing emissions from deforestation and forest degradation in Central Kalimantan Province, Indonesia
Source title: International Journal of Environment and Sustainable Development
Affiliations: Mitsubishi UFJ Research and Consulting Co., Ltd., Tokyo, Japan; United Nations Development Programme, New York, United States; University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Waseda University, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Hiratsuka, Motoshi, Mitsubishi UFJ Research and Consulting Co., Ltd., Tokyo, Japan; Paudel, Shyam Krishna, United Nations Development Programme, New York, United States; Iwanaga, Seiji, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Yaginuma, Hirofumi, Faculty of Human Sciences, Waseda University, Tokyo, Japan; Amano, Masahiro, Faculty of Human Sciences, Waseda University, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Indonesia is rapidly progressing in terms of reducing emissions from deforestation and forest degradation (REDD plus) preparedness. We carried out a detailed feasibility study to develop and implement a new mechanism of the REDD plus for Central Kalimantan, a REDD pilot province of Indonesia. Several REDD plus activities were implemented in Paduran Mulia Village of Central Kalimantan. Remote sensing data was used to detect land use changes in the study area and was complemented by ground inventory to assess the actual carbon stock of the forest. The study found that land cover and uses have significantly been changed since last 30 years. Considering 2008 as a base year, we estimated that the total emission reduction would be 9,344 Gg CO<inf>2</inf> in the next 20 years (about 450 Gg CO<inf>2</inf>/year). The results indicated the optimistic scenario with significant emission reduction if the proposed REDD plus activities were implemented successfully. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: P.H., Liem, Peng Hong; H.N., Tran, Hoai Nam; T.M., Sembiring, Tagor Malem
Author full names: Liem, Peng Hong (6603970138); Tran, Hoai Nam (15926474700); Sembiring, Tagor Malem (6602501586)
Title: Design optimization of a new homogeneous reactor for medical radioisotope Mo-99/Tc-99m production
Affiliations: Nippon Advanced Information Service, Naka, Japan; Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Badan Tenaga Nuklir Nasional Indonesia, Central Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Liem, Peng Hong, Scientific Computational Division, Nippon Advanced Information Service, Naka, Japan; Tran, Hoai Nam, Institute of Research and Development, Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Sembiring, Tagor Malem, Center for Nuclear Reactor Technology and Safety, Badan Tenaga Nuklir Nasional Indonesia, Central Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: To partly solve the global and regional shortages of Mo-99/Tc-99m supply, a conceptual design of a homogeneous solution reactor for Mo-99/Tc-99m medical radioisotope production is proposed. Some basic characteristics and features of the design are discussed. The new homogeneous solution reactor is designed by taking into account the matured technology for chemically extracting the Mo-99 from the low enriched uranium (LEU) targets (the modified LEU Cintichem process) that has been acquired, demonstrated and licensed commercially for decades by the Center for Radioisotope Production of the National Nuclear Energy Agency of Indonesia (BATAN). Design optimization for obtaining the minimum critical U-235 mass and the maximum reactor power (proportional to Mo-99 production capacity) is presented. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.T., Nguyen, Tat Thang; H., Kikura, Hiroshige; H., Murakawa, Hideki; N., Tsuzuki, Nobuyoshi
Author full names: Nguyen, Tat Thang (59794533500); Kikura, Hiroshige (35597037700); Murakawa, Hideki (7005035162); Tsuzuki, Nobuyoshi (14051240000)
Title: Measurement of Bubbly Two-phase Flow in Vertical Pipe Using Multiwave Ultrasonic Pulsed Dopller Method and Wire Mesh Tomography
Affiliations: Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Mechanics, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kobe University, Kobe, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Tat Thang, Research Laboratory for Nuclear Reactors, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan, Department for Industrial and Environmental Fluid Dynamics, Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Mechanics, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kikura, Hiroshige, Research Laboratory for Nuclear Reactors, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Murakawa, Hideki, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Kobe University, Kobe, Japan; Tsuzuki, Nobuyoshi, Research Laboratory for Nuclear Reactors, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Two measurement methods which are multiwave ultrasonic pulsed Doppler (multiwave UVP) method and wire mesh tomography (WMT) have been applied to the measurement of bubbly two-phase flow. Velocity profiles of bubbles and liquid have been measured using multiwave UVP. Simultaneously, cross-sectional void fraction distribution has been measured using WMT. As the result, a combination method has been set up. The measured parameters are indispensable in order to obtain detailed structures of two-phase flow. Multiwave UVP method exploits two basic ultrasonic frequencies which are 2 MHz and 8 MHz. Simultaneous measurement of velocity profiles of bubbles (using 2 MHz frequency) and those of liquid (using 8 MHz frequency), at the same position, is enabled. A multiwave ultrasonic transducer (multiwave TDX) which is able to emit and receive the two ultrasonic frequencies along the measurement line at the same time has been applied. The signal processing is based on the pulsed Doppler method. Using the combination method, first, instantaneous velocity profiles and void fraction distribution have been measured simultaneously for air-water counter-current bubbly flow in a vertical pipe. Flow structure has been clarified. Effect of initial condition on void fraction distribution has been confirmed. Next, measurements have been carried out for subcooled boiling bubbly flow in a vertical pipe. For measurement of subcooled boiling flow, a high temperature wire mesh sensor (WMS) has been developed. A method for separation of velocity profiles of bubbles with different sizes and velocities has been suggested. © 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: V.H., Hai, Vo Hong; N., Hung, Nguyenquoc; T.K., Bui, Tuan Khai
Author full names: Hai, Vo Hong (14055737600); Hung, Nguyenquoc (57190742491); Bui, Tuan Khai (56668729800)
Title: Development of gamma spectroscopy employing Nal(Tl) detector 3 inch × 3 inch and readout electronic of flash-ADC/FPGA-based technology
Affiliations: University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Hai, Vo Hong, Nuclear Engineering Lab, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Division of Nuclear Physics, Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Hung, Nguyenquoc, Nuclear Engineering Lab, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Bui, Tuan Khai, Department of Physics, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan
Abstract: In this article the development of a gamma spectroscopy system is described using a scintillation detector Nal(Tl) of 3 inch x 3 inch. The readout electronic for the spectroscopy is built from the fast analog-digital conversion of Flash Analog-Digital Converter (Flash-ADC) 250 MHz - 8 bits resolution, and the embedded Field-Programmable Gate Array (FPGA) technology. The embedded VHSIC Hardware Description Language (VHDL) code for FPGA is built in such a way that it works as a multi channel analyser (MCA) with 4096 Digital Charge Integration (DCI) channels. A pulse generator with frequency varying from Hz up to 12 kHz is used to evaluate the time response of the system. Two standard radioisotope sources of 133Ba and 152Eu with multi gamma energies ranging from several tens keV to MeVare used to evaluate the linearity and energy resolution of the system. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: D., Duc, Daodao; H., Yamada, Hidetaka; K., Yogo, Katsunori
Author full names: Duc, Daodao (55543152300); Yamada, Hidetaka (9732900100); Yogo, Katsunori (6701455797)
Title: Response surface optimization of impregnation of blended amines into mesoporous silica for high-performance Co2 capture
Affiliations: Nara Institute of Science and Technology, Ikoma, Japan; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Research Institute of Innovative Technology for Earth Kizugawa, Kizugawa, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Duc, Daodao, Nara Institute of Science and Technology, Ikoma, Japan, Faculty of Chemistry, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Yamada, Hidetaka, Research Institute of Innovative Technology for Earth Kizugawa, Kizugawa, Japan; Yogo, Katsunori, Nara Institute of Science and Technology, Ikoma, Japan, Research Institute of Innovative Technology for Earth Kizugawa, Kizugawa, Japan
Abstract: We used the response surface method (RSM) to optimize the conditions for the impregnation of blended amines into mesostructured cellular silica foam (MSU-F) to prepare effective solid sorbents for CO<inf>2</inf> capture. The effects of the amounts of tetraethylenepentamine (TEPA), diethanolamine (DEA), and methanol (MeOH) in the wet impregnation mixture on the amounts of CO<inf>2</inf> adsorbed were investigated. The influences of these three independent variables and their interactions were determined using the RSM; the optimum amounts of TEPA, DEA, and MeOH were 1.33 g (7.03 mmol), 0.85 g (8.08 mmol), and 58.2 g, for the preparation of 3 g of sorbent, respectively. Under the adsorption conditions of 40 °C and 100 kPa CO<inf>2</inf>, the optimum sorbent showed fast kinetics and an excellent CO<inf>2</inf> adsorption of 5.64 mmol/g; the value predicted by the RSM model was 5.67 mmol/g. Analysis of variance and the coefficient of determination (R2 = 0.9525) showed the utility of the approach used in this study to optimize the conditions for preparing high-performance solid sorbents. For the optimum sorbent, the heat of adsorption was determined to be 78.9 kJ/mol CO<inf>2</inf> at 40 °C and 100 kPa, using a Calvet calorimeter, indicating relatively strong chemisorption in the form of carbamate. We also found that the amounts of CO<inf>2</inf> adsorbed by the optimum sorbent substantially depended upon the adsorption temperature. The highest CO<inf>2</inf> adsorption, 6.86 mmol/g, was obtained at 50 °C and 100 kPa. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: C.T., Tran, Chi Thanh; V.H., Nguyen, Viet Hung; M., Tahara, Mika; Y., Kojima, Yoshihiro; R., Hamazaki, Ryoichi; P.I., Kudinov, P. I.
Author full names: Tran, Chi Thanh (35243602000); Nguyen, Viet Hung (57836825800); Tahara, Mika (15751985800); Kojima, Yoshihiro (36803354300); Hamazaki, Ryoichi (23501158600); Kudinov, P. I. (24331796200)
Title: A study on transient heat transfer of the EU-ABWR external core catcher using the Phase-change Effective Convectivity Model
Affiliations: Vietnam Atomic Energy Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Toshiba Corporation, Tokyo, Japan; The Royal Institute of Technology (KTH), Stockholm, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Tran, Chi Thanh, Vietnam Atomic Energy Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Viet Hung, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tahara, Mika, Toshiba Corporation, Tokyo, Japan; Kojima, Yoshihiro, Toshiba Corporation, Tokyo, Japan; Hamazaki, Ryoichi, Toshiba Corporation, Tokyo, Japan; Kudinov, P. I., The Royal Institute of Technology (KTH), Stockholm, Sweden
Abstract: In advanced designs of Nuclear Power Plants (NPPs), for mitigation of severe accident consequences, on the one hand, the In-Vessel Retention (IVR) concept has been implemented. On the other hand in other new NPP designs (Generation HI and III+) with large power reactors, the External Core Catcher (ECC) has been widely adopted. Assessment of ECC design robustness is largely based on analysis of heat transfer of a melt pool formed in the ECC. Transient heat transfer analysis of an ECC is challenging due to (i) uncertainty in the in-vessel accident progression and subsequent vessel failure modes; (ii) long transient, (iii) high Rayleigh number and complex flows involving phase change of the melt pool formed in an ECC. The present paper is concerned with analysis of transient melt pool heat transfer in the ECC of new Advanced Boiling Water Reactor (ABWR) designed by Toshiba Corporation (Japan). According to the ABWR severe accident management strategy, the ECC is initially dry. In order to prevent steam explosion flooding is initiated after termination of melt relocation from the vessel. The ECC full of melt is cooled from the top directly by water and from the bottom through the ECC walls. In order to assess sustainability of the ECC, heat transfer simulation of a stratified melt pool formed in the ECC is carried out. The problem addressed in this work is heat flux distribution at ECC boundaries when cooling is applied (i) from the bottom, (ii) from the top and from the bottom. To perform melt pool heat transfer simulation, we employ Phase-change Effective Convectivity Model (PECM) which was originally developed as a computationally efficient, sufficiently accurate, 2D/3D accident analysis tools for simulation of transient melt pool heat transfer in the reactor lower plenum. Thermal loads from the melt pool to ECC boundaries are determined for selected ex-vessel accident scenarios. Performance of the ECC, efficiency of severe accident management (SAM) measures and procedures are evaluated based on results of PECM simulation and severe accident analysis. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.T., Nguyen, Tat Thang; T., Nobuyoshi, Tsuzuki; H., Murakawa, Hideki; A., Povolny, Antonin; D., Hai, Duongngoc; H., Kikura, Hiroshige
Author full names: Nguyen, Tat Thang (57202141742); Nobuyoshi, Tsuzuki (57136725500); Murakawa, Hideki (7005035162); Povolny, Antonin (56422446400); Hai, Duongngoc (57192157680); Kikura, Hiroshige (35597037700)
Title: The principle and preliminary evaluation of a multiwave ultrasonic method for the measurement of the condensation rate in subcooled flow boiling
Source title: International Conference on Nuclear Engineering, Proceedings, ICONE
Affiliations: Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Kobe University, Kobe, Japan; Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Tat Thang, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Nobuyoshi, Tsuzuki, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Murakawa, Hideki, Kobe University, Kobe, Japan; Povolny, Antonin, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Hai, Duongngoc, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kikura, Hiroshige, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: The condensation rate of vapor bubbles, defined by v<inf>c</inf>=-dR/dt where R is the bubble radius (assuming that bubbles have a spherical shape) and t is time, is an important parameter to determine the heat/mass transfer in the subcooled flow boiling. Accurate measurement of v<inf>c</inf> is required to improve the numerical simulation of the flow. In this study, using multiwave ultrasound, a novel method has been developed for the measurement of v<inf>c</inf>. The velocity of the top and bottom interfaces of bubbles are measured by using two measurement lines. One line has an upward direction. The other has a downward direction. From the velocity difference between the two measurement lines, v<inf>c</inf> can be calculated. By comparison with the result of the optical visualization method, the accuracy of the measured data of v<inf>c</inf> is confirmed. Using ultrasound, measurements can be carried out for opaque fluid, non-transparent flow boundaries and extreme conditions of industrial flows (e.g. high pressure, high temperature etc.). The proposed method can be highly useful to provide validation data to improve existing correlations used in numerical simulation. Consequently, the accuracy of the numerical simulation result can be improved. That is immensely important in the thermal-hydraulic analysis in nuclear engineering. © 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: P.H., Liem, Peng Hong; H.N., Tran, Hoai Nam; H., Sekimoto, Hiroshi
Author full names: Liem, Peng Hong (6603970138); Tran, Hoai Nam (15926474700); Sekimoto, Hiroshi (7101662791)
Title: Use of PA-231 for axial power distribution flattening of thorium fuel candle high temperature gas-cooled reactors
Source title: International Conference on Nuclear Engineering, Proceedings, ICONE
Affiliations: Nippon Advanced Information Service, Naka, Japan; Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Tokyo City University, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Liem, Peng Hong, Nippon Advanced Information Service, Naka, Japan; Tran, Hoai Nam, Institute of Research and Development, Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Sekimoto, Hiroshi, Tokyo City University, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: The innovative CANDLE (Constant Axial shape of Neutron flux, nuclide densities and power shape During Life of Energy producing reactor) burnup strategy has been successfully applied to both fast and thermal reactors. In particular for thermal reactor applications, CANDLE blocktype high temperature gas-cooled reactors (HTGRs) with either uranium or thorium fuel cycle had been proposed and investigated for their simple and safe reactor operation, and the ease of designing a long life reactor. Small sized long life CANDLE HTGRs with thorium fuel shows superior burnup performance than the ones with uranium fuel but their axial power peaks are relatively higher which may not be advantageous during a depressurization accident. In this work, we proposed and investigated the use of Pa-231 mixed homogeneously in the (Th-232/U-233)O<inf>2</inf> fuel kernel of the TRISO particles to obtain lower axial power peaks. Addition of Pa-231 decreases the required amount of natural gadolinium burnable poison in the fresh fuel for establishing a valid CANDLE HTGR design since Pa-231 has a large thermal absorption cross section. Besides the role as a burnable poison nuclide, Pa-231 also serves as a fertile nuclide during the CANDLE burning since Pa-231 is finally transmuted to a fissile U-233 nuclide. A promising analysis result shows that for U-233 enrichment of 15 w/o and Pa-231 addition of 7.50 w/o, the axial power peak is decreased from 5.9 to 3.6 W/cm3 while the averaged burnup is increased from 138 to 149 GWd/t. This extends the core life time about 16 %, i.e. from 35 to 41 years with CANDLE active core height of 800 cm and reactor thermal power of 30 MWth. © 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: D.C., Phan, Dinh Chung; S., Yamamoto, Shigeru
Author full names: Phan, Dinh Chung (55631872800); Yamamoto, Shigeru (35231184800)
Title: Maximum energy output of a DFIG wind turbine using an improved MPPT-curve method
Affiliations: University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Kanazawa University, Kanazawa, Japan; Kanazawa University, Kanazawa, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Phan, Dinh Chung, Faculty of Electrical Engineering, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam, Division of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Kanazawa University, Kanazawa, Japan; Yamamoto, Shigeru, Faculty of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Kanazawa University, Kanazawa, Japan
Abstract: A new method is proposed for obtaining the maximum power output of a doubly-fed induction generator (DFIG) wind turbine to control the rotor- and grid-side converters. The efficiency of maximum power point tracking that is obtained by the proposed method is theoretically guaranteed under assumptions that represent physical conditions. Several control parameters may be adjusted to ensure the quality of control performance. In particular, a DFIG state-space model and a control technique based on the Lyapunov function are adopted to derive the control method. The effectiveness of the proposed method is verified via numerical simulations of a 1.5-MW DFIG wind turbine using MATLAB/Simulink. The simulation results show that when the proposed method is used, the wind turbine is capable of properly tracking the optimal operation point; furthermore, the generator's available energy output is higher when the proposed method is used than it is when the conventional method is used instead. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: K., Mizutani, Keisuke; S., Ibata, Satowa; Y., Aoyama, Yuko; Y., Ikeda, Yoshiho; N., He, Ngovan
Author full names: Mizutani, Keisuke (56911824200); Ibata, Satowa (56912453100); Aoyama, Yuko (56911839800); Ikeda, Yoshiho (7404015384); He, Ngovan (55850920700)
Title: A role of spray on the added resistance acting on a blunt-bow ship in head waves
Source title: Proceedings of the International Offshore and Polar Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Sanoyas Shipbuilding Corporation, Kurashiki, Japan; Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Mizutani, Keisuke, Sanoyas Shipbuilding Corporation, Kurashiki, Japan; Ibata, Satowa, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Aoyama, Yuko, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Ikeda, Yoshiho, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; He, Ngovan, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: In the present paper, added resistance acting on a chip carrier with blunt bow form running in short head waves is investigated, and an appendage to reduce the added resistance is developed. It is revealed that spray which appears at blunt bow at the moment when the crest of the incident waves hits the bow causes a part of the added resistance. CFD calculations can predict the spray. By using the calculated pressure distributions, the appendage can be designed to reduce the added resistance by 10-15%. © 2015 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.D., Xuan, T. D.; N.T., Phuong, Nguyen Thi; D.T., Khang, Do Tan; T.D., Khanh, Tran Dang
Author full names: Xuan, T. D. (7003473828); Phuong, Nguyen Thi (56906738900); Khang, Do Tan (56906762800); Khanh, Tran Dang (6603569488)
Title: Influence of sowing times, densities, and soils to biomass and ethanol yield of sweet sorghum
Affiliations: Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan; Vietnam Academy of Agricultural Sciences (VAAS), Hanoi, Viet Nam; Agricultural Genetics Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Xuan, T. D., Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan; Phuong, Nguyen Thi, Vietnam Academy of Agricultural Sciences (VAAS), Hanoi, Viet Nam; Khang, Do Tan, Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan; Khanh, Tran Dang, Agricultural Genetics Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: The use of biofuels helps to reduce the dependency on fossil fuels and therefore decreases CO<inf>2</inf> emission. Ethanol mixed with gasoline in mandatory percentages has been used in many countries. However, production of ethanol mainly depends on food crops, commonly associated with problems such as governmental policies and social controversies. Sweet sorghum (Sorghum bicolor (L.) Moench) is one of the most potential and appropriate alternative crops for biofuel production because of its high biomass and sugar content, strong tolerance to environmental stress conditions and diseases, and wide adaptability to various soils and climates. The aim of this study was to select prospective varieties of sweet sorghum, optimum sowing times and densities to achieve high yields of ethanol production and to establish stable operational conditions in cultivating this crop. The summer-autumn cropping season combined with the sowing densities of 8.3-10.9 plant m-2 obtained the highest ethanol yield. Among cultivated locations, the soil with pH of 5.5 and contents of Al and Zn of 39.4 and 0.6 g kg-1, respectively, was the best condition to have an ethanol yield >5000 L ha-1. The pH ≥ 6.0 may be responsible for the significant reduction of zinc content in soils, which decreases both biomass of sweet sorghum and ethanol yield, while contents of N, P, K, organic carbon (OC) and cation exchange capacity (CEC), and Fe likely play no role. The cultivar 4A was the preferred candidate for ethanol production and resistant to pests and diseases, especially cut worm (Agrotis spp.). © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T., Kato, Takaaki; A.Q., Tran, Anh Quan; H., Hoang, Haihai

Title: Factors affecting voluntary participation in food residue recycling: A case study in Da Nang, Viet Nam
Affiliations: The University of Kitakyushu, Kitakyushu, Japan; The University of Kitakyushu, Kitakyushu, Japan; Da Nang University, Da Nang, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Kato, Takaaki, The University of Kitakyushu, Kitakyushu, Japan; Tran, Anh Quan, Graduate School of Environmental Engineering, The University of Kitakyushu, Kitakyushu, Japan; Hoang, Haihai, International Cooperation Department, Da Nang University, Da Nang, Viet Nam
Abstract: This study investigated the factors affecting participation in food residue recycling in Da Nang City, Viet Nam. Since involvement of citizens in food residue recycling in developed countries usually requires government interventions such as sanctions for non-participants, this study is unique in that it seeks to identify factors influencing voluntary participation in this activity, as no government intervention exists regarding food residue recycling in Da Nang City. We considered microeconomic, psychological, and traditional factors. Some of the microeconomic factors consistently explained our results using a social survey of 142 randomly selected households. Psychological factors affected participation in some model specifications. None of the variables in the tradition category were found to be statistically significant. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H.N., Tran, Hoai Nam; P.H., Liem, Peng Hong
Author full names: Tran, Hoai Nam (15926474700); Liem, Peng Hong (6603970138)
Title: Neutronic feasibility study of U-Th-Pa based high burnup fuel for pebble bed reactors
Affiliations: Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Nippon Advanced Information Service, Naka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tran, Hoai Nam, Institute of Research and Development, Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Liem, Peng Hong, Nippon Advanced Information Service, Naka, Japan
Abstract: Neutronic feasibility study of U-Th-Pa based high burnup fuel for the pebble bed reactors has been carried out. An additional content of P231a in a mixed U233-T232h fuel pebble was optimized for simultaneously controlling long-term excess reactivity and attaining high fuel burnup. Because of a large thermal absorption cross section, P231a has a potential to absorb thermal neutrons and act as a burnable absorber in the early stage of burnup. In the latter stage, P231a is transmuted to U233 and act as a fertile fuel. Parametric study was performed for heavy metal (HM) amount, U233 enrichment and P231a content. The objective is to attain a target burnup greater than 100 GWd/T with a low uranium enrichment and a small content of P231a. Six fuel compositions with the HM amount of 9-18 g per pebble, the U233 enrichment of 8 and 10%, and the P231a content of 3.2-5.5% were selected for discussion and comparison. The burnup levels of about 130-170 GWd/t are achieved for the six fuel compositions. The results of temperature coefficient show that negative reactivity feedback during burnup with the increase of temperature is assured, which is one of the important safety parameters. © 2014 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.M., Vu, Thanh Mai; T., Kitada, Takanori
Author full names: Vu, Thanh Mai (55619332100); Kitada, Takanori (7102744350)
Title: Seed and blanket thorium-reprocessed fuel ADS: Multi-cycle approach for higher thorium utilization and TRU transmutation
Affiliations: The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Vu, Thanh Mai, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kitada, Takanori, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan
Abstract: In the previous publication, the seed and blanket thorium-reprocessed fuel ADS was designed for efficient transmutation of TRU waste from the spent nuclear fuel. In this study, the multi-cycle core was designed in order to increase thorium utilization and TRU waste transmutation. For that purpose, the reprocessed fuel assemblies inside the subcritical core are shuffled for twice burnt while the thorium assemblies are remained inside the reactor until the end of reactor life. As the result, at the equilibrium state, the thorium fuel contribution to total core power is improved (35.7%) compared to the startup cycle and it has benefit in flattening the power peaking inside the subcritical core. Compare to the startup cycle, less reprocessed fuel is loaded but the reprocessed assemblies are shuffled and burnt twice, hence, the TRUs are transmuted in a deeper level. At discharge, the reduction of radiotoxicity from the TRU waste is about 20% with 1% uncertainty, mainly due to the reduction of Pu and Am. © 2014 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: P.D., Luu, Phuongduc Duc; H.T., Truong, Hoa Thi; L., van Boi, Luu; P.N., Lan, Pham Ngoc; K., Imamura, Kiyoshi; N., Takenaka, Norimichi; Y., Maeda, Yasuaki
Author full names: Luu, Phuongduc Duc (56385435700); Truong, Hoa Thi (56385221700); van Boi, Luu (6507028401); Lan, Pham Ngoc (56385210900); Imamura, Kiyoshi (57202410922); Takenaka, Norimichi (7007012272); Maeda, Yasuaki (55797766600)
Title: Production of biodiesel from Vietnamese Jatropha curcas oil by a co-solvent method
Affiliations: Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Luu, Phuongduc Duc, Department of Applied Chemistry, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan, Faculty of Chemistry, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Truong, Hoa Thi, Danang Environmental Technology Center, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; van Boi, Luu, Faculty of Chemistry, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Lan, Pham Ngoc, Faculty of Chemistry, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Imamura, Kiyoshi, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Takenaka, Norimichi, Department of Applied Chemistry, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Maeda, Yasuaki, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan
Abstract: Biodiesel fuels (BDFs) was successfully produced from Vietnamese Jatropha curcas oil with high content of free fatty acids (FFAs) in two stages. In the first stage, the esterification process was carried out with the optimal conditions as follows; a methanol-to-FFAs molar ratio of 6:1, 1wt% H<inf>2</inf>SO<inf>4</inf>, at a temperature of 65°C, and using 30% (wt/wt) acetonitrile as co-solvent. This step reduced the concentration of FFAs in the reaction mixture from 15.93 to 2wt% in 60min. In the second stage, the transesterification process generated fatty acid methyl esters (FAMEs) with 99% efficiency was performed in 30min with the optimal conditions as follows; a methanol-to-oil molar ratio of 6:1, 1wt% KOH, at a temperature of 40°C, and 20% (wt/wt) acetone as co-solvent. The produced biodiesel quality meets the standards JIS K2390 and EN 14214 regarding FAME yield, FFAs and water contents. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H., Le, Hungminh; H., Hirao, Hajime; Y., Kawazoe, Yoshiyuki; D., Nguyen-Manh, Duc
Author full names: Le, Hungminh (24332141100); Hirao, Hajime (8589167900); Kawazoe, Yoshiyuki (57208764411); Nguyen-Manh, Duc (7003528210)
Title: Nanostructures of C60-metal-graphene (metal = Ti, Cr, Mn, Fe, or Ni): A spin-polarized density functional theory study
Affiliations: School of Chemistry, Chemical Engineering and Biotechnology, Singapore City, Singapore; University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Institute of Thermophysics, Siberian Branch, Russian Academy of Sciences, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Culham Centre for Fusion Energy, Abingdon, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Le, Hungminh, School of Chemistry, Chemical Engineering and Biotechnology, Singapore City, Singapore, Faculty of Materials Science, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Hirao, Hajime, School of Chemistry, Chemical Engineering and Biotechnology, Singapore City, Singapore; Kawazoe, Yoshiyuki, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan, Institute of Thermophysics, Siberian Branch, Russian Academy of Sciences, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Nguyen-Manh, Duc, Theory and Modeling Department, Culham Centre for Fusion Energy, Abingdon, United Kingdom
Abstract: We used plane-wave density functional theory (DFT) to investigate the properties of C<inf>60</inf>-M-graphene (C<inf>60</inf>-M-G) nanostructures (M = Ti, Cr, Mn, Fe, or Ni). The calculated binding energies suggested that C<inf>60</inf> could be mounted on a metal-graphene surface with good bonding stability. The high-spin C<inf>60</inf>-Cr-G nanostructure was found to be more stable than the previously reported low-spin configuration. Also, C<inf>60</inf>-Ti was found to stand symmetrically upright on the graphene surface, while in the remaining four cases, the orientation of C<inf>60</inf>-M in the C<inf>60</inf>-M-G nanostructures were bent, and the geometry of each structure is somewhat different, depending on the identity of the bridging metal atom. The large geometric distortion of C<inf>60</inf>-M in the tilted C<inf>60</inf>-M-G nanostructures (with Cr, Fe, Mn, and Ni) is attributed to the spin polarization in the 3d orbitals and dispersion interactions between graphene and C<inf>60</inf>. Additional DFT calculations on smaller C<inf>60</inf>-M-benzene complexes with atomic-orbital (AO) basis sets provided consistent results on structural geometry and numbers of unpaired electrons. The DFT calculations using AO basis sets suggested that the C<inf>60</inf>-M unit was flexible with respect to the bending motion. The knowledge of metal-dependent geometric differences derived in this study may be useful in designing nanostructures for spintronic and electronic applications. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H.V., Khai, Huynh Viet; M., Yabe, Mitsuyasu
Author full names: Khai, Huynh Viet (57223953396); Yabe, Mitsuyasu (7005872026)
Title: Choice modeling: assessing the non-market environmental values of the biodiversity conservation of swamp forest in Vietnam
Source title: International Journal of Energy and Environmental Engineering
Affiliations: Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Khai, Huynh Viet, Agricultural, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Yabe, Mitsuyasu, Department of Agricultural and Resource Economics, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan
Abstract: The study investigated the economic value of biodiversity attributes that could provide policy makers reliable information to estimate welfare losses due to biodiversity reductions and analyze the trade-off between biodiversity and economics. To obtain the non-market benefits of biodiversity conservation, an indirect utility function and willingness to pay for biodiversity attributes were applied using the approach of choice modeling with the analysis of multinomial logit model. The study found that Mekong Delta residents accepted their willingness to pay of VND 913 monthly for a 1 % increase in healthy vegetation, VND 360 for an additional mammal species and VND 2,440 to avoid the welfare losses of 100 local farmers. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: K.P., Nguyen, Khai Phuc; G., Fujita, Goro; D.T., Nguyen, Duc Tuyen; V.N., Dieu, Vo Ngoc; T., Funabashi, Toshihisa
Author full names: Nguyen, Khai Phuc (55596378500); Fujita, Goro (36186886000); Nguyen, Duc Tuyen (58279068400); Dieu, Vo Ngoc (57203922022); Funabashi, Toshihisa (7005032678)
Title: Optimal placement and sizing of SVC by using various meta-heuristic optimization methods
Affiliations: Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HUTECH, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nagoya University, Nagoya, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Khai Phuc, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan; Fujita, Goro, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan; Nguyen, Duc Tuyen, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan; Dieu, Vo Ngoc, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HUTECH, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Funabashi, Toshihisa, Nagoya University, Nagoya, Japan
Abstract: This paper presents comparison of three kinds of meta-heuristic optimization to determine location and sizing of Static Var Compensator (SVC). The optimization methods are Particle Swarm Organization (PSO), Improved Harmony Search (IHS) and Cuckoo Search Algorithm (CSA). The multi-objective function of this problem considers loss power, voltage deviation and operational cost of SVC. All of methods are tested on three types of IEEE power systems, such as 9-bus case, 30-bus case and 57-bus case. Results show that the CSA does not only gives better solution than others do, but it also has better performance, while the IHS is more effective than the version of PSO. © 2015 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H.Q., Pham, Hung Q.; T., Mai, Toan; N.N., Pham-Tran, Nguyen Nguyen; Y., Kawazoe, Yoshiyuki; H., Mizuseki, Hiroshi; D., Nguyen-Manh, Duc
Author full names: Pham, Hung Q. (56102304700); Mai, Toan (56102350000); Pham-Tran, Nguyen Nguyen (6602332341); Kawazoe, Yoshiyuki (57208764411); Mizuseki, Hiroshi (7007024371); Nguyen-Manh, Duc (7003528210)
Title: Engineering of band gap in metal-organic frameworks by functionalizing organic linker: A systematic density functional theory investigation
Affiliations: University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Viện Khoa học và Công nghệ Tính toán, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Molecular and NanoArchitecture Center, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Institute for Materials Research, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Culham Centre for Fusion Energy, Abingdon, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Pham, Hung Q., Faculty of Chemistry, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viện Khoa học và Công nghệ Tính toán, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Molecular and NanoArchitecture Center, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Mai, Toan, Faculty of Chemistry, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Pham-Tran, Nguyen Nguyen, Faculty of Chemistry, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viện Khoa học và Công nghệ Tính toán, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Kawazoe, Yoshiyuki, Institute for Materials Research, Institute for Materials Research, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Mizuseki, Hiroshi, Institute for Materials Research, Institute for Materials Research, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Nguyen-Manh, Duc, Theory and Modeling Department, Culham Centre for Fusion Energy, Abingdon, United Kingdom
Abstract: A systematic investigation on electronic band structure of a series of isoreticular metal-organic frameworks (IRMOFs) using density functional theory has been carried out. Our results show that halogen atoms can be used as functional groups to tune not only the band gap but also the valence band maximum (VBM) in MOFs. Among halogen atoms (F, Cl, Br, I), iodine is the best candidate to reduce the band gap and increase the VBM value. In addition, it has been found that for the antiaromatic linker DHPDC (1,4-dihydropentalene-2,5- dicarboxylic acid) the energy gap is 0.95 eV, which is even lower than those calculated for other aromatic linkers, i.e., FFDC (furo[3,2-b]furan-2,5- dicarboxylic acid) and TTDC (thieno[3,2-b]thiophene-2,5-dicarboxylic acid). By analyzing the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital-highest occupied molecular orbital gaps calculated at the molecular level, we have highlighted the important role of the corresponding organic linkers in the MOF band gap. In particular, the change of C-C-Cî - ?O dihedral angle in the organic linker can be used to analyze the difference of band gaps in MOF crystals. It is shown that a deep understanding of chemical bonding within linker molecules from electronic structure calculations plays a crucial role in designing semiconductor properties of MOF materials for engineering applications. © 2014 American Chemical Society. © 2014 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: A.R., Trihamdani, Andhang Rakhmat; H.S., Lee, Han Soo; T.T.T., Phuong, Tran Thi Thu; T., Kubota, Tetsu; T., Tanaka, Takahiro; K., Matsuo, Kaoru
Author full names: Trihamdani, Andhang Rakhmat (57131148500); Lee, Han Soo (57067175200); Phuong, Tran Thi Thu (57130425100); Kubota, Tetsu (23025368600); Tanaka, Takahiro (57218641068); Matsuo, Kaoru (56982373900)
Title: The cooling effect of green strategies proposed in the Hanoi master plan for mitigation of urban heat island
Affiliations: Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan; Saitama University, Saitama, Japan; Vietnam Institute Urban and Rural Planning, Viet Nam; Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Trihamdani, Andhang Rakhmat, Graduate School for IDEC, Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan; Lee, Han Soo, Graduate School of Science and Engineering, Saitama University, Saitama, Japan; Phuong, Tran Thi Thu, Vietnam Institute Urban and Rural Planning, Viet Nam; Kubota, Tetsu, Graduate School for IDEC, Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan; Tanaka, Takahiro, Graduate School of Engineering, Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan; Matsuo, Kaoru, Graduate School of Engineering, Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan
Abstract: This study aims to assess the impacts of land use changes brought by the Hanoi Master Plan on its urban climate using the Weather Research and Forecasting (WRF), focusing on the cooling effect of the green strategies that were proposed in the master plan. The results show that even after implementing the master plan, the peak air temperature in the urban areas still remains at the same level of 41°C. However, the expansion of built-up areas largely increases the UHI intensity and raises the nocturnal air temperatures in the built-up areas. The centralized green spaces proposed in the master plan is seen to be insufficient to mitigate UHIs compared to the equally distributed green spaces. The urban air temperature in Hanoi is increased when the westerly or south-westerly Foehn winds flow over the city during the daytime. In contrast, relatively strong and cool southerly winds prevail during the night-time and contribute to reduction in the nocturnal air temperature in the city. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Co-solvent method produce biodiesel form waste cooking oil with small pilot plant
Affiliations: Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Luu, Phuongduc Duc, Department of Applied Chemistry, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan, Faculty of Chemistry, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Takenaka, Norimichi, Department of Applied Chemistry, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; van Boi, Luu, Faculty of Chemistry, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Lan, Pham Ngoc, Faculty of Chemistry, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Imamura, Kiyoshi, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Maeda, Yasuaki, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan
Abstract: In this study, we studied the production of biodiesel from waste cooking oil with co-solvent technology. A co-solvent technology with acetone has many advantage, but needs to remove solvents dissolved in the mixture. The optimum transesterification conditions to obtain the 98% purity of fatty acid methyl esters (FAMEs) are as follows: 1 wt.% potassium hydroxide catalyst, 20wt.% acetone and 5:1 methanol to oil molar ratio, reaction temperature of 400C and reaction time of 30 minutes. The water content is 104 ppm, methanol content in the final product 95 ppm, and the concentration of acetone in the products 247 ppm. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.M., Vu, Thanh Mai; T., Kitada, Takanori
Author full names: Vu, Thanh Mai (55619332100); Kitada, Takanori (7102744350)
Title: Impact of thorium capture cross section uncertainty on the thorium utilized ADS reactivity calculation
Source title: Science and Technology of Nuclear Installations
Affiliations: The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Vu, Thanh Mai, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kitada, Takanori, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan
Abstract: Recently, the researches on fast neutron spectrum system utilized thorium fuel are widely conducted. However, the recent thorium cross section libraries are limited compared to uranium cross section libraries. The impact of thorium cross section uncertainty on thorium fuel utilized accelerator driven system (ADS) reactivity calculation is estimated in this study. The uncertainty of the k<inf>eff</inf> caused by 232 Thcapture cross section of JENDL-4.0 is about 1.3%. The uncertainty of JENDL-4.0 is needed to be enhanced to provide more reliable results on reactivity calculation for the fast system. The impact of uncertainty of 232Th capture cross section of ENDF/B-VII is small (0.1%). Therefore, it will cause no significant impact of the thorium cross section library on the thorium utilized ADS design calculation. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
