Authors: N.T., Dinh, Nga Thi; K., Hatta, Kohei; S.H., Kwon, Sang Hagk; A.P., Rollon, Analiza Palenzuela; K., Nakasaki, Kiyohiko
Author full names: Dinh, Nga Thi (57209019546); Hatta, Kohei (56275807200); Kwon, Sang Hagk (55645272400); Rollon, Analiza Palenzuela (24725389000); Nakasaki, Kiyohiko (35560623900)
Title: Changes in the microbial community during the acclimation stages of the methane fermentation for the treatment of glycerol
Affiliations: Ho Chi Minh City University of Natural Resources and Environment, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; University of the Philippines Diliman, Quezon City, Philippines
Authors with affiliations: Dinh, Nga Thi, Department of Research and Development and External Relations, Ho Chi Minh City University of Natural Resources and Environment, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Hatta, Kohei, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Kwon, Sang Hagk, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Rollon, Analiza Palenzuela, Department of Chemical Engineering, University of the Philippines Diliman, Quezon City, Philippines; Nakasaki, Kiyohiko, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Granular sludge from a full-scale methane reactor treating brewery wastewater was used as a seed for the treatment of glycerol in a laboratory-scale repeated-batch methane reactor, and the change in the microbial community during the acclimation stages was examined. Two types of substrate solutions, a glucose, sodium acetate, and lactic acid mixture, as well as glycerol, were prepared and fed by mixing the two solutions to increase the ratio, in a stepwise manner, of glycerol from 0% to 100%, while keeping a loading of COD at 2.5kgm-3d-1 throughout the fermentation process. Vigorous methane gas production, approximately 580dm3m-3d-1, was observed during the acclimation stages. Microbial analysis revealed that both bacterial and archaeal communities changed significantly; bacteria (genus Trichococcus and family Syntrophomonadaceae) became dominant rapidly after the start of acclimation, and archaea belonging to the hydrogenotrophic methanogens (genera Methanobacterium and Methanospirillum), increased gradually with the progress of acclimation. © 2014 Elsevier Ltd. © 2014 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: L., Khuong, Leduy; R., Kondo, Ryuichiro; R.D., Leon, Rizalinda De; K.A., To, Kim Anh; S., Meguro, Sadatoshi; K., Shimizu, Kuniyoshi; I., Kamei, Ichiro
Author full names: Khuong, Leduy (59845964000); Kondo, Ryuichiro (7102405123); Leon, Rizalinda De (56223731300); To, Kim Anh (57206415596); Meguro, Sadatoshi (7004958749); Shimizu, Kuniyoshi (7404960600); Kamei, Ichiro (55083269100)
Title: Effect of chemical factors on integrated fungal fermentation of sugarcane bagasse for ethanol production by a white-rot fungus, Phlebia sp. MG-60
Affiliations: University of the Philippines Diliman, Quezon City, Philippines; Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; University of Miyazaki, Miyazaki, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Khuong, Leduy, Department of Chemical Engineering, University of the Philippines Diliman, Quezon City, Philippines, Center for Research and Development in Biotechnology, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kondo, Ryuichiro, Department of Agro-environmental Sciences, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Leon, Rizalinda De, Department of Chemical Engineering, University of the Philippines Diliman, Quezon City, Philippines; To, Kim Anh, Center for Research and Development in Biotechnology, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Meguro, Sadatoshi, Department of Forest and Environmental Sciences, University of Miyazaki, Miyazaki, Japan; Shimizu, Kuniyoshi, Department of Agro-environmental Sciences, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Kamei, Ichiro, Department of Forest and Environmental Sciences, University of Miyazaki, Miyazaki, Japan
Abstract: Bioethanol production through integrated fungal fermentation (IFF), involving a unified process for biological delignification with consolidated biological processing by the white-rot fungus Phlebia sp. MG-60, was applied to sugarcane bagasse. Initial moisture content of the bagasse was found to affect biological delignification by MG-60, and 75% moisture content was suitable for selective lignin degradation and subsequent ethanol production. Additives, such as basal media, organic compounds, or minerals, also affected biological delignification of bagasse by MG-60. Basal medium addition improved both delignification and ethanol production. Some inorganic chemical factors, such as Fe2+, Mn2+, or Cu2+, reduced bagasse carbohydrate degradation by MG-60 during delignifying incubations and resulted in increased ethanol production. The present results indicated that suitable culture conditions could significantly improve IFF efficiency. © 2014 Elsevier Ltd. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T., Kato, Takaaki; E., Himeshima, Eri; H., Hoang, Haihai; V.Q., Tran, Van Quang; H., Nakamura, Hidenori
Author full names: Kato, Takaaki (57203309724); Himeshima, Eri (56200555300); Hoang, Haihai (59454667100); Tran, Van Quang (59884853100); Nakamura, Hidenori (56468386800)
Title: Environmental information and propensity to help developing countries: An experimental survey of citizens in Kitakyushu, Japan
Affiliations: The University of Kitakyushu, Kitakyushu, Japan; Environmental Restoration and Conservation Agency, Kawasaki, Japan; University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Da Nang University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Nagoya University, Nagoya, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kato, Takaaki, The University of Kitakyushu, Kitakyushu, Japan; Himeshima, Eri, Environmental Restoration and Conservation Agency, Kawasaki, Japan; Hoang, Haihai, International Cooperation Department, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Tran, Van Quang, Department of Environment, Da Nang University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Nakamura, Hidenori, Graduate School of Environmental Studies, Nagoya University, Nagoya, Japan
Abstract: Japanese municipalities have provided significant support for improving environment to developing countries. The motivation behind this study was that the growing requirements for Japanese local governments to gain support from citizens might cause a problem. The problem was the disparity between donor citizens and recipients in the aid envisioned. In our social survey, we investigated the views of citizens in Kitakyushu, Japan, within a specific context of helping large Vietnamese cities. In particular, we mentioned Da Nang City as an example. Many of our respondents chose "drinking water quality," "river/sea pollution," and "waste management" as important environmental problems in the Vietnamese cities. These problems were in line with those officially recognized by the administrators of Da Nang. However, there were sharp differences in perceived environmental problems between the respondents and urban dwellers in Da Nang. Background knowledge of Vietnam, owing to previous visits there, and of Kitakyushu's aid activities in the country clearly affected the choices of the important environmental problems. Provision of information on the environment in Da Nang changed the ranking among the top four problems, but the items within the set remained the same as before. Both knowledge gained as a result of visiting Vietnam and knowledge of Kitakyushu's aid activities in the country contributed to maintaining initial views after the presentation of the Da Nang information. The implications of these results in citizen education by municipalities are discussed with reference to the ideas of problem-based learning. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.H., Bui, Thi Hang; D., Thang, Doanha; N.T., Nga, Nguyen Tuyet; P.T.L., Minh, Phan Thi Le; E., Kobayashi, Eiji

Title: Nanoparticle Fe2O3-loaded carbon nanofibers as iron-air battery anodes
Affiliations: International Training Institute for Materials Science, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Physics and Electronics, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hanoi Medical University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan

Abstract: We prepared nanoparticle Fe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf>-loaded carbon nanofiber material by a chemical method. Fe(NO<inf>3</inf>)<inf>3</inf> was impregnated on carbon in an aqueous solution, and the mixture was dried and then calcined for 1 h at 400°C in flowing Ar. The herringbone carbon nanofiber and mesoporous carbon nanofiber with large actual surface area were used to increase the dispersion of iron on the carbon surface. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) coupled with X-ray diffraction measurements revealed that nano-sized Fe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> particles were distributed on the carbon surface and that many nano-sized Fe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> species were present inside the pores on the mesoporous carbon surface. Such dispersion of nano-sized Fe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> will support the redox reaction of iron and result in improved capacity of Fe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf>-loaded carbon electrodes. © 2013 The Electrochemical Society. All rights reserved. © 2013 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: V.Q., Bui, Viet Quoc; H., Le, Hungminh; Y., Kawazoe, Yoshiyuki; D., Nguyen-Manh, Duc
Author full names: Bui, Viet Quoc (55602465800); Le, Hungminh (24332141100); Kawazoe, Yoshiyuki (57208764411); Nguyen-Manh, Duc (7003528210)
Title: Graphene-Cr-graphene intercalation nanostructures: Stability and magnetic properties from density functional theory investigations
Affiliations: University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Culham Centre for Fusion Energy, Abingdon, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Bui, Viet Quoc, Faculty of Materials Science, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Le, Hungminh, Faculty of Materials Science, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Kawazoe, Yoshiyuki, New Industry Creation Hatchery Center, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Nguyen-Manh, Duc, Theory and Modeling Department, Culham Centre for Fusion Energy, Abingdon, United Kingdom
Abstract: A theoretical investigation of two-dimensional graphene-Cr-graphene intercalation nanostructures has been carried out using density functional theory (DFT) calculations. The intercalation nanostructures of interest are classified based on the atomic ratio of Cr with respect to C on two graphene layers, and we accordingly assign nomenclatures to the intercalation nanostructures as 1-4, 1-12, and 1-16 GMG. Binding energy analysis suggests that the 1-12 and 1-16 GMG structures are energetically stable, whereas the 1-4 GMG structure is unstable. When examining the 1-4 bilayer graphene-Cr (GGM) structure, we have found that it is energetically stable and nonmagnetic. On the other hand, all three GMG intercalation structures are found to be ferromagnetic, and the 1-16 GMG structure exhibits the highest total magnetization (2.00 μ<inf>B</inf>/cell), whereas the 1-12 GMG structure exhibits the lowest total magnetization (0.46 μ<inf>B</inf>/cell). Interplays between stability and magnetic properties of these three nanostructures are discussed from electronic structure analysis. It is found for the two stable nanostructures that the 2p<inf>z</inf> orbitals of graphene layers are aligned antiferromagnetically with respect to the Cr layer, thus causing negative contributions to total magnetic moments of two stable GMG nanostructures. © 2013 American Chemical Society. © 2013 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Study of plutonium recycling scheme with uranium multi-recycling system
Affiliations: Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Institute for Nuclear Research Vietnam, Dalat, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Nakamura, Takeshi, Department of Applied Quantum Physics and Nuclear Engineering, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Vo Doan, Hai Dang, Institute for Nuclear Research Vietnam, Dalat, Viet Nam; Kotoh, Kenji, Department of Applied Quantum Physics and Nuclear Engineering, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan
Abstract: We have considered a fuel cycle scheme for multi-recycling of plutonium recovered from spent UO<inf>2</inf> fuels of LWRs. Plutonium is to be partially loaded into the next LWRs in the form of MOX fuels with UO<inf>2</inf> fuels made by re-enrichment of uranium recovered from spent fuels of LWRs. We consider to recycle plutonium in combination with uranium multi-recycling system previously reported, which can provide uranium fuels for not only fully UO <inf>2</inf> fueled PWRs but also partially MOX fueled PWRs. The results of the process system analysis suggest that the proposed scheme makes it possible to recycle plutonium in succession. © 2013 The Authors. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author full names: Hong, Thong Duc (55894466300); Soerawidjaja, Tatang Hernas (6505685589); Reksowardojo, Iman Kartolaksono (6507227091); Fujita, Osamu (7004673028); Duniani, Zarrah (55894491400); Pham, Mai X. (55893654100)
Title: A study on developing aviation biofuel for the Tropics: Production process - Experimental and theoretical evaluation of their blends with fossil kerosene
Source title: Chemical Engineering and Processing - Process Intensification
Affiliations: Institut Teknologi Bandung, Bandung, Indonesia; Institut Teknologi Bandung, Bandung, Indonesia; Hokkaido University, Sapporo, Japan; Pertamina, Jakarta, Jakarta, Indonesia; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Hong, Thong Duc, Combustion Engines and Propulsion Systems Laboratory, Institut Teknologi Bandung, Bandung, Indonesia, Department of Automotive Engineering, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Soerawidjaja, Tatang Hernas, Department of Chemical Engineering, Institut Teknologi Bandung, Bandung, Indonesia; Reksowardojo, Iman Kartolaksono, Combustion Engines and Propulsion Systems Laboratory, Institut Teknologi Bandung, Bandung, Indonesia; Fujita, Osamu, Division of Mechanical and Space Engineering, Hokkaido University, Sapporo, Japan; Duniani, Zarrah, Division of Research and Development, Pertamina, Jakarta, Jakarta, Indonesia; Pham, Mai X., Department of Automotive Engineering, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Abstract: In the present work, the production process of bio-jet paraffins is appropriately proposed according to the conditions of the socioeconomic situations, the current technologies of biofuel production and the available feedstock sources for the tropical countries. The blending process of bio-kerosene which is a mixture of bio-jet paraffins and fossil kerosene is also displayed. The two prototypes of bio-paraffins (Bio-P1 and Bio-JP2), which were manufactured in Indonesia following the proposed production process, are used for making bio-kerosenes in current study. The theoretical and experimental investigations have been carried out to evaluate and identify the critical properties of bio-kerosenes: distillations, freezing point, lower heating value, density, flash point and viscosity to ensure ASTM criteria of jet fuel. The results show it can be blended directly 5% volume of Bio-P1 or 10% volume of Bio-JP2 to commercial Jet A-1 for powering aviation gas turbine engines without redesigning fuel system or fuel supply infrastructure. The use of these bio-paraffins not only reduces CO<inf>2</inf> lifecycle but also significantly decreases emissions of sulfur compounds (SO<inf>x</inf>). With preliminary achievements of this work, it is no doubt about the feasibility of developing aviation alternative fuels according to the proposed production process for the tropical countries. © 2013 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: S., Komatsu, Satoru; H., Ha, Hieudinh; S., Kaneko, Shinji
Author full names: Komatsu, Satoru (36163419900); Ha, Hieudinh (55893219500); Kaneko, Shinji (35233854900)
Title: The effects of internal migration on residential energy consumption and CO2 emissions: A case study in Hanoi
Affiliations: Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan; HCMC University of Technology and Education, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Komatsu, Satoru, Graduate School for International Development and Cooperation, Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan; Ha, Hieudinh, HCMC University of Technology and Education, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Kaneko, Shinji, Graduate School for International Development and Cooperation, Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan
Abstract: The objective of this research is to estimate the potential effects of migration on residential energy use and CO<inf>2</inf> emissions in Hanoi, Vietnam, a location in which urbanization and migration are occurring simultaneously. This article estimates the effects of migration on residential energy use and CO<inf>2</inf> emissions quantitatively, basing the probability of being a migrant on the economic, demographic and dwelling characteristics of households. The results of this study indicate that the effects of migration involve reductions in energy consumption and CO<inf>2</inf> emissions. Urban-to-urban migration is shown to have no statistically significant impact on per capita energy consumption and CO<inf>2</inf> emissions, which indicates that population increases through urban-to-urban population growth and natural population growth have no statistically significant differences in this regard. However, rural-to-urban migration is shown to have a significant and negative influence on residential energy consumption and CO<inf>2</inf> emissions. Population growth led by rural-to-urban migration produces lower energy consumption estimates than natural population growth. Thus, energy consumption estimates are lower when a city's population increase is caused by rural-to-urban migration than when urban-to-urban migration and natural population growth are the main drivers of population increases. These results have important policy implications for developing urban cities regarding population growth and energy consumption. © 2013 International Energy Initiative. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: D.C., Nguyen, Duy Cuong; K., Fukatsu, Ken; K., Tanimoto, Keiji; S., Ikeda, Shigeru; M., Matsumura, Michio; S., Ito, Seigo
Author full names: Nguyen, Duy Cuong (11339920900); Fukatsu, Ken (57213544759); Tanimoto, Keiji (55807567500); Ikeda, Shigeru (7404042302); Matsumura, Michio (7402157910); Ito, Seigo (7404825324)
Title: The effect of annealing temperature and KCN etching on the photovoltaic properties of Cu(In,Ga)(S,Se)2 solar cells using nanoparticles
Affiliations: University of Hyogo, Kobe, Japan; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Duy Cuong, Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Sciences, University of Hyogo, Kobe, Japan, Advanced Institute for Science and Technology, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Fukatsu, Ken, Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Sciences, University of Hyogo, Kobe, Japan; Tanimoto, Keiji, Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Sciences, University of Hyogo, Kobe, Japan; Ikeda, Shigeru, Research Center for Solar Energy Chemistry, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Matsumura, Michio, Research Center for Solar Energy Chemistry, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Ito, Seigo, Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Sciences, University of Hyogo, Kobe, Japan
Abstract: Cu(In,Ga)S<inf>2</inf> nanoparticles were synthesized by a hot-injection method under a low-vacuum ambience, which were printed and annealed with Se vapor for Cu(In,Ga)(S,Se)<inf>2</inf> solar cells. The Cu(In,Ga)S<inf>2</inf> nanoparticles were around 14 nm, and the stable ink was obtained by dispersing the nanoparticles in hexanethiol. The crystallinity of the Cu(In,Ga)(S,Se) <inf>2</inf> films increased with the increase in annealing temperature. Cu(In,Ga)(S,Se)<inf>2</inf> solar cells with KCN etching after annealing showed better photovoltaic properties than KCN etching before annealing and without etching. The best cell was observed at an annealing temperature of 540°C and KCN etching after annealing; the parameters of this cell were a short-circuit photocurrent density of 27.12 mA/cm2, open-circuit voltage of 0.42 V, fill factor of 0.38, and conversion efficiency of 4.3%. © 2013 Duy-Cuong Nguyen et al. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: L., Thanh, Letu; K., Okitsu, Kenji; Y., Sadanaga, Yasuhiro; N., Takenaka, Norimichi; Y., Maeda, Yasuaki; H., Bandow, Hiroshi
Author full names: Thanh, Letu (7004530789); Okitsu, Kenji (56894735200); Sadanaga, Yasuhiro (6603718076); Takenaka, Norimichi (7007012272); Maeda, Yasuaki (55797766600); Bandow, Hiroshi (7004563774)
Title: A new co-solvent method for the green production of biodiesel fuel - Optimization and practical application
Affiliations: Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Thanh, Letu, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan, Faculty of Environmental Science, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Okitsu, Kenji, Department of Materials Science, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Sadanaga, Yasuhiro, Department of Applied Chemistry, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Takenaka, Norimichi, Department of Applied Chemistry, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Maeda, Yasuaki, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Bandow, Hiroshi, Department of Applied Chemistry, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan
Abstract: An homogeneous reaction process using acetone as a co-solvent for the transesterification of vegetable oils with methanol in the presence of potassium hydroxide catalyst has been developed. The effects of the main parameters, such as the amounts of acetone and KOH, the molar ratio of methanol to oil and the reaction temperature, on fatty acid methyl esters (FAME) yield were investigated. The optimal conditions were: 25 wt.% acetone and 1.0 wt.% KOH catalyst in oil; a molar ratio of methanol to oil of 4.5:1; and a reaction temperature of 25 °C. Under these conditions, the conversion of vegetable oil to FAME exceeded 98% after 30 min. This method was applied to produce biodiesel fuel (BDF) from waste cooking oil (WCO), canola, catfish and Jatropha curcas oils, with the main product quality factors satisfying the JIS 2390 BDF standards. © 2012 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved. © 2012 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.H., Pham, Thinh H.; S.A., Boggs, Steven A.; H., Suzuki, Hironori; T., Imai, Toshiya
Author full names: Pham, Thinh H. (57213329993); Boggs, Steven A. (7102823330); Suzuki, Hironori (55704199300); Imai, Toshiya (57198841373)
Title: Effect of externally gapped line arrester placement on insulation coordination of a twin-circuit 220 kv line
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; University of Connecticut, Storrs, United States; Toshiba Corporation, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Pham, Thinh H., Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Boggs, Steven A., Electrical Insulation Research Center, University of Connecticut, Storrs, United States; Suzuki, Hironori, Surge Arrester Department, Toshiba Corporation, Tokyo, Japan; Imai, Toshiya, Surge Arrester Department, Toshiba Corporation, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Application of externally gapped lightning arresters (EGLAs) to a twin circuit 220 kV transmission line was simulated using Alternative Transients Program/Electromagnetic Transients Program. The lightning current to the tower top as well as to phase conductors was estimated using the electrogeometric model. Increasing the number of phases on which EGLAs were installed in one circuit reduces the likelihood of back flashover. Installing EGLAs on the three phases of one circuit has two advantages, viz., 1) eliminating double circuit outages and 2) preventing lightning-induced back flashovers for strikes to the tower top {\leq} 200 kA. However, EGLAs on one circuit cannot improve lightning performance related to the shielding failure when the unprotected circuit is hit. EGLA duty varied little with the number of phases on which EGLAs were installed, which indicates that the required EGLA rating is unlikely to depend on the number of phases on which EGLAs are installed. © 1986-2012 IEEE. © 2012 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T., Uchiyama, Tadao; Y., Fujita, Yusuke; Y., Ueda, Yoshiaki; A., Nishizaki, Aiko; H., Okabe, Hiroshi; S., Takagi, Sunao; H., Mitsuishi, Hiroshi; Y., Kawahara, Yohei; L., Huy, Le; P.N., Trung, Phan Ngoc
Author full names: Uchiyama, Tadao (55317021800); Fujita, Yusuke (55316669200); Ueda, Yoshiaki (55317027100); Nishizaki, Aiko (55316605200); Okabe, Hiroshi (36093307500); Takagi, Sunao (56701718900); Mitsuishi, Hiroshi (37072952300); Kawahara, Yohei (55316682400); Huy, Le (57511815800); Trung, Phan Ngoc (37020370300)
Title: Evaluation of a Vietnam offshore CO2 huff 'n' puff test
Source title: Proceedings - SPE Symposium on Improved Oil Recovery
Affiliations: Japan Oil, Gas and Metals National Corporation, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Uchiyama, Tadao, ; Fujita, Yusuke, ; Ueda, Yoshiaki, ; Nishizaki, Aiko, Japan Oil, Gas and Metals National Corporation, Tokyo, Japan; Okabe, Hiroshi, Japan Oil, Gas and Metals National Corporation, Tokyo, Japan; Takagi, Sunao, Japan Oil, Gas and Metals National Corporation, Tokyo, Japan; Mitsuishi, Hiroshi, Japan Oil, Gas and Metals National Corporation, Tokyo, Japan; Kawahara, Yohei, ; Huy, Le, ; Trung, Phan Ngoc,
Abstract: First CO<inf>2</inf>-EOR application to the offshore oil field in Vietnam has been investigated through an international joint study scheme between Japan and Vietnam since 2007 and a preliminary study outcome indicated feasibility to some extent. To reduce and mitigate uncertainties/risks in the field scale EOR implementation, a CO<inf>2</inf>-EOR pilot test was executed in Vietnam offshore oil field in 2011. The test was conducted as a single-well Huff'n' Puff. CO<inf>2</inf> was injected into the well and the well was flowed after soaking. In order to confirm the CO<inf>2</inf>-EOR effect the following items were monitored during the test: 1) CO<inf>2</inf> Injection Performance 2) Real Time Bottom-hole Pressure/Temperature 3) Oil/Gas/Water/CO<inf>2</inf> Production Performance 4) Fluids' Saturation Change before and after CO<inf>2</inf> Injection 5) Produced Fluid Property & Composition on-site Over 100 tons of CO<inf>2</inf> were successfully injected into the well. Bottom-hole pressure was kept higher than MMP (Minimum Miscibility Pressure) during the injection period, thus miscible condition was considered to be achieved in the reservoir at least near the wellbore. The vertical contrast of CO<inf>2</inf> injectivity and oil saturation change in the reservoir were confirmed by saturation logs and production logs. Clear increment of oil rate, reduction of water cut and oil composition change were observed after CO<inf>2</inf> injection. Simulation study for matching pilot test performance was carried out and its result was in good agreement with the monitored data. Authors: H., Kitamura, Hiroki; L., Zhao, Liwei; T.H., Bui, Thi Hang; S., Okada, Shigeto; J., Yamaki, Junichi
Author full names: Kitamura, Hiroki (55121415100); Zhao, Liwei (8865021600); Bui, Thi Hang (57203943145); Okada, Shigeto (7403456741); Yamaki, Junichi (7005807869)
Title: Effect of binder materials on cycling performance of Fe 2O 3 electrodes in alkaline solution
Affiliations: Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; International Training Institute for Materials Science, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Kitamura, Hiroki, Interdisciplinary Graduate School of Engineering Sciences, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Zhao, Liwei, Institute of Materials Chemistry and Engineering, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Bui, Thi Hang, International Training Institute for Materials Science, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Okada, Shigeto, Institute of Materials Chemistry and Engineering, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Yamaki, Junichi, Institute of Materials Chemistry and Engineering, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan
Abstract: To investigate the effects of binder materials on the electrochemical properties of Fe <inf>2</inf>O <inf>3</inf> electrodes in alkaline solution, four different materials were applied as binders: polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE), polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF), polyethelene (PE), and poly tetrafluoroethylene- co-vinylidene (P(TFE-VDF)). In KOH aqueous solutions, electrodes containing different binders showed quite different properties. The PE-containing electrode showed the highest capacity retention up to 14 cycles (330 mAh g -1, 82.7%). However, capacity fading was observed subsequently, and only 24.6% capacity remained after 30 cycles. In contrast, the PTFE-containing electrode showed continuous capacity fading but the best capacity retention of 38.6% after 30 cycles. Comparing the amount of dropout Fe <inf>2</inf>O <inf>3</inf> from electrodes after charge/discharge measurements, it was reasonable to find that the electrodes with better cycling performance showed less Fe <inf>2</inf>O <inf>3</inf> dropout. When K <inf>2</inf>S additives were applied, both the electrodes fabricated with PTFE and PE showed superior cycling performance, which was attributed to the good stability of PTFE and PE binders. However, when the effect of the K <inf>2</inf>S additive on the Fe <inf>2</inf>O <inf>3</inf> dropout was studied with PTFE-containing electrodes, heavier Fe <inf>2</inf>O <inf>3</inf> dropout was observed in the K <inf>2</inf>S-added electrolyte. This indicated that Fe <inf>2</inf>O <inf>3</inf> dropout was not a dominant factor for the capacity fading of the electrodes. © 2011 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved. All rights reserved. © 2012 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: N., Viet Long, Nguyen; M., Ohtaki, Michitaka; T., Matsubara, Takashi; M.T., Cao, Minh Thi; M., Nogami, Massayuki
Author full names: Viet Long, Nguyen (35334870500); Ohtaki, Michitaka (7005180328); Matsubara, Takashi (55788828300); Cao, Minh Thi (55243894500); Nogami, Massayuki (57202849551)
Title: New experimental evidences of Pt-Pd bimetallic nanoparticles with core-shell configuration and highly fine-ordered nanostructures by high-resolution electron transmission microscopy
Affiliations: Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Posts and Telecommunications Institute of Technology Vietnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nagoya Institute of Technology, Nagoya, Japan; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HUTECH, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Viet Long, Nguyen, Department of Molecular and Material Sciences, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan, Posts and Telecommunications Institute of Technology Vietnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Laboratory for Nanotechnology, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Nagoya Institute of Technology, Nagoya, Japan; Ohtaki, Michitaka, Department of Molecular and Material Sciences, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Matsubara, Takashi, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Nagoya Institute of Technology, Nagoya, Japan; Cao, Minh Thi, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HUTECH, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nogami, Massayuki, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Nagoya Institute of Technology, Nagoya, Japan
Abstract: In our facile synthesis method, poly(vinylpyrrolidone)-protected Pt and Pt-Pd bimetallic nanoparticles with controllable polyhedral core-shell morphologies are precisely synthesized by the reduction of Pt and Pd precursors at a certain temperature in ethylene glycol with silver nitrate as structure-controlling agent. The Pt nanoparticles exhibited well-shaped polyhedral morphology with highly fine and specific nanostructures in the size range of 20 nm. Important evidences of core-shell configurations of the Pt-Pd core-shell nanoparticles were clearly characterized by high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) measurements. The results of HRTEM images showed that the core-shell Pt-Pd nanoparticles in the size range of 25 nm with polyhedral morphology were synthesized with the thin Pd shells of ∼3 nm in thickness as the atomic Pd layers grown on the Pt cores. Very interesting characteristics of surface structure of Pt nanostructures and Pt-Pd core-shell nanostructures with surface defects were observed. The high-resolution TEM images of Pt-Pd bimetallic nanoparticles showed that the Frank-van der Merwe and Stranski-Krastanov growth modes coexist in the nucleation and growth of the Pd shells on the as-prepared Pt cores. It is predicted that the FM growth becomes the main favorable growth compared with the SK growth in the formation of the thin Pd shells of Pt-Pd core-shell nanoparticles. The experimental evidence of the deformations of lattice fringes and lattice-fringe patterns was found in Pt and Pt-Pd core-shell nanoparticles. The interesting renucleation and recrystallization at the attachments between the nanoparticles are revealed to form a good lattice match. In addition, our novel ideas of the largest surface-area superlattices and promising utilization of them are proposed for next generations of various fuel cells with low cost. Finally, the products of Pt-Pd core-shell nanoparticles can be potentially utilized as highly efficient catalysts in the realization of polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cell and direct methanol fuel cell using the very low Pt loading with better cost-effective design. © 2012 American Chemical Society. © 2012 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H., Kitamura, Hiroki; L., Zhao, Liwei; T.H., Bui, Thi Hang; S., Okada, Shigeto; J., Yamaki, Junichi
Author full names: Kitamura, Hiroki (55121415100); Zhao, Liwei (8865021600); Bui, Thi Hang (57203943145); Okada, Shigeto (7403456741); Yamaki, Junichi (7005807869)
Title: Effect of charge current density on electrochemical performance of FeC electrodes in alkaline solutions
Affiliations: Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; International Training Institute for Materials Science, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Kitamura, Hiroki, Interdisciplinary Graduate School of Engineering Sciences, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Zhao, Liwei, Institute of Materials Chemistry and Engineering, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Bui, Thi Hang, International Training Institute for Materials Science, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Okada, Shigeto, Institute of Materials Chemistry and Engineering, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Yamaki, Junichi, Institute of Materials Chemistry and Engineering, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan
Abstract: A composite Fe <inf>2</inf>O <inf>3</inf>C powder was applied as a negative material in ironair batteries. The effect of charge current density on the electrochemical behavior of an electrode in KOH electrolyte without or with K <inf>2</inf>S additives was investigated. In KOH electrolyte, the discharge capacity increased in proportion to the logarithm of charge current density in the range of 10-40 mA cm -2. According to an analysis of Tafel plots of the electrodes, the hydrogen evolution was found to reach its diffusion limit earlier than the reduction reaction of Fe(OH) <inf>2</inf> to Fe as charge current density increased. This was deduced to be the reason for the increase of discharge capacity with current density. But as the density increased further, the discharge capacity decreased because both above reactions reached their diffusion limits. When K <inf>2</inf>S additives were used, a similar phenomenon was observed, with a higher discharge capacity than that without additives. It indicated that the practical capacities of ironair batteries could be increased through the depression of hydrogen evolution by optimizing the charge current density for the batteries. At a charge current density of 50 mA cm -2, the Fe <inf>2</inf>O <inf>3</inf>C electrode showed the highest discharge capacity of 810 mAh g -1-Fe <inf>2</inf>O <inf>3</inf> in K <inf>2</inf>S-added electrolyte. © 2012 The Electrochemical Society. © 2012 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: A trial proficiency test of eight NAA laboratories in Asia using stream sediments
Source title: Journal of Radioanalytical and Nuclear Chemistry
Affiliations: Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation, Sydney, Australia; Tokyo Metropolitan University, Hachioji, Japan; Nagoya University, Nagoya, Japan; National Measurement Institute, Australia, Sydney, Australia; Nuclear Research Institute, Dalat City, Viet Nam; Bangladesh Atomic Energy Commission, Dhaka, Bangladesh; China Institute of Atomic Energy, Beijing, China; Badan Tenaga Nuklir Nasional Indonesia, Central Jakarta, Indonesia; Agensi Nuklear Malaysia, Bangi, Malaysia

Abstract: Eight neutron activation analysis research groups from seven countries have participated in a trial proficiency test under the auspices of the Forum for Nuclear Cooperation in Asia. Three stream sediment reference materials were used in the test. A high degree of proficiency was found in the quantification of Co and Sc and more than 20 elements were well quantified by the majority of laboratories. The results support the use of neutron activation analysis, as practised by the participants, for geochemical mapping. The data produced in this study may provide an opportunity to improve the characterisation of the three reference materials. © Akadémiai Kiadó, Budapest, Hungary 2011. © 2014 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: V.H., Hai, Vo Hong; N.Q., Dao, N. Q.; M., Nomachi, Masaharu
Title: Cosmic ray angular distribution employing plastic scintillation detectors and Flash-ADC/FPGA-based readout systems
Affiliations: University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Hai, Vo Hong, Faculty of Physics and Engineering Physics, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Dao, N. Q., Faculty of Science, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Nomachi, Masaharu, Department of Physics, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan
Abstract: It is known that secondary cosmic rays are high energetic particles which are products of shower particles, when primary cosmic rays from outer space hit the atmosphere molecules. Many studies of cosmic rays show that cosmic flux depends on the depth of atmosphere. At ground level, most secondary cosmic rays are muons, a type of charged particle, and have angular dependence. The purpose of this article was to develop the telescope with two plastic scintillation detectors to investigate the angular distribution of cosmic rays at ground level. Directions of investigation were carried out vertical, 45-degree oblique and horizontal directions with respect to earth surface, approximately from North to South. Electronic readout system was developed from Flash Analog Digital Converter (Flash-ADC) of 8 bits-250Ms/sec, and Embedded Field Programmable Gate Array (FPGA)-based trigger. LabVIEW™ interface was written for controlling trigger system and taking data. For each direction measurement, the deposited energy spectra in the scintillators were obtained. The interest of cosmic-ray events was analyzed for counting. Angular distribution was obtained quantitatively. The experiment has been done at University of Science-HCMC. © Carl Hanser Verlag, München. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.A., Ngo, Tien Anh; T.H., Nguyen, Tra Huong; H.T.V., Bui, Ha Thi Viet
Author full names: Ngo, Tien Anh (37109934900); Nguyen, Tra Huong (55473728600); Bui, Ha Thi Viet (56529069600)
Title: Thermophilic fermentative hydrogen production from xylose by Thermotoga neapolitana DSM 4359
Affiliations: Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Ngo, Tien Anh, Institute of Advanced Energy, Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan, Department of Microbiology, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Tra Huong, Department of Microbiology, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Bui, Ha Thi Viet, Department of Microbiology, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: Biohydrogen production from xylose by Thermotoga neapolitana was investigated in batch culture using serum bottles and a continuously stirred anaerobic bioreactor (CSABR). The effect of various xylose concentrations on growth and H<inf>2</inf> production were studied in small batch culture for highly efficient H<inf>2</inf> production. The highest hydrogen production of 32.1 ± 1.6 mmol-H<inf>2</inf>/L and maximum biomass concentration of 959.63 ± 47.9 mg/L were obtained at initial xylose concentration of 5.0 g/L. To develop a large-scale biohydrogen production system as well as overcome the problems in small batch culture, a continuously stirred anaerobic bioreactor was tested on T. neapolitana in both pH-uncontrolled batch culture and pH-controlled batch culture. The results showed that the production level of H<inf>2</inf> from fermentation in a pH-controlled batch culture was much higher than those from a pH-uncontrolled batch culture for H<inf>2</inf> production from xylose. The H<inf>2</inf> yield in a pH-controlled batch culture on xylose substrate was 2.22 ± 0.11 mol-H<inf>2</inf> mol-1 xylose<inf>consumed</inf>, which was nearly 1.2-fold higher than pH-uncontrolled batch cultures. In order to study the precise effect of a stable pH on hydrogen production, and metabolite pathway involved, cultures was conducted with pH-controlled at different levels ranging from 6.5 to 7.5. The maximum H<inf>2</inf> yield of 2.8 ± 0.14 mol-H<inf>2</inf> mol-1 xylose<inf>consumed</inf> was measured while the pH was maintained at 7.0. The acetic acid and lactic acid production were 2.98 ± 0.15 g/L and 0.36 ± 0.02 g/L, respectively. © 2011 Elsevier Ltd. © 2011 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H.N., Nguyen, Hoang N.; P.A.D., Gaspillo, Pag Asa D.; J.B., Maridable, Julius B.; R.M., Malaluan, Roberto M.; H., Hinode, Hirofumi; C., Salim, Chris; H.K.P., Huynh, Ha Ky Phuong
Author full names: Nguyen, Hoang N. (49864278800); Gaspillo, Pag Asa D. (6602227949); Maridable, Julius B. (49863942500); Malaluan, Roberto M. (6506546119); Hinode, Hirofumi (6603680612); Salim, Chris (23569596300); Huynh, Ha Ky Phuong (54786499200)
Title: Extraction of oil from Moringa oleifera kernels using supercritical carbon dioxide with ethanol for pretreatment: Optimization of the extraction process
Source title: Chemical Engineering and Processing - Process Intensification
Affiliations: De La Salle University, Manila, Philippines; Mindanao State University – Iligan Institute of Technology, Iligan, Philippines; Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Hoang N., Chemical Engineering Department, De La Salle University, Manila, Philippines; Gaspillo, Pag Asa D., Chemical Engineering Department, De La Salle University, Manila, Philippines; Maridable, Julius B., Chemical Engineering Department, De La Salle University, Manila, Philippines; Malaluan, Roberto M., Department of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Mindanao State University – Iligan Institute of Technology, Iligan, Philippines; Hinode, Hirofumi, Graduate School of Science and Engineering, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Salim, Chris, Graduate School of Science and Engineering, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Huynh, Ha Ky Phuong, Department of Inorganic Chemistry, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Abstract: The study involved the extraction of oil from Moringa oleifera (MO) kernels using supercritical fluid extraction (SFE) technique. The arrays of operating parameters are extraction condition, loading configuration, and SC-CO<inf>2</inf> with ethanol addition for substrate pretreatment. It identifies a combination of operating parameters that provide a higher yield. The experiments were conducted in the pressure range of 15-30MPa, 35-60°C temperature interval, average particle size of 0.16-1.12mm and CO<inf>2</inf> flow rate of 0.5m3/h. Adding 10% EtOH for substrate pretreatment, increased 10% in the yield. No significant difference in yield and fatty acid content between the oil from SC-CO<inf>2</inf>-EtOH and Soxhlet extraction with n-hexane was detected. Loading the seeds in multiple-staged trays increased to as much as 26.89% in the yield against randomly packed configuration. Response surface methodology, predicted an optimal oil yield of 37.84% at a pressure of 28.97MPa, 44.30°C temperature, and particle size of 0.54mm. A crossover pressure point of Ben oil was found within the range 22.5-30MPa. © 2011 Elsevier B.V. © 2011 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: N., Viet Long, Nguyen; H., Duy Tong, Hien; T., Asaka, Toru; M., Ohtaki, Michitaka; M., Nogami, Massayuki
Author full names: Viet Long, Nguyen (35334870500); Duy Tong, Hien (7201359741); Asaka, Toru (7005817068); Ohtaki, Michitaka (7005180328); Nogami, Massayuki (57202849551)
Title: Synthesis and characterization of Pt-Pd alloy and core-shell bimetallic nanoparticles for direct methanol fuel cells (DMFCs): Enhanced electrocatalytic properties of well-shaped core-shell morphologies and nanostructures
Affiliations: Nagoya Institute of Technology, Nagoya, Japan; Posts and Telecommunications Institute of Technology Vietnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Interdisciplinary Graduate School of Engineering Sciences, Kasuga, Japan; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Viet Long, Nguyen, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Nagoya Institute of Technology, Nagoya, Japan, Department of Education and Training, Posts and Telecommunications Institute of Technology Vietnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Department of Molecular and Material Sciences, Interdisciplinary Graduate School of Engineering Sciences, Kasuga, Japan, Laboratory for Nanotechnology, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Duy Tong, Hien, Laboratory for Nanotechnology, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Asaka, Toru, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Nagoya Institute of Technology, Nagoya, Japan; Ohtaki, Michitaka, Department of Molecular and Material Sciences, Interdisciplinary Graduate School of Engineering Sciences, Kasuga, Japan; Nogami, Massayuki, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Nagoya Institute of Technology, Nagoya, Japan
Abstract: In our research, we present the controlled synthesis of poly(vinylpyrrolidone) (PVP) protected Pt-Pd nanoparticles of various alloy and core-shell morphologies by modified polyol method with the assistance of AgNO<inf>3</inf>. The Pt-Pd alloy and core-shell nanoparticles were characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM), high-resolution TEM, and electrochemical measurements. The comparison of electrocatalytic properties of Pd-Pt bimetallic nanoparticles was described to confirm their highest catalytic performance. Importantly, the catalytic activity of Pt-Pd alloy and core-shell nanoparticles was investigated to develop novel electrocatalysts in direct methanol fuel cells (DMFCs). The results showed that the core-shell nanoparticles with the thin nanoshells as monolayers exhibit as great nanocatalysts. The correlation among structure, size and morphology was presented in their catalytic characterization. © 2011 Hydrogen Energy Publications, LLC. Published by Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved. © 2013 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.H., Le, Thai Hoa; Y., Tamura, Yukio; M., Matsumoto, Masaru
Author full names: Le, Thai Hoa (36102865800); Tamura, Yukio (57202885982); Matsumoto, Masaru (55773528700)
Title: Spanwise pressure coherence on prisms using wavelet transform and spectral proper orthogonal decomposition based tools
Source title: Journal of Wind Engineering and Industrial Aerodynamics
Affiliations: Tokyo Polytechnic University, Atsugi, Japan; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Le, Thai Hoa, Tokyo Polytechnic University, Atsugi, Japan, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tamura, Yukio, Tokyo Polytechnic University, Atsugi, Japan; Matsumoto, Masaru, Kyoto Daigaku Katsura, Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan
Abstract: This paper presents new approaches to clarifying spanwise pressure coherence on typical prisms using some advanced tools based on continuous wavelet transform and spectral-branched proper orthogonal decomposition. Wavelet coherence and coherence modes have been developed for mapping characteristics of spanwise coherence of pressure and turbulence. Temporal-spectral spanwise coherence maps have been represented in the time-frequency plane and spatial-spectral spanwise coherence maps have been expressed in the space-frequency plane. Some new findings are that spanwise pressure coherence not only depends on spanwise separation, frequency and turbulent conditions, but is also influenced by bluff body flow and time. Intermittent and time-dependent pressure coherence in the time domain has been investigated as the nature of pressure coherence. Furthermore, distribution and intermittency of pressure coherence are significantly influenced by analyzed time-frequency resolutions and parameters of the analyzed wavelet function. The coherence mode has been proposed for better understanding of the effect of bluff body flow on pressure coherence. Physical measurements of surface fluctuating pressure and turbulence have been carried out on typical prisms with slenderness ratios of B/. D=1 and 5 in turbulent flow. © 2011 Elsevier Ltd. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: V., Ca, Vuthanh; Y., Yamamoto, Yoshimichi; N., Charusrojthanadech, Nunthawath
Author full names: Ca, Vuthanh (6603330158); Yamamoto, Yoshimichi (52063971700); Charusrojthanadech, Nunthawath (25960625900)
Title: Improvement of prediction methods of coastal scour and erosion due to tsunami back-flow
Source title: Proceedings of the International Offshore and Polar Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Vietnam Administration of Seas and Islands, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tokai University, Tokyo, Japan; King Mongkut's Institute of Technology Ladkrabang, Bangkok, Thailand
Authors with affiliations: Ca, Vuthanh, Research Institute for the Management of Seas and Islands, Vietnam Administration of Seas and Islands, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Yamamoto, Yoshimichi, Graduate School of Science and Technology, Tokai University, Tokyo, Japan; Charusrojthanadech, Nunthawath, Department of Civil Engineering, King Mongkut's Institute of Technology Ladkrabang, Bangkok, Thailand
Abstract: The 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami caused large-scale erosion and scour on many coasts. If the coastal scour by the first tsunami wave caused the destruction of a dyke, the second tsunami wave may generate much more serious damage. Therefore, it is necessary to research on the improvement of prediction methods for erosion and scour by tsunami. This paper presents a numerical model for the above mentioned purpose. In the model, the sediment transport due to tsunami is simulated by using user-friendly prediction methods, and considering bed load and suspended load transport. Furthermore, prediction methods on the maximum scour depth and its position at the beach in front of a seawall are also proposed. © 2010 by The International Society of Offshore and Polar Engineers (ISOPE). © 2010 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: L., Thanh, Letu; K., Okitsu, Kenji; Y., Sadanaga, Yasuhiro; N., Takenaka, Norimichi; Y., Maeda, Yasuaki; H., Bandow, Hiroshi
Author full names: Thanh, Letu (7004530789); Okitsu, Kenji (56894735200); Sadanaga, Yasuhiro (6603718076); Takenaka, Norimichi (7007012272); Maeda, Yasuaki (55797766600); Bandow, Hiroshi (7004563774)
Title: A two-step continuous ultrasound assisted production of biodiesel fuel from waste cooking oils: A practical and economical approach to produce high quality biodiesel fuel
Affiliations: Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Thanh, Letu, Department of Applied Chemistry, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan, Faculty of Environmental Science, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Okitsu, Kenji, Department of Materials Science, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Sadanaga, Yasuhiro, Department of Applied Chemistry, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Takenaka, Norimichi, Department of Applied Chemistry, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Maeda, Yasuaki, Department of Applied Chemistry, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Bandow, Hiroshi, Department of Applied Chemistry, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan
Abstract: A transesterification reaction of waste cooking oils (WCO) with methanol in the presence of a potassium hydroxide catalyst was performed in a continuous ultrasonic reactor of low-frequency 20 kHz with input capacity of 1 kW, in a two-step process. For the first step, the transesterification was carried out with the molar ratio of methanol to WCO of 2.5:1, and the amount of catalyst 0.7 wt.%. The yield of fatty acid methyl esters (FAME) was about 81%. A yield of FAME of around 99% was attained in the second step with the molar ratio of methanol to initial WCO of 1.5:1, and the amount of catalyst 0.3 wt.%. The FAME yield was extremely high even at the short residence time of the reactants in the ultrasonic reactor (less than 1 min for the two steps) at ambient temperature, and the total amount of time required to produce biodiesel was 15 h. The quality of the final biodiesel product meets the standards JIS K2390 and EN 14214 for biodiesel fuel. © 2010 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved. © 2010 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.; MEDLINE® is the source for the MeSH terms of this document.

Authors: M., Esteban, Miguel; N.D., Thao, Nguyen Danh; H., Takagi, Hiroshi; T., Shibayama, Tomoya
Author full names: Esteban, Miguel (35075976400); Thao, Nguyen Danh (25961169800); Takagi, Hiroshi (35411413700); Shibayama, Tomoya (7101822721)
Title: Pressure exerted by a solitary wave on the rubble mound foundation of an armoured caisson breakwater
Source title: Proceedings of the International Offshore and Polar Engineering Conference
Affiliations: United Nations University, Japan, Tokyo, Japan; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Penta-Ocean Construction Co., Ltd., Tokyo, Japan; Yokohama National University, Yokohama, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Esteban, Miguel, Institute of Advanced Studies, United Nations University, Japan, Tokyo, Japan; Thao, Nguyen Danh, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Takagi, Hiroshi, International Construction Divistion, Penta-Ocean Construction Co., Ltd., Tokyo, Japan; Shibayama, Tomoya, Department of Civil Engineering, Yokohama National University, Yokohama, Japan
Abstract: Although a lot of attention has been paid to develop formulas and methodologies to assess the effect of wind waves on caisson breakwaters, there is still limited understanding of the loadings due to tsunami waves. More specifically, no methodology exists to determine the effect that a partially destroyed armour layer would have on the overall stability of an armoured caisson breakwater. Although Esteban et al. (2008) developed a method to estimate the deformation of a caisson breakwater subjected to solitary wave attack, this method is known the be greatly influenced by the presence of an armour layer in front on the caisson. Thus, laboratory experiments with solitary waves were carried out to clarify the failure mechanism of an armoured caisson breakwater against a comprehensive range a tsunami type events (bore-type, breaking and non-breaking). The results of the experiments show how the load which is exerted by the caisson onto the foundation depends on the depth of water in front of it, the shape of the armour layer and whether the wave strikes the caisson or the armour layer first. Of particular interest, it was found how the presence of armour (in particular a failed or partially constructed armour layer) can sometimes be detrimental to the stability of the caisson itself. Authors: N.T., van Ha, Nguyen Thi; A.P., Ananth, A. Prem; C., Visvanathan, C.; V., Anbumozhi, Venkatachalam
Author full names: van Ha, Nguyen Thi (6507610622); Ananth, A. Prem (57039803900); Visvanathan, C. (56233881200); Anbumozhi, Venkatachalam (57194164736)
Title: Techno policy aspects and socio-economic impacts of eco-industrial networking in the fishery sector: experiences from An Giang Province, Vietnam
Affiliations: Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Asian Institute of Technology Thailand, Khlong Luang, Thailand; Institute for Global Environmental Strategies, Hayama, Japan
Authors with affiliations: van Ha, Nguyen Thi, Faculty of Environment, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Ananth, A. Prem, Environmental Engineering and Management, Asian Institute of Technology Thailand, Khlong Luang, Thailand; Visvanathan, C., Environmental Engineering and Management, Asian Institute of Technology Thailand, Khlong Luang, Thailand; Anbumozhi, Venkatachalam, Institute for Global Environmental Strategies, Hayama, Japan
Abstract: Eco-industrial networking is considered as a new approach for businesses to improve their competitiveness, economic viability and human and ecosystem health. A cyclic material flow with alternative usage of all materials in the loop is an essential feature of an eco-industrial network. While eco-industrial networking has been primarily applied on the high-tech sector, this paper attempts to apply the principles on the fishery sector of An Giang, a Vietnamese province in the Mekong River Delta. An Giang Province has its own market share in the trade of Tra and Basa fish. The industries in the value chain of Tra and Basa are in a situation that forces them to improve their competitiveness to retain the market share. It was found that forming an eco-industrial network and recruiting new businesses to utilize all materials in the process provides additional revenue apart from reducing waste disposal concerns. This paper details the current market situation, the issues faced and material flow patterns and presents a feasible eco-industrial network. The results of the study indicate that the eco-industrial network creates positive impacts in terms of increased competitiveness, improved socio-economic conditions and cleaner environment. © 2009 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved. © 2009 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H.D., Hanh, Hoang Duc; N.T., Dong, Nguyen The; K., Okitsu, Kenji; R., Nishimura, Rokurou; Y., Maeda, Yasuaki
Author full names: Hanh, Hoang Duc (18634087400); Dong, Nguyen The (18633581200); Okitsu, Kenji (56894735200); Nishimura, Rokurou (35578887100); Maeda, Yasuaki (55797766600)
Title: Biodiesel production through transesterification of triolein with various alcohols in an ultrasonic field
Affiliations: Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Hanh, Hoang Duc, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Dong, Nguyen The, Institute of Environmental Technology, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Okitsu, Kenji, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Nishimura, Rokurou, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Maeda, Yasuaki, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan
Abstract: The biodiesel production through transesterification of triolein with various alcohols such as methanol, ethanol, propanol, butanol, hexanol, octanol and decanol was investigated at molar ratio 6:1 (alcohol:triolein) and 25 °C in the presence of base catalysts (NaOH and KOH) under ultrasonic irradiation (40 kHz) and mechanical stirring (1800 rot/min) conditions. It was found that the rate of the alkyl ester formation under the ultrasonic irradiation condition was higher than that under the stirring condition. In addition, it was confirmed that the rate depended upon the kind of alcohols; as the number of carbon in alcohol increased, the rate of the ester formation tended to decrease. On the other hand, the secondary alcohols such as 2-propanol, 2-butanol, 2-hexanol, and 2-octanol showed little ester conversion, suggesting that the steric hindrance strongly affected the transesterification of triolein. © 2008 Elsevier Ltd. Authors: H.D., Hanh, Hoang Duc; N.T., Dong, Nguyen The; K., Okitsu, Kenji; R., Nishimura, Rokurou; Y., Maeda, Yasuaki
Author full names: Hanh, Hoang Duc (18634087400); Dong, Nguyen The (18633581200); Okitsu, Kenji (56894735200); Nishimura, Rokurou (35578887100); Maeda, Yasuaki (55797766600)
Title: Biodiesel production by esterification of oleic acid with short-chain alcohols under ultrasonic irradiation condition
Affiliations: Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Hanh, Hoang Duc, Dept. of Applied Materials Science, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Dong, Nguyen The, Institute of Environmental Technology, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Okitsu, Kenji, Dept. of Applied Materials Science, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Nishimura, Rokurou, Dept. of Applied Materials Science, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Maeda, Yasuaki, Dept. of Applied Materials Science, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan
Abstract: Production of fatty acid ethyl ester (FAEE) from oleic acid (FFA) with short-chain alcohols (ethanol, propanol, and butanol) under ultrasonic irradiation was investigated in this work. Batch esterification of oleic acid was carried out to study the effect of: test temperatures of 10-60 °C, molar ratios of alcohol to oleic acid of 1:1-10:1, quantity of catalysts of 0.5-10% (wt of sulfuric acid/wt of oleic acid) and irradiation times of 10 h. The optimum condition for the esterification process was molar ratio of alcohol to oleic acid at 3:1 with 5 wt% of H<inf>2</inf>SO<inf>4</inf> at 60 °C with an irradiation time of 2 h. © 2008 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: M., Esteban, Miguel; N.D., Thao, Nguyen Danh; H., Takagi, Hiroshi; T., Shibayama, Tomoya
Author full names: Esteban, Miguel (35075976400); Thao, Nguyen Danh (25961169800); Takagi, Hiroshi (35411413700); Shibayama, Tomoya (7101822721)
Title: Analysis of rubble mound foundation failure of a caisson breakwater subjected to tsunami attack
Source title: Proceedings of the International Offshore and Polar Engineering Conference
Affiliations: United Nations University, Japan, Tokyo, Japan; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HUTECH, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Yokohama National University, Yokohama, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Esteban, Miguel, Institute of Advanced Studies, United Nations University, Japan, Tokyo, Japan; Thao, Nguyen Danh, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HUTECH, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Takagi, Hiroshi, Department of Civil Engineering, Yokohama National University, Yokohama, Japan; Shibayama, Tomoya, Department of Civil Engineering, Yokohama National University, Yokohama, Japan
Abstract: Presently, there is no methodology to evaluate the deformation that the rubble mound of a caisson breakwater would suffer if it was attacked by a tsunami. The present paper proposes a methodology to evaluate this deformation based on the method of Esteban and Shibayama (2006), which originally was developed for wind waves. The method was verified by carrying out laboratory experiments using solitary waves and comparing the results to those obtained using the new methodology. Authors: H.D., Hanh, Hoang Duc; N.T., Dong, Nguyen The; C.E., Stavarache, Carmen Eugenia; K., Okitsu, Kenji; Y., Maeda, Yasuaki; R., Nishimura, Rokurou
Author full names: Hanh, Hoang Duc (18634087400); Dong, Nguyen The (18633581200); Stavarache, Carmen Eugenia (7801371456); Okitsu, Kenji (56894735200); Maeda, Yasuaki (55797766600); Nishimura, Rokurou (35578887100)
Title: Methanolysis of triolein by low frequency ultrasonic irradiation
Affiliations: Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Hanh, Hoang Duc, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Dong, Nguyen The, Institute of Environmental Technology, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Stavarache, Carmen Eugenia, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Okitsu, Kenji, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Maeda, Yasuaki, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Nishimura, Rokurou, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan
Abstract: Methanolysis of triolein was investigated at room temperature by 40 kHz ultrasonic irradiation to make biodiesel fuel as methyl esters. It was found that the yield of methyl esters strongly depended on the amount of KOH and the molar ratio of methanol to triolein (M/T) and was highest at the M/T molar ratio of 6/1, KOH concentration of 1 wt% and irradiation time of 30 min. In addition, the effects of sonication on the methanolysis of triolein were discussed in comparison to the effects of stirring experiments. The optimum condition under stirring experiments showed that the molar ratio of M/T, KOH concentration and reaction time were 6/1, 1.5 wt% and 4 h, respectively. These results clearly indicated that the ultrasonic irradiation method would be a promising one compared to the conventional stirring method. The high yield under the ultrasonic irradiation condition would be due to high speed mixing and mass transfer between the methanol and triolein as well as the formation of a microemulsion resulting from the ultrasonic cavitation phenomenon. © 2007 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Application of NAA to air particulate matter collected at thirteen sampling sites in eight Asian countries: A collaborative study
Source title: Journal of Radioanalytical and Nuclear Chemistry
Affiliations: Tokyo Metropolitan University, Hachioji, Japan; Korea Atomic Energy Research Institute, Daejeon, South Korea; Institute for Nuclear Research Vietnam, Dalat, Viet Nam; China Institute of Atomic Energy, Beijing, China; Tohoku University of Community Service and Science, Sakata, Japan; Philippine Nuclear Research Institute, Quezon City, Philippines; Japan Atomic Energy Agency, Kashiwa, Japan; Badan Tenaga Nuklir Nasional Indonesia, Central Jakarta, Indonesia; Agensi Nuklear Malaysia, Bangi, Malaysia; Thailand Institute of Nuclear Technology, Bangkok, Bangkok, Thailand
Authors with affiliations: Ebihara, Mitsuru, Department of Chemistry, Tokyo Metropolitan University, Hachioji, Japan; Chung, Yongsam, Korea Atomic Energy Research Institute, Daejeon, South Korea; Dung, Ho Manh, Institute for Nuclear Research Vietnam, Dalat, Viet Nam; Moon, Jong Hwa, Korea Atomic Energy Research Institute, Daejeon, South Korea; Ni, Bangfa, China Institute of Atomic Energy, Beijing, China; Otoshi, T., Tohoku University of Community Service and Science, Sakata, Japan; Oura, Yoshiji, Department of Chemistry, Tokyo Metropolitan University, Hachioji, Japan; Santos, Flora L., Philippine Nuclear Research Institute, Quezon City, Philippines; Sasajima, Fumio, Japan Atomic Energy Agency, Kashiwa, Japan; Sutisna, null, Badan Tenaga Nuklir Nasional Indonesia, Central Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: Air particulate matter (APM) samples (PM<inf>2.5</inf> and PM <inf>10-2.5</inf>) were collected at 13 sampling points in 8 Asian countries and their chemical compositions were determined by using neutron activation analysis (NAA) with the k <inf>0</inf>-standardization method in addition to conventional comparative method of NAA. Analytical data showed that mass concentration and elemental composition of the APM collected are variable in terms of time and space, and are related to the characteristics of the sampling sites concerned. NAA was proved to be highly effective for the regional characterization of APM in chemical composition. © 2008 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Particles (particulate Matter); Air Particulate Matters; Analytical Data; Asian Countries; Chemical Compositions; Comparative Methods; Neutron-activation Analysis; Pm 10; Pm 2.5; Sampling Points; Sampling Site; Neutron Activation Analysis
Index Keywords: Particles (particulate matter); Air particulate matters; Analytical data; Asian countries; Chemical compositions; Comparative methods; Neutron-activation analysis; PM 10; PM 2.5; Sampling points; Sampling site; Neutron activation analysis
Funding Texts: A collaborative work was initiated through the Forum for Nuclear Cooperation in Asia (FNCA) sponsored by the Japanese Government in 2000, to which China, Indonesia, Japan, Korea, Malaysia, Philippines, Thailand and Vietnam are allied to work together under a general theme of the utilization of research reactor. With this theme, an application of neutron activation analysis (NAA) was adopted as a subtheme in recognition of its importance amongst the participating countries. An emphasis of this collaborative study has been placed on the utilization of NAA in analyzing environmental samples. NAA is capable of determining about 30 elements in air particulate matter (APM) by applying appropriate irradiation, cooling and counting procedures.1With more proper optimization of these procedures, 42 elements could be detected.2 Thus, NAA has been proved to be effective in getting reliable data for APM.

Authors: P.Q., Dzung, Phan Quoc; L.M., Phuong, Le Minh; N., van Nho, Nguyen; Y., Saito, Yoshifuru
Author full names: Dzung, Phan Quoc (15922546400); Phuong, Le Minh (15923642600); van Nho, Nguyen (55665385100); Saito, Yoshifuru (35598714000)
Title: A new on-line approach for determining conducting angles in a multilevel cascaded inverter
Affiliations: Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Hosei University, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Dzung, Phan Quoc, Faculty of Electrical and Electronics Engineering, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Phuong, Le Minh, Faculty of Electrical and Electronics Engineering, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; van Nho, Nguyen, Faculty of Electrical and Electronics Engineering, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Saito, Yoshifuru, Department of Art and Technology, Hosei University, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: An on-line approach for calculating of conducting angles for a multilevel cascaded inverter is presented. The proposed method is a combination of equal voltage-second area and superposition principles. The conducting angle for each voltage level can be determined so that the fundamental component of the output voltage waveform of each H- bridge inverter unit musts accord with each voltage-second area of the reference voltage waveform. This approach can be suitable for calculating of switching angles for any level of multilevel inverter, particularly in case of unequal DC sources. To demonstrate the validity of the proposed method, a simulation study has been done using Matlab/Simulink. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H.D., Hanh, Hoang Duc; N.T., Dong, Nguyen The; K., Okitsu, Kenji; Y., Maeda, Yasuaki; R., Nishimura, Rokurou
Author full names: Hanh, Hoang Duc (18634087400); Dong, Nguyen The (18633581200); Okitsu, Kenji (56894735200); Maeda, Yasuaki (55797766600); Nishimura, Rokurou (35578887100)
Title: Effects of molar ratio, catalyst concentration and temperature on transesterification of triolein with ethanol under ultrasonic irradiation
Source title: Journal of the Japan Petroleum Institute
Affiliations: Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Hanh, Hoang Duc, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Dong, Nguyen The, Institute of Environmental Technology, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Okitsu, Kenji, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Maeda, Yasuaki, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Nishimura, Rokurou, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan
Abstract: The transesterification of triolein with ethanol to make biodiesel fuel was studied under ultrasonic irradiation. The effects of the amount of base catalyst (NaOH or KOH), molar ratio of ethanol to triolein (E/T), and temperature were determined. The ethyl ester concentration increased with increasing reaction time under both ultrasonic irradiation and stirring. The optimum conditions for the formation of ethyl ester under ultrasonic irradiation at 25°C were E/T molar ratio of 6:1, base catalyst concentration of 1 wt, and reaction time of < 20 min. Increases in reaction time and temperature as well as E/T molar ratio contributed to the steady state concentration of ethyl ester. Alcoholysis of triolein by ultra sonic irradiation has the potential for producing cheap biofuels, which could reduce pollution and protect the environment. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Base Catalyst; Biodiesel; Ethanol; Transesterification; Triolein; Ultrasonic Irradiation

Authors: T., Hong, Tranthi; N., Tam, Nguyenngoc
Author full names: Hong, Tranthi (7202830555); Tam, Nguyenngoc (7101712633)
Title: Methodology on Defining Parameters of Enlarged-Bottom Equipment Corresponding to Soil Properties
Source title: Proceedings of the International Offshore and Polar Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Osaka Sangyo University, Daito, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Hong, Tranthi, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tam, Nguyenngoc, Osaka Sangyo University, Daito, Japan
Abstract: The possibility of drilling enlarged-bottom hole depends on the working parameters such as the rotational speed of the main axle ω<inf>1</inf> and the penetration speed of ground blade ω<inf>2</inf> as well as the structural parameters: the pile diameter of the bottom enlarged D, the height of the bottom enlarged, h and the enlarged-bottom angle, α. In this paper, a mathematical model for the working parameter of enlarged-bottom drilling equipment was proposed, establishing the relationship between the working parameter and the soil properties. This model gives a method to calculate exactly the relations between the working parameter, the structural parameters and the soil properties. A group of the boundary conditions, such as overloading and limit values of α, ω<inf>1</inf>, ω <inf>2</inf> are defined. And the causes for the overload of a machine are determined. It is concluded that the enlarged bottom angle value of drilling hole is governed by the resistance of the soil and the relationship between the pile diameter and the torque of the drilling base machine is found to be an exponential. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Affiliations: Ehime University, Matsuyama, Japan; Kochi University, Kochi, Japan; Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam

Abstract: In Viet Nam and other Asian countries, shrimp production in coastal areas has developed rapidly over recent years. However, the expanses of shrimp ponds cause some problems including disease and environment pollution. A case study on environment quality of shrimp ponds in mangrove areas has been taken. This paper lays emphasis on: 1) to access pollution caused by the organic matters and nutrients in shrimp ponds; 2) accumulation of antibiotics in water and mud in-out of shrimp ponds. The organic and nutrient were high and increased during shrimp culture period. The concentrations of antibiotics in water and bottom mud of shrimp ponds were very high. Over 2ppm of trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole were observed in the water samples of shrimp pond. More than 2.5mg/lg wet-mud of norfloxacin and oxolinic acid are found. The findings drawn in this paper would be useful for farmers as well as for managers in controlling environment in shrimp pond in mangrove areas. © 2012 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
